DOC.HEAD: Berlin Mayor and Los Angeles Counterpart Sign Unified Sister-City Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Newly reunited Berlin and Los Angeles formally became sister-cities and their mayors pledged to promote cultural, educational and social exchanges. The agreement signed Friday by Berlin Governing Mayor Walter Momper and Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley extended an existing sister-city arrangement to what was once East Berlin. Bradley and Momper signed the cooperation pact during a ceremony in the City Hall Rotunda. For 23 years, Los Angeles and the area formerly known as West Berlin maintained sister-city ties. Momper was beginning a two-day visit aimed at showing the importance of the role the United States played in German reunification, which became official Wednesday. Friday, Momper addressed the Los Angeles World Affairs Council and the German-American Chamber of Commerce. He was scheduled to attend German-American Day celebrations in Anaheim and in Los Angeles today as well as a dinner-dance hosted by Bradley at the Hyatt Hotel at Los Angeles International Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Conventional Arms Treaty Will be Ready Next Month; Second Pact Lags
DOC.TEXT: A treaty to reduce NATO and Warsaw Pact non-nuclear forces in Europe will be ready for signing next month, but a U.S.-Soviet pact to curb long-range nuclear weapons is lagging even after top-level talks. The conventional arms treaty, the most sweeping arms control pact in history, will be signed at a summit in Paris by the 16 North Atlantic Treaty Organization members and the six-nation Warsaw Pact. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze settled all remaining questions about arms-reduction zones, aircraft ceilings and helicopter restrictions over six hours of talks Friday. ``This is a major accomplishment,'' Shevardnadze said. But the Soviet official said he and Baker were unable ``to reach agreement on every and all issues'' in the path of a U.S.-Soviet treaty to cut long-range nuclear missiles by about 30 percent. That casts doubt on a December summit in Moscow between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, although Baker said ``it's still very possible.'' He said it depends on settling a dispute over transfers to allies of nuclear arms and technology that would be banned under the treaty. Baker said he made ``good progress'' with Shevardnadze on the issue, known as non-circumvention, and that if U.S. and Soviet negotiators in Geneva follow through the two other roadblocks might be cleared. ``We are tired,'' Shevardnadze said, ``but the results are good.'' The two other unsettled issues concern the kinds of SS-18 missile tests the Soviets would be permitted to conduct and whether the Soviet Backfire bomber would be subject to numerical restrictions. Between their two sessions Friday, Baker and Shevardnadze took a break to preside at a ceremony dedicating a new sculpture for the United Nations that symbolizes the growing superpower rapport. The work of Soviet sculptor Zurab Tseretel, titled ``Good Defeats Evil,'' incorporates pieces of intermediate-range nuclear missiles that were dismantled in a 1988 U.S.-Soviet treaty. Baker flew home to Washington and Shevardnadze to Moscow. Their chief arms control aides, who participated in the talks first at the Soviet and then the U.S. mission to the United Nations now will try again in Geneva to reach solutions. And Shevardnadze will visit Washington next month to try to wrap up the treaty with Baker. The Conventional Forces in Europe treaty on which Baker and Shevardnadze did agree would be the largest arms-control deal in history and the first in Europe since the end of World War II. It would take a much bigger bite out of the Soviet arsenal in Europe than the U.S. arsenal. NATO and the Warsaw Pact each would be limited to 20,000 tanks, 20,000 artillery pieces, 30,000 armored combat vehicles and 2,000 helicopters in the area stretching from Europe's Atlantic Coast to the Ural Mountains inside the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Princess Diana had coffee in the White House with Barbara Bush and visited a ``first lady'' of a different kind during a whirlwind 24-hour tour of the nation's capital. The other ``first lady'' she saw Friday is a 3-year-old girl who earned her nickname when she became the first child placed at Grandma's House, a home for children with AIDS. The princess hugged the little girl and gave her a ride in her Rolls-Royce. As cameras flashed, she stepped out of the car with the little girl in her arms - a symbolic picture that gratified the founders of Grandma's House. ``It shows that it's all right to love a person with AIDS, it's all right to care about a person with AIDS, it's all right to hug a person with AIDS ... It won't hurt you,'' said the Rev. Debbie Tate, president of a crisis housing organization that runs Grandma's House. --- SANTA MONICA, Calif. (AP) - Sylvester Stallone, of ``Rocky'' and ``Rambo'' movie fame, won a court order against a persistent fan who he claimed has written letters threatening: ``I'll tie you up if you try to escape from me!'' Elfie Wade of Santa Monica was ordered Thursday to stay at least 200 yards away from the actor's Malibu home and his Santa Monica-based White Eagle Enterprises. ``I am extremely concerned that Ms. Wade may be a great danger and threat to me,'' Stallone said in a written court statement. Wade has dogged Stallone for nearly two years, placing up to 10 letters a day in his mailbox, according to court documents. The temporary order prohibits Wade from following, telephoning or writing to the actor. A hearing on Stallone's request for a permanent injunction was scheduled for Oct. 18. Other stars who have taken court action against obsessive fans include Johnny Carson, David Letterman, Michael J. Fox and Sharon Gless, whose home was invaded by a fan. ----= NEW YORK (AP) - Ivana Trump will write two novels for Simon & Schuster with the help of an unnamed writer described as an ``experienced commercial novelist,'' the publisher said. The name of Mrs. Trump's co-author and terms of the deal were not disclosed in a statement released by Pocket Books, the Simon & Schuster division that plans to publish the first book in 1992. Her estranged husband, developer Donald Trump, recently published his second best seller, ``Surviving at the Top.'' ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - First lady Barbara Bush will appear as herself on a the ABC daytime soap opera ``All My Children,'' using the opportunity to promote life-saving volunteerism. Mrs. Bush, scheduled to appear on the show's Oct. 18 episode, will deliver a public service announcement for the National Bone Marrow Registry as part of the drama's story line, ABC said. The first lady's brief spot complements plot developments surrounding a child character stricken by leukemia whose survival depends on receiving a bone marrow transplant. ---- ROXIE, Miss. (AP) - The mayor of this tiny town is a little embarrassed that makers of Elton John's latest music video chose it as a location site because its streets are chock-full of potholes. The Mississippi Film Office sent producer David Zuckerman pictures of several small towns in the southwestern part of the state, and Roxie ``beat'' the others because of its many bone-jarring pavement craters. ``It was kind of sad that they were here hunting the one thing we were trying to get rid of,'' said Betty Norris, mayor of the town of 600. Elton John, known for songs such as ``Rocket Man'' and ``Goodbye Yellow Brick Road,'' did not come to Roxie, but about 25 film crew members and actors came to shoot footage Sunday for the video for ``You Gotta Love Someone.'' Norris said the town didn't earn any money from the filming, but she hopes it will bring attention to the city's application for a street repair grant. ---= MEDINA, Ohio (AP) - Cartoonist Tom Batiuk is depending on the band director in his comic strip ``Funky Winkerbean'' to inspire readers to deluge ABC Sports with mail in support of more air time for football halftime shows. In a cartoon published today, Harry L. Dinkle, the ``world's greatest band director'' in the daily comic strip, urges readers to clip and mail to ABC a coupon saying: ``Halftime belongs to the bands!'' Batiuk, who draws the strip at his home in this northeast Ohio community about 25 miles southwest of Cleveland, said Friday he wants ABC to know that ``Project Halftime'' is done in fun. Batiuk, who played in the band when he was in junior high school, said he picked ABC as a target because it has broadcast college football games longer than any other network. Mark Mandel, a spokesman for ABC Sports in New York, said Friday the network tries to include aands in at least part of its halftime show.

DOC.HEAD: State Budget Woes Spread Outward from Northeast
DOC.TEXT: State budget crunches are spreading south and west from New England where they began, the National Governors' Association reports. ``The fiscal condition of the states is the worst we have seen since the major recession of 1983,'' NGA executive director Raymond C. Scheppach said Friday in releasing the group's annual fiscal survey of the states. The study attributed the difficulties to a slowing national economy, increased Medicaid costs and the continuing decline in federal aid to states. Over half of the states would have ended their most recent fiscal year with deficits had they not moved to cut spending after their budgets were enacted, Scheppach said. States raised taxes by an expected 10.3 billion, the largest dollar increase ever, the report said. Twenty-six states increased net revenues and seven reduced them. Nearly half the total increase came in three states - Massachusetts, New Jersey and New York. State spending was up 7.7 percent on average in fiscal 1990, but it is expected to grow only by an average of 6.5 percent this year, Scheppach said. Total state year-end balances declined from $12.5 billion in fiscal 1989 to $9.1 billion in 1990, and are estimated to decline to $7.4 billion in fiscal 1991. Those balances - which amount to surplus money after all spending - averaged 4.8 percent in 1989 and are estimated to be down to 3.5 percent at the end of fiscal 1991. State budget officers consider a 5 percent reserve prudent as a hedge against tough times. A regional economic slowdown that hit New England has caused massive financial problems for all six New England states, prompting the region's three Democratic governors to retire and leaving two of three Republican governors in dire political condition. In addition, New York and New Jersey have run into financial trouble, prompting big tax increases. ``What seems to be happening is the turndown in the economy that began in New England ... is now spreading South and West,'' Scheppach said. Adding to state financial problems is the growth in demands for Medicaid spending, the report said. Scheppach pointed to figures showing states increased Medicaid spending by 18.4 percent in 1990, and are estimated to increase them 15 percent to 20 percent in fiscal 1991.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Upholds Nominee's Criticism of Burma
DOC.TEXT: Frederick Vreeland's criticism of Burmese policies that cost him his nomination as ambassador to Rangoon simply upheld the position of the U.S. government, the State Department says. A human rights organization, meanwhile, urged the United States to continue criticizing the Burmese military regime, and to contest its right to Burma's seat at the United Nations. Burma's ruling State Law and Order Council canceled its earlier acceptance of Vreeland as ambassador in objecting to his answers to questions by senators at his confirmation hearing earlier this week. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Friday that the Burmese government informed the U.S. Embassy in Rangoon on Thursday of its decision to withdraw acceptance of Vreeland. The White House then withdrew Vreeland's nomination under the rule that a host country must agree to receive an ambassador. ``Mr. Vreeland's statements reflected the policy and the views of the United States government, including our often-stated view that the military regime should rapidly implement the results of the national elections in May, which should lead to a return to parliamentary democracy,'' Boucher said. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., said Thursday that he believed the nomination was withdrawn because of questions raised about Vreeland's involvement in what DAmato said was a cover up of possible Bulgarian and Soviet involvement in the 1981 assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II. D'Amato said he had intended to question Vreeland at a second hearing about his activities in Rome. Asked if the withdrawal had anything to do with accusations that Vreeland was a CIA agent involved in suppressing the papal investigation, Boucher repeated that the action was taken as a result of the Burmese objections. The State Department spokesman declined to answer questions related to reports of Vreeland's CIA involvement, saying it was department policy not to respond to allegations of intelligence connections or activity. ``He had a career as political and economic officer, various positions at our embassies overseas,'' Boucher said of Vreeland. Asia Watch, a private human rights monitoring group, later urged the Bush administration to maintain a tough stand against rights abuses in Burma. In making a new ambassadorial nomination, it should put Burma on notice ``that the United States regards improvement in the human rights situation as its highest priority,'' Asia Watch Executive Director Sidney Jones said in a statement. Ms. Jones also urged the administration to object to seating the Burmese delegation when the Credentials Committee report is presented next week at United Nations headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: Johnny, Your Mommy is Beeping You
LaserPhoto DX1
DOC.TEXT: A housewife constantly racing to keep up with her active 4-year-old son has found a high-tech way to get him home in a hurry - she beeps him. ``When Jonathan's beeper goes off, he is home, which is nice. He can't argue; he can't say, `Just a minute,' '' said Pat Hammett. ``It's convenient in that I don't have to stand out and yell for five minutes and be one of those screaming mothers.'' The beepers designed for children are the creation of Leslie and John Gilmore, who founded Kid Konnection in this Denver suburb about a month ago. The pagers come in brightly colored cases that can be worn on a child's waist. They can be leased for $14 to $18 a month, which pays for the beeper and the paging service, Mrs. Gilmore said. So far, the fledgling company has received more than 200 inquiries and its clients include a Boulder teen-ager and a hearing-impaired child whose beeper vibrates. ``I think it gives children a sense of responsibility rather than having Mom come out, screaming at them,'' Mrs. Gilmore said. The couple came up with the idea after Mrs. Gilmore quit her job as manager of a local boutique to stay home with her sons, Christopher, 4, and Jeffrey, 18 months. Like her neighbor Mrs. Hammett, Mrs. Gilmore had trouble keeping up with her 4-year-old. ``I thought there ought to be a way to communicate with him when I'm in the house and he's out,'' she said. Christopher said he's happy with the arrangement. ``It protects me,'' he said. ``When it beeps, I come in.'' Mrs. Gilmore said: ``It just has become so routine for him, like brushing his teeth.'' Although the kiddie beeper is a novelty with a purpose, some wonder whether it will cause a high-tech communication gap. Mitch Handelsman, an associate professor of psychology at the University of Colorado-Denver, says the potential problem doesn't have to surface. ``Just as TV can be useful if there is sufficient communication, this beeper technology can become a part of optimal family functioning as long as it does not substitute for important communication,'' he said. The beepers also aren't foolproof. Some children ``will find 100 creative ways to lose the beeper,'' Handelsman said. Mrs. Hammett said that although her son does not leave the house to play without his beeper, the device has not made her complacent. ``I consider myself an overly protective parent,'' she said. ``I still poke my head out the door.''

DOC.HEAD: Pound to Join European Currency System
DOC.TEXT: In a surprise turnaround, Britain has declared it is ready to tie the pound to Europe's exchange rate mechanism. The decision is apt to bolster both European efforts to integrate the continent's economies and British attempts to harness domestic inflation. However, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher stressed her continued opposition to creating a single European bank and a single currency. The announcement Friday by Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major was coupled with word that Britain's base interest rate will drop by one percentage point to 14 percent on Monday. The pound is joining the European exchange rate mechanism at a high level, which the government hopes will ease Britain's 10.6 percent inflation rate. The country's switch from a free-floating currency to a linked one is designed to promote economic stability by limiting disruptive exchange rate movements. The pound and stock market rose sharply on the news because joining the mechanism would set a stable floor under the currency. The sterling joins nine other European Community currencies in Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism: the Spanish peseta, the German mark, the French franc, the Dutch guilder, the Italian lira, the Belgian and Luxembourg francs, the Danish krone and the Irish pound. The Portuguese escudo and the Greek drachma are the only remaining outsiders. Thatcher agreed in principle to link the pound to the other currencies at a community summit meeting in Madrid last year, but she said she would move only when Britain's inflation rate was lower to the European average of 5.5 percent. Britain decided to go ahead because Britain's double-digit inflation is expected to decline, Mrs. Thatcher said. The twin moves of entry into the 11-year-old mechanism and the one-point interest rate cut are ``right for the times,'' the prime minister said, speaking outside 10 Downing Street, her residence. ``The fact that our policies are working and are seen to be working have made both these decisions possible,'' she said. Entering the exchange rate mechanism would ``underpin our anti-inflationary stance,'' she said. Opposition Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock said it was correct to cut interest rates and join the mechanism but that the moves were ``action of cornered government.'' Britain previously linked the pound to other currencies from 1944 to 1971 under a system of fixed but adjustable exchange rates. It then participated in a rate movement-limiting European ``snake'' until 1973. The pound, which has risen sharply in recent months on speculation that it would soon join the exchange rate mechanism, soared to $1.9455 from $1.9185 before the announcement, and to 2.9933 marks from 2.9492 marks. London's Stock Exchange extended trading for an hour because of the announcement. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed Friday at 2,143.9, up 73.5 points, or 3.6 percent, from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEAD: Art World Relieved by Mapplethorpe Verdict; Foes Remain Undaunted
With PM-Mapplethorpe Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Arts patrons hailed a Cincinnati jury's acquittal of a museum and its director for exhibiting sexually graphic Robert Mapplethorpe photos, but critics of the photos said the battle is not over. A Municipal Court jury on Friday acquitted Cincinnati's Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. Barrie could have been sentenced to one year in jail and fined $2,000, and the gallery fined $10,000, if convicted of both misdemeanors. ``I am truly astounded,'' said David Ross, director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, where the traveling Mapplethorpe exhibit closed Friday. ``I had expected the jury to convict. I am more proud to be an American today.'' Floyd Abrams, a New York City lawyer who specializes in First Amendment cases, said similar cases may arise, however. ``Another prosecutor could think, `I'll do it differently. I'll do it better. Put me in front of the jury.''' He also cautioned that the Cincinnati trial alone could discourage controversial museum exhibitions. ``Freedom of expression is worse off today than it was the day before the indictment, but better off than it was yesterday,'' he said. In Tupelo, Miss., the Rev. Donald Wildmon, who heads the conservative American Family Association, said the acquittal does nothing to end the fight to prevent the National Endowment for the Arts from using tax dollars to finance artwork his group considers pornographic and religiously offensive. Endowment officials said NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer would not have any comment on the verdict. ``This is not a landmark, Pearl Harbor decision,'' Wildmon said. ``This was just another obscenity trial.'' He said another court in another city could have ruled differently. But Elliot Mincberg, legal director of the liberal People for the American Way Action Fund in Washington, D.C., called the verdict a ``clear-cut victory for free expression and the First Amendment.'' ``Today's verdict is a repudiation of the far right's campaign to vilify artistic expression in America,'' Mincberg said. Joy Silverman, ssociate director of the National Campaign for Freedom of Expression, a nonprofit group representing artists, applauded ``the courage of the jurors in Cincinnati.'' ``They have not caved in to the censorship hysteria initiated by members of the far right,'' said Ms. Silverman. Conservative lawmakers and religious fundamentalists have led the fight against the NEA's partial financing of the touring exhibition of photos by the late Mapplethorpe, several of which are sexually graphic. Ralph Reed, a spokesman for the Rev. Pat Robertson's Christian Coalition, said: ``We are disappointed in the outcome but this is a long struggle and we recognize that we cannot win every case. ``The 2 Live Crew verdict in Florida earlier this week more than counterbalances this unfortunate verdict.'' A record store owner was convicted of obscenity Wednesday in Fort Lauderdale for selling a sexually explicit album by the rap group. Debbie Bennett, public relations director for 2 Live Crew's label, Luke Records, said the Cincinnati jury's decision encouraged her on the eve of the rap group's own obscenity trial next week. ``I guess America is looking up,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: UDC Students Agree to End Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10 graf pvs, bgng: `Talks had,' to ADD board chairwoman's resignation
DOC.TEXT: University of the District of Columbia students ended a protest that immobilized the school for 11 days, but they failed to win their chief demand - ouster of the most of the school's trustees. After all-day discussions Friday, students accepted a agreement in which trustees agreed to lobby the City Council to restructure the board and expand it from 15 to 21 members. School officials also granted nearly all of about 40 other student demands for improvements in academic and athletic programs. ``This is a new day at UDC,'' protest leader Mark Thompson told a crowd of cheering students late Friday night. ``Never again will a UDC student be referred to in a negative light. We have proven that we are concerned about our situation here.'' ``We have reached an agreement that will serve the university well,'' Trustee A. Knighton Stanley said. ``Never again will students at UDC be implied to be inferior to any students in the United States of America.'' Several dozen protestors at the 12,000-student public institution seized control of a university building Sept. 26, demanding that the 11 mayoral appointees to the board resigned. The students claimed the board was controlled by political friends of Mayor Marion Barry who allowed the school's quality to deteriorate. They also said the school's accreditation was in jeopardy. Students voted to approve the agreement only minutes before an 11 p.m. deadline set by trustees, who said they would withdraw the offer and end negotiations at that time. Thompson said students would remain in the building until a signing ceremony, set for 12:30 p.m. Sunday. Talks had stalled for several days over the issue of the resignations, with most board members refusing to quit. Board Chairwoman Nira Long resigned effective Oct. 16, however. Stanley said two board members who agreed to resign did so for personal reasons that had nothing to do with the protest. Stanley offered his own resignation to speed along dialogue. A source close to the negotiations said trustees regarded the students' request for resignations as ``foolish.'' Such a move would have put the school in a legal limbo, opened the trustees to charges they had abandoned their fiduciary responsibilities and jeopardized the school's accreditation, said the source, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. Trustees decided to end negotiations Friday night if no agreement had been reached because they feared students leaders had lost control of the protest, the source said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Bishops Defend Celibacy of Priests
DOC.TEXT: American bishops at a Vatican meeting said the Roman Catholic Church should keep the rule of priestly celibacy, despite criticism that it is driving some potential candidates from the ministry. ``If the church is singing the same tune as everybody else, who needs the church?'' Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, head of the U.S. bishops' conference, told reporters Friday. ``That's why I am persuaded that celibacy is much more important than it has ever been before.'' He and other prelates at the international synod said the church and celibacy represent a ``countercultural force'' showing there is more to life than the pursuit of personal satisfaction. The issue of celibacy has been raised numerous times during the first week of the monthlong synod, an advisory body convened by Pope John Paul II to discuss the formation of priests. More than 200 bishops are attending. The pope has indicated he will not change the celibacy rule, and the Vatican moderator at the synod has said the issue should not even be discussed. Still, some bishops have questioned the requirement and suggested that allowing ordination of married men could help alleviate the shortage of priests in some areas. The number of priests in the world has dropped from 406,000 to 400,000 the past five years. In the United States, the number of students in the last four years of seminary was 3,698 this year, compared with 7,855 in 1968. The celibacy rule is based on the view that sex and marriage would prevent the priest from giving his complete attention to the work of God. In his comments, Pilarczyk dismissed the idea that the number of priests should be used as a yardstick of the strength of the church. ``It's not necessarily the case that the more priests you've got, the better off the church is,'' Pilarczyk said. Cardinal Joseph Bernardin of Chicago said steps must be taken to halt ``the erosion'' in the understanding and appreciation of celibacy. ``There are many positive values to celibacy,'' he said. ``I think the people who can best (espouse those values) are the priests themselves. You hear some priests complaining, but there are many, many wonderful priests, the vast majority, who live a chaste, celibate life and get a great deal from their ministry.'' The American church was shaken this summer when Archbishop Eugene A. Marino of Atlanta resigned following revelations of a two-year ``intimate relationship'' with a young woman. However, Bernardin said the percentage of Amercan priests who have been involved in sexual scandals ``is really very small.'' ``We don't want to downplay or minimize the seriousness of those problems that do exist,'' he said. ``We are trying to handle them as best we can.'' A Canadian prelate, Auxiliary Bishop Frederick Bernard Henry of London, Ontario, told the synod Wednesday that the church needs programs of psychosexual testing to monitor the sexual maturity of priests. He noted that recent cases of sexual abuse by priests had caused ``deep soul-searching'' in the Canadian church. In July, a church-appointed commission reported priests had sexually abused boys in Newfoundland for more than a decade and the church had failed to stop the practice.

DOC.HEAD: Art Gallery and Director Acquitted in Mapplethorpe Exhibit
LaserPhoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: Sexually graphic photos by Robert Mapplethorpe have artistic value, a jury ruled in acquitting an art gallery and its director of obscenity charges in a closely watched trial. A Hamilton County Municipal Court jury Friday cleared Cincinnati's Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, of one count each of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related photos in the exhibit, ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment.'' Barrie said he was grateful at the outcome in the nation's first obscenity trial of an art gallery, but lamented that battles over artistic freedom were still being waged. ``I'm glad this fight is over in Cincinnati, but it's not over in the rest of our country,'' he said. ``I will be in a number of cities speaking about this issue.'' Next week in Florida, members of the rap group 2 Live Crew face trial on obscenity charges for performing songs from their sexually explicit ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' album, which a federal judge had ruled obscene. Earlier this week, a Florida jury found a record-store owner guilty of obscenity for selling the album. Barrie smiled slightly as the first of the four innocent verdicts was announced, and his smile widened as a court clerk read each subsequent verdict. Gallery supporters shouted and applauded. The four-man, four-woman jury, composed mostly of working-class suburbanites, reached its verdict after five days of testimony and two hours of deliberations. If Barrie had been convicted of both misdemeanor charges, he could have been sentenced to one year in jail and fined $2,000. The gallery could have been fined $10,000 if convicted on both counts. ``This was a major battle fought here today, not some minor incident in the city of Cincinnati,'' Barrie said. ``It was a major battle for the arts and for creativity and for the continuance of creativity in this country ... '' The Rev. Donald E. Wildmon, whose American Family Association in Tupelo, Miss., has fought National Endowment for the Arts funding for exhibits such as Mapplethorpe's, said the trial was not that significant. ``This is not a landmark, Pearl Harbor decision. This was just another obscenity trial,'' Wildmon said. ``I think this really puts the NEA issue right back in the political arena where it belongs.'' Barrie, 43, testified during the trial that he and the gallery's board had never wavered in their decision to bring the controversial exhibit to Cincinnati. ``Robert Mapplethorpe was a great artist, it was a beautiful show, it should have never been here in court,'' he said. Mapplethorpe died of AIDS at age 42 in March 1989. The Cincinnati charges were based on seven photographs a grand jury cited from the 175-photo exhibit. Five of the photos have homosexual or sadomasochistic subjects; two show children with their genitals exposed. The exhibit attracted little attention in its first showings in Philadelphia and Chicago, but in Washington it angered Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and other congressional conservatives. Their attack forced the Corcoran Gallery of Art to cancel the show in mid-1989. It also prompted the new director of the National Endowment for the Arts, John Frohnmayer, to require that artists sign a statement agreeing to not use NEA funds to make obscene art. Some have turned down grants in protest. The exhibit drew more than 80,000 people during its seven-week run in Cincinnati, an attendance record for an art exhibit in the city. The traveling show closed this week in Boston, where 103,000 tickets were sold. During closing arguments, Assistant City Prosecutor Frank Prouty told jury members it was up to them to decide the artistic merit of the photographs. ``Are these van Goghs, these five pictures?,'' he asked as he went into graphic descriptions of the photos of the adults. H. Louis Sirkin, Barrie's attorney, said the photos undoubtedly offended some people but had serious artistic merit. He also reminded jurors that the same exhibit was shown in other cities without incident. ``Is Cincinnati that different? Are we that childish?'' Sirkin asked. ``Are we not big enough to say we can't accept what other cities have seen?''

DOC.HEAD: Preliminary Probe Clears NIH Researcher, Investigation to Continue
DOC.TEXT: A preliminary investigation has discredited allegations that a National Institutes of Health researcher falsely claimed to have discovered the virus that causes AIDS, the head of the NIH said. Dr. William F. Raub, acting director of the Bethesda, Md.-based institutes, said Friday, however, that he had ordered a full-blown investigation despite the fact that the initial inquiry had ``resolved certain of the publicized allegations and issues or shown them to be without substance'' in the case of Dr. Robert C. Gallo. Raub said Gallo and Gallo's research team in the Laboratory of Tumor Cell Biology found the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, on their own. Gallo's group ``had a substantial number of HIV detections and isolations from several different sources at the critical time'' that Gallo's lab was growing both the virus it isolated and a virus it had been given by a French team. Independent discovery of the virus has been credited to both Gallo's team and the Pasteur Institute team led by Dr. Luc Montagnier. Montagnier's team published its results first, and the French and United States governments agreed to settle a lawsuit over priority, with researchers from both teams sharing royalties from the blood test. In an article published last November, the Chicago Tribune raised questions about whether Gallo's team found the virus on its own or found, inadvertently or otherwise, what it had been given by the French team. NIH said its preliminary investigation determined that Gallo's team found the virus independently. Raub said the formal investigation will try to determine the origins of the virus that Gallo and his colleagues used to develop the blood tests. ``Subjects of the investigation are Dr. Gallo and Dr. Mikulas Popovic,'' Raub said. He said the investigation would focus on ``several aspects of published reports'' by Gallo's team, particularly the May 4, 1984 article by Gallo, Popovic and others in the magazine Science that announced discovery of the virus. An NIH spokesman said the other authors are not being investigated. Raub said investigators would test ``a number of biological samples in an effort to determine the origins'' of the virus used to develop the blood test used today to detect HIV. Raub did not say what ``several aspects'' he had in mind, and the spokesman, Don Ralbovsky, said ``we really can't go into other detail.'' The investigation will be conducted by the Office of Scientific Integrity, an arm of NIH, with consultants nominated by the National Academy of Sciences and its affiliate, the Institute of Medicine. There was no answer at Gallo's home Friday night.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Rebels Claim Capture of Provincial Capital
DOC.TEXT: Moslem guerrillas claim to have captured a provincial Afghan capital after several days of heavy battles. The rebel report came during escalated fighting in Afghanistan's 10-year-old civil war. A spokesman for the Moslem insurgents based in Pakistan, Hamid Karzai, said the guerrilla forces on Friday overran Terin Kot, about 180 miles south of Kabul, the Afghan capital. He said the victory followed several days of heavy battles. Some Islamic green flags of the insurgents flew from buildings in the city, the capital of Uruzgan province. However, it was not possible to confirm the rebels' claim that they controlled it. The assault on government troops defending Terin Kot was launched by guerrillas of several rebel groups with headquarters in Pakistan. For more than a dozen years, U.S.-backed rebels have been fighting to topple Kabul's government. Moslem insurgents reportedly control much of the countryside, but they have been ineffective in destroying government defenses around most cities and control only a handful of the towns. Moscow has been the major backer of the government in Kabul. However, the Soviets withdrew the last of their soldiers from Afghanistan in February 1989. Since then, President Najibullah has tried to distance himself and his party from its communist roots, claiming to have rekindled the spirit of Islam. Rebel leaders have dismissed that effort and vowed to press on with their efforts to overthrow his government. Bitter feuding among rebel leaders has stymied the resistance, however. For several months, Moscow and Washington have been trying to work out a settlement to end the war. They are reportedly close to an agreement that calls for new national elections. The stumbling block has been the composition of a caretaker administration to oversee the vote. After a lull of several months, renewed fighting and rocket attacks have been reported throughout the country. Earlier this week, 61 people died and scores were injured in rocket attacks on the Afghan capital.

DOC.HEAD: Burial Insurance Is a Big Hit on LA's Gang-Plagued Streets
DOC.TEXT: Parents of young gang members and other children exposed to street violence are snapping up low-cost life insurance policies designed to soften the blow of burial and funeral services. One insurance salesman said door-to-door sales calls in some of the city's most gang-plagued areas were paying off, especially when they were made shortly after shootings in the neighborhood. ``We are doing fantastic business,'' said Magdy Barsoum, an Inglewood district manager for American National Insurance Co. Insurance industry officials challenged the ethics of such sales calls, but Barsoum defended the practice, saying otherwise many would not be able to obtain needed coverage. Parents ``are finding out that a lot of young kids are dying from gangs, shootings and accidents. We pay out $70,000 to $80,000 a month on violent deaths,'' Barsoum said, The $10-a-month policies typically provide $5,000 to $10,000 in coverage. Many are bought simply to cushion funeral and burial costs that average $4,000, he said. Barsoum said his 30 sales agents scan newspapers for reports of drive-by shootings and other gang violence, then move quickly - articles in hand - to the afflicted neighborhoods. Such crime stories are ``one of our best sources for customers,'' Barsoum said. ``We take the newspaper out with us and say, `Look here, your kids are in danger.' '' American National officials at company headquarters in Galveston, Texas, do not approve. ``If there is any truth to that type of marketing it will be discontinued,'' company spokesman Dan Wood said. ``That's certainly not the way we do business, never has been.'' ``This is not the kind of practice we would support or what our code of ethics outlines as an appropriate practice,'' said Betty Combs, spokeswoman for the California Association of Life Underwriters. ``It is inappropriate to play on people's fears,'' she said. ``Life insurance is a product to be sold to families in need, not on what their fears are.'' Others say the technique provides coverage to residents in poor neighborhoods who otherwise could not afford premiums set by territorial rating, which often produces high rates in low-income areas. ``I have never heard of an insurance company actively seeking out a market like this,'' said Gene Grabowski, spokesman for the American Council of Life Insurance in Washington. ``But it sounds like they are being smart by providing a need.'' Barsoum has some satisfied customers. Darryl Redford, 21, said he purchased a $10,000 policy in July after a rash of drive-by shootings. ``I've seen too many people get shot,'' Redford said. ``Heaven prevent me from getting caught in a cross-fire, but this insurance will bury me if I do.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Contract to Northrop Criticized by House Leader
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force decision to award two new contracts to a division of the Northrop Corp. that is under suspension is being criticized by the chairman of a House panel. ``Combine this with the Navy's disclosure at our last hearing that it had granted a waiver to purchase 104 gyroscopes for the Harrier jet, and it appears that the suspension is not even a slap on the wrist,'' said Rep. John Conyers. The Michigan Democrat chairs the House Government Operations Committee and its subcommittee on legislation and national security. Northrop Corp.'s Precision Products Division was suspended from doing business with the Pentagon about 15 months ago. The company earlier had been indicted for allegedly falsifying test results on the Harrier jet fighter-bomber and air-launched cruise missile. On Sept. 19, the Air Force the suspension to purchase replacement parts for gyroscopes on the Minuteman missile and those used in the Paved Penny Laser Target Identification System on the A-10 and A-7 aircraft. The Air Force said in a statement that it had granted the waiver ``to insure Paved Penny equipped A-10s deployed for Desert Shield have sufficient spares to support night-time operations with precision-guided munitions.'' Operation Desert Shield is the Defense Department's code name for the deployment of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf. The Air Force said it waived the suspension for the Minuteman parts because they had become ``critically short due to utilization rates and manufacturing lead times.'' Such a shortage would ``adversely affect the high-alert status required for this important part of our security deterrence,'' said Maj. Phyllis Phipps-Barnes. Conyers previously held a hearing on the AV-8B Harrier jet, four of which the Marine Corps grounded because of faulty sensors that stabilize the aircraft. At the session, Col. James Hart, the Marine Corps officer for the program, said it had waived the suspension against Northrop to buy a package of spare rate sensor assemblies for $300,000 for the Harrier. In the statement criticizing the Air Force, Conyers leveled a new attack against the Harrier, which costs $20 million per aircraft. Over the past six years, six servicemen have been killed in accidents involving the aircraft. The most recent incident occurred Tuesday, when a Marine jet pilot was killed during a training mission in North Carolina. ``It defies my imagination that the Navy finds acceptable these losses and continues to operate a system with such a high fatality rate and proven record of severe reliability problems,'' Conyers said. The Marine Corps has nearly 200 Harriers, made by McDonnell-Douglas Corp. under license from a British manufacturer. The Harriers, needing no runway to take off, can be based in forest clearings and other unorthodox places to provide close support and air cover for Marine units.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Government Closed Three Times In Past Decade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government was forced to shut down temporarily three times in the past decade due to squabbles between the administration and Congress over the budget. -The government closed briefly in November 1981 when an estimated 400,000 employees were dismissed at midday after President Reagan vetoed an emergency money bill. -On October 4, 1984, about 500,000 government workers were sent home by Congress' failure to approve an appropriations bill. But they were told to be back at their desks the next day after the Senate late in the day adopted an emergency spending measure. -On October 16, 1986, the government sent 500,000 non-essential employees home at midday, but Congress later in the day passed an appropriations bill acceptable to Reagan and workers were ordered to report on their next shift. More than 1{ million employees, including more than a million who work for the Defense Department, stayed on the job. Those who got the half-day furlough included the president's maids and gardeners. Only one out of four employees was considered non-essential. Congress, as it had done in 1981 and 1984, passed a resolution ordering that employees furloughed get their regular salaries anyway. Payments to furloughed workers cost the government an estimated $85 million in 1981 and $65 million in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Union Leaders Blast Mayor They Helped Elect Over Layoff Proposal
DOC.TEXT: A defensive Mayor David Dinkins apologized publicly to municipal union leaders, saying they were ``justifiably annoyed'' about his abrupt proposal to lay off up to 15,000 city workers. ``The unions should have been advised'' beforehand, the mayor said Friday. ``We were going to do it, but it happened in a time frame that did not make it possible. That's no excuse.'' Dinkins said Thursday that he may be forced to send out pink slips to deal with an expected budget deficit in fiscal 1992 of $1.4 billion. The move puts New York among other Northeastern cities that are letting workers go because of a sluggish economy bordering on recession. The city's proposed layoffs and other agency reductions would save the city $800 million. The mayor also ordered an immediate freeze on hiring and merit raises in order to save another $115 million in payroll costs. The announcement drew criticism from the unions that put Dinkins over the top last November and made him the first black mayor of New York. The outcry came because Dinkins had not consulted his allies first. ``The mayor has declared war on the unions in the city. He has spit in the eye of public employees through this unilateral action,'' said Barry Feinstein, president of Teamsters Local 237, which has about 12,000 city workers. ``I feel betrayed, I swear, I really do,'' Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37, which represents 140,000 city workers, said Friday. ``We have a tremendous problem. Those 15,000 workers are going to come from the guts of us.'' The mayor also has proposed new taxes to close a $1.8 billion budget gap for this fiscal year. This week, New York went on a fiscal roller coaster ride. On Monday, it settled its first union contract with a 5.5 percent raise for teachers. Union leaders, including Feinstein and Hill, said then that they expected the city to be as generous with them. On Tuesday, the mayor proposed a $1.8 billion plan to fight crime in the city, including the hiring of nearly 8,000 police officers and a severe increase in taxes. Hill said the hurt lingered despite an apology he said the mayor offered overnight. ``We helped elect him. He only won by 2 percentage points. He knows we played a vital role in making sure he won,'' Hill said. ``We didn't have to fight this hard to elect a mayor who would lay off 15,000 workers.'' The city faced an even worse budget crunch in 1975 when it nearly went bankrupt and laid off about 25,000 workers. This time, New York joins New Haven, Boston, Philadelphia, Trenton, N.J., and Baltimore in using layoffs to balance the budget.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Vetoes Textile Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush vetoed a bill that would mean strict quotas on imports of textiles and shoes. Bush, in vetoing the bill Friday, said the measure ``picks the pockets of U.S. consumers'' by driving up prices to the tune of $2,600 per family over four years. He said also the bill would cause an ``economic calamity'' by forcing a collapse of international trade talks. Congress had ignored Bush's veto threats in adopting the legislation, which imposes quotas on imports of textiles, textile products and non-rubber shoes. International trade agreements regulate trade in textiles and impose other quotas. ``This highly protectionist bill would damage the national economy, increase already artificially high costs to consumers of several basic goods and abrogate our international agreements,'' Bush's veto message said. Disputing claims by the bill's supporters, Bush said the textile industry was doing well. Domestic production has been up slightly since 1987, he said, and unemployment in major textile-producing states is lower than the national average.
DOC.HEAD: Air Force Calls Up 844 Reserve Members From Four States
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force said it had called additional reserve and National Guard units to active duty to support the U.S. troop buildup in the Persian Gulf. The 844 reservists and guardsmen called up Friday bring to 5,167 the number of Air Force reserve members activated since President Bush on Aug. 22 authorized the Pentagon to use reserves in Operation Desert Shield. Those called to active duty included: -206 members of the 914th Tactical Airlift Group of the Air Force Reserve at Niagara Falls, N.Y. -187 members of the 927th Tactical Airlift Group of the Air Force Reserve at Selfridge Air Force Base, Mich. -224 members of the 130th Tactical Airlift Group of the Air National Guard at Charleston, W.Va. -227 members of the 136th Tactical Airlift Wing of the Air National Guard at Dallas. The total number of reserves called up from all services is 27,947.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Proposes Legislation To Give Trade Benefits To Andes Nations
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has proposed giving a decade of preferable trade benefits to four South American nations in response to their cooperation in the war on drugs. Bush's Andean Trade Preference Act, proposed Friday, is patterned after the Caribbean Basin Initiative that gives special trade benefits to Caribbean nations. The beneficiary countries would be Peru, Colombia, Ecuador and Bolivia. Also addressed in the Andean proposal Bush sent to Congress is the long festering trade dispute with Colombia over cut flowers, which would be made duty free. The measure would authorize duty free treatment for 10 years for some imports from the countries along the Andean mountains, which also are the principle source and production countries for the cocaine trade. Products ``particularly sensitive to import competition'' will not be duty free, the White House said. Those products include, textiles and apparel, canned tuna, petroleum products, watches and watch parts. Luggage, leather apparel and flat goods would be eligible for a duty reduction program. The administration is trying to provide economic incentives and assistance to South American countries that have suffered in cracking down on lucrative drug industries that greatly buttress their poor economies.
DOC.HEAD: Heat Gets To Weather Service Computers
DOC.TEXT: An air conditioning system failure caused the National Weather Service to lose power to its main computers in Suitland, Md., officials said. The power loss occurred about 8 p.m. Friday and the computers were brought back on line about an hour and 15 minutes later, Washington lead forecaster John Billet said. He said while technicians were attempting to power up backup computers in Kansas City ``some reports got lost in the process.'' Billet said some hourly observations that airport authorities file to the NWS to compile their reports were delayed or lost.

DOC.HEAD: Riot-Rocked Osaka Neighborhood Calms Down
DOC.TEXT: A riot-torn neighborhood in western Japan was littered with broken glass, burned-out cars and twisted bicycles but was quiet today after another night of violence by laborers. A police official blamed leftist day workers angry about a police bribery scandal for touching off the four days of riots. At least 159 people, including 125 police, have been injured in the violence in the Nishinari district of Osaka, the nation's second-largest city, prefectural police officials said. More than 1,000 people pounded riot troopers with gasoline bombs and rocks from Friday night until well into the early morning hours, and almost 50 people had been arrested, a prefectural police official said. At least 12 vehicles parked along the streets were burned overnight, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Most of the protesters had dispersed by early this morning, but a cordon of armored troopers continued to guard the police station. Elementary schools closed Friday due to the riots, but reopened today. Osaka prefectural police, however, said the current calm may not mean the end of the local upheaval. Menial laborers in the area have previously demonstrated against low wages and other issues. But the scope of this week's violence is extremely unusual for Japan, where issues rarely stir such passions or protests. A police officer speaking on condition of anonymity said the disturbance started Tuesday after an argument broke out between a man who had been collecting cardboard in the streets and leftist workers, one of whom was bitten by the man's dog. Police took the man into the station for questioning. Leftists then took up the man's cause and massed outside. They began shouting for the man's release and violence broke out after a larger crowd gathered and accused the police of bribery, he said. The following day a local policeman from the Nishinari station was arrested on suspicion of having taken $81,000 in bribes from two gangsters in exchange for providing information about police operations against the gang. Authorities said that menial laborers with longstanding grudges against police joined the disturbance at first but gradually dropped out, while outside hooligans and students as young as junior high schoolers continued rioting. Police reported two stores were set ablaze early Friday and a train station also was heavily damaged by fire. Several shops, including a 24-hour convenience store, were looted. The rundown district, nicknamed the ``Airin'' district by locals, is notorious for gangs, many transient laborers and shabby hotels. Relations between residents and police are strained, locals say. Local residents and human rights activists have complained about police anti-crime measures, including 24-hour surveillance cameras on street corners.

DOC.HEAD: Accused S&L Chief Says He is Innocent of Fraud Charges
DOC.TEXT: Financier Charles Keating, who became a symbol of the nation's thrift crisis, says he is ``absolutely'' innocent of fraud charges in junk bond sales arranged through his failed Lincoln Savings & Loan. Keating and three co-defendants entered innocent pleas Friday to an array of charges that accuse them of bilking investors in American Continental Corp. junk bonds sold through Lincoln branches. The Arizona developer listened quietly as Deputy District Attorney William Hodgman read a summary of the 42-count indictment in a packed courtroom. ``Mr. Keating, as to the charges against you in this indictment, how do you now plead?'' asked Hodgman. ``Absolutely not guilty,'' Keating answered in a loud voice. Co-defendants Ray C. Fidel, Robin S. Symes and Judy Wischer, officers of Lincoln or American Continental, then answered ``not guilty'' to the charges. They are free but Keating has been unable to post his $5 million bail. Keating, 66, was chairman of Phoenix-based American Continental, which owned Irvine, Calif.-based Lincoln. The S&L has failed and experts estimate the cost of its bailout will reach $2 billion. Keating has been in jail since he surrendered to face the indictment on Sept. 18 and bail was set at $5 million. Neal has said Keating is broke and has argued for a reduction to $500,000, a sum his children can help post. Prosecutors believe there were 17,458 bondholders who lost a total of $250,138,000 on American Continental Corp. junk bonds, most of which were sold at Lincoln branches in California. The indictment only lists 20 victims who lost $1,183,000. Prosecutors say they limited the scope of the case to make it easier for the jury to follow. The case was assigned for trial to Superior Court Judge Lance Ito and a hearing was scheduled for Oct. 15 to discuss further motions in the case. Each of the defendants could face as much as 10 years in prison if convicted of six or more of the 42 counts. Fidel, 32, was president of Lincoln; Symes, 37, was its chief executive officer; and Wischer, 42, was president of American Continental. Fidel and Symes had to post $100,000 bail. Wischer had to post $200,000. Outside court, defense attorney Stephen Neal said, ``Mr. Keating is looking forward to defending himself on these charges.... He is confident of being vindicated.''

DOC.HEAD: Buckley Creates PAC To Target Weicker
DOC.TEXT: Conservative political columnist William F. Buckley Jr. has created a political action committee to work against Lowell Weicker's third-party bid for governor. Buckley chose the same name for his committee as one chosen by one of Weicker's top lieutenants for his own committee. Buckley likely will have to come up with a new name for his Committee for Connecticut's Future, said the secretary of state's office. That's the name of an organization set up by state Senate Minority Leader Reginald Smith, who is serving as Weicker's chief fiscal adviser.
DOC.HEAD: Congressional Candidate in Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: A Republican congressional candidate who has suggested that government be run like a business says he has two bankruptcy petitions pending. Gregory Cochran blamed his personal and business bankruptcy actions on other people. He filed for personal bankruptcy in 1987 and bankruptcy on his defunct Cochran Exterminating Co. in 1988. He said the petitions are pending in U.S. Bankruptcy Court. Cochran opposes Democratic Rep. Bart Gordon in the November election. ``I might say that bankruptcy is something that happens to everyone - sometimes to many people,'' Cochran said. ``The man (Abraham Lincoln) who started the Republican Party failed in business and one of the best Democratic presidents, Harry Truman, filed for bankruptcy.'' He also said bankruptcy has helped prepare him for public office. ``It shows I certainly know all the problems that you can get into,'' Cochran said.

Democratic state treasurer candidate Ray Shaffer says he's in a campaign bind because of voter sympathy for his opponent, Bob Seale, hurt in a Labor Day plane wreck that killed Seale's wife. Shaffer also questioned whether Seale would be ``emotionally stable enough'' to handle the treasurer's job because of the death of his wife, Judy. ``I have trouble bringing out the negatives because voters may perceive it as attacking someone who is incapacitated,'' Shaffer said. Seale was a landslide winner in the primary election a few days after the plane wreck, defeating incumbent Treasurer Ken Santor 2-to-1 margin. ``I have compassion and sympathy for Bob, but ... all of a sudden he is made out a hero and is the frontrunner ... I would not want to see him elected because of sympathy,'' said Shaffer. Seale is expected to be released this week from a Reno hospital, but probably will make only limited campaign appearances before the Nov. 6 election. Brad Lawrence, Seale's campaign manager, refused to comment on haffer's statements.

Congressional candidate Oliver Luck has offered a public television station $4,500 to help pay for a televised debate with Democratic Rep. Harley O. Staggers Jr. Luck, a Republican lawyer, offered half the money needed by WNPB-TV in Morgantown to televise the debate, scheduled Oct. 25 at Alderson-Broaddus College in Philippi. Alvin Prichard, the station's programming director, said Friday he cannot accept money from Luck's campaign without receiving a similar contribution from Staggers. Staggers' campaign coordinator, Larry Thompson, did not say whether Staggers would match Luck's offer, but predicted the debate would be on public television. Prichard said the station cannot afford to broadcast the debate without sponsors or donations.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Warn Mosquito-Borne Disease Likely to Keep Spreading
DOC.TEXT: A mosquito-borne encephalitis outbreak is likely to spread in Florida because the blood-sucking bugs flourish through mid-December in the warm, moist climate, scientists say. The state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services on Friday confirmed 28 cases of St. Louis encephalitis and listed 10 more as likely cases involving the often disabling disease - all in central and south Florida. ``Where it goes from here is anybody's guess,'' department spokesman Ernie Durfee said in Tallahassee. Since the outbreak was first identified in mid-August, the hardest-hit area has been the state's central Atlantic coast. Indian River has 10 cases and three more presumed to be encephalitis. Orange County - with the state's biggest tourist attractions - has three confirmed and another person presumed to have it. Fifteen people are hospitalized and two - both over age 55 - are comatose, health officials said. Researchers said they suspected as early as June that an epidemic was imminent in Florida because of rainfall patterns and the number of test chickens found to have been bitten by infected mosquitos. ``We watched the epidemic unfold in front of us, right from the beginning ... and we feel that possibly the worst part of the epidemic may still be ahead,'' said Jonathan Day, an entomologist with the University of Florida's Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences. Encephalitis is an inflammation of the brain causing fever, sore throat, headaches, confusion and muscular weakness. In severe cases of this incurable disease, it causes convulsions, coma and death. The carrier is a small, brownish, common backyard mosquito that officials say is relatively timid and bites only during nighttime hours. Durfee said infants and those over 55 are most susceptible because babies have undeveloped immune systems and older people have depressed immune systems. The St. Louis strain last surfaced in Florida 13 years ago with 110 cases confirmed and eight deaths attributed to it. The disease is cyclical, occurring every 10 to 15 years because of a combination of factors such as rainfall and mosquito hatchings, Durfee said. But not all mosquitoes are carriers. ``Out of every 1,000 mosquitoes at random in Florida, four could carry the type virus. And out of those four the number that have it is very low - generally less than 1 percent,'' Durfee said. Ten to 14 days after a mosquito becomes infected, it can transmit the virus through its bite. Mosquitoes can't pick up the virus from infected humans, but they can from infected birds. ``We've been sampling mourning doves, common grackles, blue jays, cardinals, mockingbirds and boat-tailed grackles,'' Day said. ``In the mourning doves and common grackles we're looking at 100 percent infection.''

DOC.HEAD: `Graying' Catholic Church Hopes to Woo More Baby-Boomers
DOC.TEXT: Catholic leaders gathered this weekend to plan ways to attract the baby-boom generation, an age group that tends to shy away from active Catholicism. ``The membership is acknowledging that their members are getting grayer, getting older,'' said Paul K. Henderson of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops in Washington. ``The institution recognizes itself that there is a significant component of the population missing.'' Data indicate the average parishioner is 47 years old, while the average age of an American is 22, said John Fontana, chairman of the Re-Generating Catholicism Steering Committee. ``There's a gap there. It's a gap that almost begins with the baby boomers and beyond,'' Fontana, 40, said in an interview Friday, the first day of the convention. The meeting ends Sunday. Besides thorny issues like the church's blanket condemnation of abortion and birth control, a national trend of declining interest in religion persists. ``It's not just the Catholic Church having this problem,'' he said. ``It's also a problem in mainline Protestant churches.'' William McCready, a public-opinion researcher from Northern Illinois University, said young parishioners think ``the church hasn't paid a lot of attention to them.'' McCready, a scheduled speaker at the conference, said the bottom line is that ``young people tend to shy away from organized religion.'' He said 25 percent of Americans are Catholics - between 55 million and 70 million people - with probably half of those being active members. ``The fundamentalist churches have drawn some young people, but nowhere near what the Catholic Church has lost. Most of them are just sitting on the sidelines,'' said McCready, who is not a Catholic. The conference defined a baby boomer as 25 to 45 years old, but McCready said the term more accurately applies to people between 30 and 45. The baby boom was the great increase in the U.S. birthrate in the years after World War II. Henderson, a committee member, said priests, in short supply, are so busy they sometimes don't pay enough attention to young adults. ``Somehow we're not making that linkage between the gospel message and what young people are looking for: a sense of direction,'' said Henderson, 37. He said church leaders had been advised that ``young adults do not always feel welcome in parishes or in their churches'' and they think activities too often are aimed at older adults. In the past, churches were the main place to socialize on Sundays, but Fontana noted that different activities dominate an increasingly secular United States. ``There is more competition for time,'' he said. ``There are health clubs; there are shopping malls open on Sunday.'' The church and youth leaders gathering in Chicago from around the country don't expect to solve the problem at the conference, but they want to identify and discuss possible solutions. Fontana, a doctor of ministry candidate, said declining participation by the young comes despite an increase in young people's interest in spirituality, documented in a Gallup survey. ``I'm not sure the church is tapping into that,'' he said. ``I think they're putting forth doctrine rather than helping people ascertain meaning in their lives.'' Fontana, who works with young adults at Chicago's Old St. Patrick's Church, said that church had grown from four to 1,200 members in the past seven years. Its members are predominantly between 22 and 40. To woo young Catholics, Fontana said, priests and parishioners must show hospitality to the newcomers - ``just greeting them, welcoming them.'' Also, he said, ``Our worship services need to speak to their lives. Often times a homily doesn't connect with people's personal lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Gather for Annual Storytelling Festival
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Mibre in final graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people are gathering here this weekend to hear tall tales, old yarns and new stories, to learn about heroic spiders and know-it-all crows, and to sympathize with people on party lines. The occasion is the 18th annual National Storytelling Festival, which takes place in Tennessee's oldest town. Hearing other people tell stories nurtures the soul, said Jane McElroy, a veteran attending her fifth festival. ``It really speaks to something down deep,'' she said. ``It makes us understand ourselves better.'' Those who heard Johnny Moses on Friday also got to know his story well. Moses, a Nootka shaman, told about the ``animal people'' of years ago, repeating the opening line of the story four times in his native language. ``Usually we repeat things four times in case you weren't listening the first time, the second time or the third time,'' he explained. Moses, known as Walking Medicine Robe, was chosen by his people in Washington state and British Columbia, Canada, to pass on their tribal traditions at the festival in Jonesborough, which was founded in 1779. Moses told the story of ``Mr. Know It All,'' a crow that ignored the warnings of the mosquito, the bear, the flea and the slug to stay away from the beach. The bird wound up as Octopus Lady's dinner. Donald Davis, a storyteller from Waynesville, N.C., told about his Uncle Frank's experiences with modern technology in the form of a telephone that had eight houses connected on one party line. Martha Holloway, a grandmother from Texas, told a story from ``The Prince of Tides'' by Pat Conroy, about a collection of black widow spiders that saved two children from an intruder. This year's festival runs through Sunday and includes 17 featured storytellers. Sponsors say they expect 6,000 people to attend. ``It just has a personal appeal - what it is I don't know,'' said Jean Currey, who made her fourth trip from Atlanta. ``Most of them have a message of some sort.'' The festival began in 1973 with four featured storytellers speaking from the back of a farm wagon to an audience of about 60. ``I think there has been a tremendous renaissance in the last 15 years,'' says Milbre Burch, an Atlanta woman attending her sixth festival. ``People just love to sit and listen to people tell stories.''

DOC.BYLINE: Persian Gulf Crisis at a Glance
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
Iraq accused the United States and its allies of bringing ``the entire world to the brink of a devastating war'' in a quest to gain control of the Middle East's oil. In a speech Friday for the U.N. General Assembly, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said the nations were seeking to control oil so they could manipulate the ``needs of the world, and especially the needs of the peoples of the Third World.'' --- Israel reacted angrily to disclosures by Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak that Iraq and Israel have had indirect secret contacts for years. Eliyahu Ben-Elissar, chairman of the Israeli Parliament's defense and foreign affairs committee, on Friday accused Mubarak of ``psychological warfare.'' --- In Washington, five senators called for a Pentagon investigation of how Iraq might have obtained the technology to make fuel-air explosives. The Pentagon sought to play down any fears over the explosives. They are highly effective against troops in the open, but not against hardened targets like fortifications. --- Iraqi President Saddam Hussein met in Baghdad with an aide to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and accepted a message from the Soviet leader. The official Iraqi News Agency did not disclose its contents. --- The U.S. State Department said about 300 Americans and foreign-born family members have signed up for an evacuation flight due to leave Kuwait on Wednesday. U.S. officials say that at least 900 Americans remain trapped in Kuwait and Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: William F. Buckley Jr. to Step Down as National Review's Top Editor
DOC.TEXT: William F. Buckley Jr. says he plans to resign within two weeks as ranking editor of the National Review, the biweekly news magazine he founded 35 years ago as a bastion of conservative thought. Buckley, who said he will take a position as editor at large, announced his plans Friday night at the close of the magazine's 35th anniversary banquet at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He said National Review's anniversary issue, to be published in two weeks, would be his last as ranking editor. Buckley said in an interview with The New York Times that he is also resigning as the magazine's chief executive officer and will be succeeded by Wick Allison, the magazine's publisher. He said the new ranking editor will be John O'Sullivan, who will also keep his title as editor. Buckley said he has watched the magazine flourish over the years. ``National Review is now recognized as a central journalistic document,'' he said. ``Even people who oppose it would miss it, I think, because they recognize that it is a crucible through which conservative thought gets laundered and ventilated.'' He added that the magazine ``did as much as anybody, with the exception of himself, to shepherd into the White House Ronald Reagan.'' Buckley, 64, is also the longtime host of the public television program ``Firing Line,'' as well as a syndicated columnist and the author of several books.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Paper Says Terry Waite to Be Released Next Week
DOC.TEXT: Anglican church envoy Terry Waite and other Western hostages in Lebanon might be released next week, the nation's leading newspaper said today. The respected An-Nahar attributed the front-page report to unidentified sources. It did not say how many hostages may be freed and mentioned only Waite by name. The report said Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati is to visit the Syrian capital of Damascus ``in the next two days for consultations with the Syrian command'' of President Hafez Assad. Velayati, the sources said, also ``might travel to Beirut for talks with President Elias Hrawi and other Lebanese officials.'' Syria, with 40,000 peacekeeping troops deployed in predominantly Moslem Lebanese regions since 1976, is the main power broker in Lebanon. Iran is the main backer of Hezbollah, or Party of God, the Shiite Moslem umbrella for underground factions holding most of the 13 Western captives missing in Lebanon, including four Britons. ``The release of a number of foreign hostages held in Lebanon, topped by Anglican church envoy Terry Waite, is possible next week,'' An-Nahar quoted the informed sources as saying. It did not elaborate. An-Nahar has proved reliable in the past in its reports on the hostages. The story contained only a one-paragraph reference to the hostage issue. It also said Velayati was to work out with Syrian and Lebanese leaders a settlement to the 3-year-old bloody power struggle between Hezbollah and the mainstream Shiite Amal militia, which has killed more than 1,000 people. Hussein Musawi, the Shiite mentor of some hostage-holding factions, said Sept. 29 that the four British hostages would benefit from the recently restored diplomatic ties between Britain and Tehran. However, Musawi said the six American captives were not expected to be released soon due to the American military deployment in the gulf region following Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The other Western captives are two West Germans and an Italian. There has been a flurry of reports about the possible release of British hostages since Britain and Iran restored ties after a rupture of 18 months over British author Salman Rushdie's novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' Moslems say the novel is blasphemous. ``Improving relations and the new British conduct toward Iran would serve British interests in general, including the British hostages,'' said Musawi, whose Islamic Amal movement is part of the Hezbollah umbrella. Waite, 51, a personal emissary of Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie, disappeared Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his hotel in Moslem west Beirut for a meeting with Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War. The group is believed to hold American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland. No group has claimed responsibility for Waite's abduction, but former Irish hostage Brian Keenan, released in August, said he was held with the Anglican envoy for a while in the same house. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held among the 13 Western captives in Lebanon. Anderson, 42, was kidnapped March 16, 1985. In addition to Waite, the british captives are journalist John McCarthy, World War II flier Jack Mann and writer Alec Collett. McCarthy, 33, of Barnet, North London, was kidnapped April 17, 1986, as he drove to Beirut airport to catch a flight to London. Mann, 76, was kidnapped in Beirut May 12, 1989. Collett, a New York-based writer on assignment in Lebanon for the U.N. Relief and Works Agency, was kidnapped March 25, 1985. The Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Moslems, believed linked to Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal, claimed April 23, 1986 it hanged Collett in retaliation for Britain's support of the U.S. air raids on Libya earlier that month. The group released a videotape purportedly showing Collett, then 63, dangling from a scaffold. No body has been found, but British officials believe Collett is dead.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Security Council Gives OK for Haiti Election Monitors
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council has approved U.N. monitors for Haiti's elections, and France pledged $2 million to help organize the voting. The Security Council's action came Friday in a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, approving his plan to help the Caribbean nation with its Dec. 16 elections. The U.N. General Assembly is expected to give final approval Monday. Haiti is struggling to introduce democratic government. The impoverished country, which declared independence from France in 1804, has been ruled by military force during most of its history. The last attempt at free elections collapsed in 1987 when thugs backed by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters. In recent months, former members of the security service of ousted dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier have returned to Haiti. Many Haitians worry they will interfere in the elections. Perez de Cuellar has indicated he will send 87 staff members, 80 election monitors and 150 military personnel at a cost of about $10 million. Haitian President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot opposes the presence of armed personnel, however. Diplomats say most Haitians consider armed security men as oppressors after three decades of dictatorship by the Duvalier family. On Thursday, Haiti's Electoral Council signed an agreement with the Organization of American States for about 25 OAS poll watchers to monitor the campaign and election. Another team of election observers will be led by former President Jimmy Carter. The request for U.N. observers touched off a battle in the Security Council between the United States and a coalition of Cuba, China and Colombia. The United States backed the plan. The other three nations contended that there was no threat to international peace posed by the Haitian situation and that the council therefore had no jurisdiction. In announcing its electoral aid, the French Embassy in Haiti said Friday that France was contributing the $2 million to support a civic education campaign and the printing of ballots. The United States has pledged $6.4 million in electoral assistance.
