DOC.HEAD: Kemp Spurns fellow Republican, Endorses Conservative in New York Race
DOC.TEXT: Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp has endorsed Conservative Party gubernatorial candidate Herbert London over Kemp's fellow Republican Pierre Rinfret, according to a published report. Kemp, a former congressman from Buffalo, made the endorsement Friday night at National Review magazine's 35th anniversary celebration, The New York Times reported in today's late editions. London and Rinfret are running against Gov. Mario Cuomo in the Nov. 6 statewide election. London, who did not attend the dinner, said earlier he didn't expect to get Kemp's endorsement. In his endorsement, Kemp also took shots at Rinfret who has come under fire for his public criticism of fellow Republicans, including state party leaders. ``Any candidate who runs for governor of New York and criticizes Ronald Reagan for cutting taxes does not deserve to be our candidate,'' Kemp said.

DOC.HEAD: Princess Caroline's Husband Buried as Thousands Mourn
DOC.TEXT: Several thousand people crowded around the cathedral today where a tearful funeral was held for Princess Caroline's husband, Stefano Casiraghi, killed in a boat-racing accident. The 33-year-old princess, wearing sunglasses, a heavy black-lace head-covering and black dress, wept occasionally during the 55-minute service. Casiraghi, 30, an Italian businessman, was killed instantly Wednesday when his boat flipped while racing at high speed in the World Offshore Racing championships. The somersault ejected co-pilot Patrice Innocenti, who was hospitalized with injuries. Casiraghi, defending the championship he won in 1989 in Atlantic City, N.J. remained strapped in the boat, which slammed him headfirst into the ocean. ``The brutality of his death adds to our pain,'' intoned Roman Catholic Archbishop of Monaco Joseph Sardou during the solemn ceremony. ``The sea, so calm today, holds dangers that must constantly be confronted.'' Caroline sat in the front row between her father, Prince Rainier, and brother, Prince Albert. Princess Stephanie, Caroline's younger sister, wept throughout and had to exit the service for a short time. Albert left briefly to comfort her. Caroline's three children from her seven-year marriage to Casiraghi were not present. Sardou praised Casiraghi as ``an exemplary sportsman and businessman,'' but said, referring to Caroline: ``It was through his union with you, madame, that he found the greatest expression of his Christian faith.'' Pallbearers carried Casiraghi's mahogany coffin to the nearby Chapel of Peace for burial in a spot overlooking the stretch of Mediterranean where his boat flipped over. The 115-year-old cathedral could hold just 1,600 of the several thousand mourners who began lining up early today to attend the ceremony. The rest remained outside. Mourners allowed entrance included Danielle Mitterrand, wife of French president Francois Mitterrand, and a host of celebrities, businessmen and political figures from around Europe. Thousands of large and small floral bouquets covered the cathedral steps in a myriad of bright colors and pastels, offerings from Monaco subjects, corporations and the principality's famous casinos. Brightly colored shorts and T-shirts worn by tourists contrasted with the stark black worn by Monaco's citizens. Armed police kept a close watch on the crowd. Casiraghi's accident marks the second time in eight years the royal family ruling this wealthy Riviera principality has suffered sudden, tragic death. In September 1982, Princess Grace - former Hollywood star Grace Kelly - died of injuries suffered in a car accident. Princess Grace was Rainier's wife and the mother of Caroline, Albert and Stephanie. Most of Monaco's small shops closed for an hour during the ceremony. Sardou's eulogy drew tears from mourners, some of whom remebered Princess Grace's death. ``I was here for Grace's funeral and now I'm here to mourn young Stefano. There is a curse on the royal house,'' said one elderly Italian woman. A white-uniformed, five-man honor guard wearing red-tasseled hats stood stiffly at attention during the ceremony. Sunlight steamed through the small stained-glass windows. Caroline wept as she walked out holding her father's arm. The princess decided to bury her husband at the simple chapel over the objection of her in-laws, who wanted him interred in Italy, French and Italian newspapers reported. Casiraghi married Caroline in a civil ceremony in 1983. He had been racing at world-class level since 1984 and had told friends he planned to quit after this season.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Blasts Off With Solar Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Launch director ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with comments from launch director. Picks up 12th graf pvs: `NASA's two ...'; SUBS 19th graf, `About six ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with crew getting go-ahead to proceed with preparations to deploy satellite. Picks up 20th graf pvs: `While swinging ...'
DOC.TEXT: Discovery thundered into orbit today with five astronauts and a nuclear-powered sun probe, ending the shuttle fleet's second-longest grounding ever and boosting NASA's battered credibility. The 100-ton spaceship rode a 700-foot-pillar of flame at 7:47 a.m. EDT through a thin bank of clouds and then into a sky flushed by a rising sun. The liftoff was 12 minutes late because of showers near a shuttle emergency landing runway at the Kennedy Space Center and a momentary technical glitch. Discovery began NASA's 36th shuttle flight and the first in 5{ months. The probe tucked inside its cargo bay was to be sent on a 1.86 billion-mile journey to study the sun's unexplored poles. Two minutes into the flight, the two solid fuel rockets burned out and dropped into the Atlantic Ocean. Discovery continued upward on the thrust of its three main liquid fuel engines, reaching a 184-mile-high orbit 6{ minutes later. ``It was just a fantastic sight to see this thing go,'' said Ed Massey, a project administrator for NASA. ``We think it's fantastic, and it's also a great plus to the nation that the shuttle fleet is up and flying again.'' ``After 18 years, you can't help but feel good,'' said scientist Edgar Page, who started working on the project in 1972 for the European Space Agency. NASA had been counting on a successful flight to help boost its image, battered this year by a string of failed launch attempts, the Hubble Space Telescope's flawed mirror and this week's accident involving another shuttle, Atlantis. Workers forgot to remove a 9-foot-long beam from Atlantis, and the metal piece banged around the orbiter as it was being lifted into an upright position. Launch director Bob Sieck said he did not know whether to describe the team's mood today as ``one of euphoria or relief.'' Sieck said the team was confident heading into liftoff ``in spite of the distractions and the disappointments that have occurred recently, which would tend to overshadow a lot of good work that's been put in to get ready for this mission.'' ``The team worked real hard for this, Sieck said. ``They earned it. They got their reward - finally.'' The major hurdle to launch - fueling - went smoothly. No dangerous leaks were detected as more than 500,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen gushed into the shuttle's external tank earlier today. NASA's two other space shuttles, Columbia and Atlantis, sprouted hydrogen leaks during fueling and had to be returned to the hangar for repairs. Discovery was the last shuttle to fly, in April, and is the only craft in which hydrogen leaks were not found. The longest shuttle-fleet grounding was 2{ years, after Challenger exploded shortly after liftoff in January 1986, killing all seven crew members. Discovery also was the first shuttle to fly after that hiatus, launching a successful mission in September 1988. The latest Discovery mission isn't being affected by a shutdown of government agencies because of the dispute over the federal budget. Kennedy Space Center spokesman Dick Young said funds for the mission already had been set aside. A federal judge in Washington also sided with NASA on Friday in denying a request by environmentalists to delay the mission for safety reasons. The solar probe Ulysses contains nearly 23.7 pounds of radioactive plutonium-238. It will provide electricity for the 807-pound satellite during its five-year, $750 million mission to study the sun's poles. Ulysses would be the first spacecraft to orbit over the sun's polar regions. All previous craft circled over the equator. NASA's chief scientist, Lennard Fisk, said he expects Ulysses to ``revolutionize our knowledge of the sun and the region of space that surrounds it.'' The European Space Agency satellite has been waiting to be carried aloft since 1983. About six hours after liftoff, Discovery's crew, commanded by veteran astronaut Dick Richards, was to send the spacecraft hurtling toward the planet Jupiter at a speed of 34,450 mph, making it the fastest man-made object in relation to Earth. The crew was given the go-ahead two hours into the flight to begin reparing for Ulysses' deployment. While swinging around Jupiter, Ulysses will receive a gravity assist that will slingshot it toward the sun. The satellite is expected to pass over the sun's south pole in 1994 and the north pole in 1995. The rest of the four-day mission involves experiments, including one in which a fire would be started in a sealed chamber in an effort to improve safety on future flights. In addition to Richards, the crew consists of pilot Robert Cabana and mission specialists William Shepherd, Bruce Melnick and Thomas Akers.

DOC.HEAD: Launch Brings Joy to European and NASA Officials at Ulysses Mission Control
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Today's launch of the Ulysses spacecraft aboard the shuttle Discovery delighted European and NASA officials whose agencies began discussing the solar exploration mission 18 years ago. ``Everybody's absolutely elated,'' said Willis Meeks, NASA's Ulysses project manager at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, which will serve as mission control for the sun-orbiting spacecraft. Before today's launch, ``I was waiting for the nerves to come,'' Meeks said. ``A couple of minutes after liftoff, my body went crazy for five seconds.'' Ulysses, which will orbit the sun's poles in 1994 and 1995, rode into Earth orbit as space shuttle Discovery was launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla. It was to be deployed from the shuttle later today. The $750 million mission is a joint project of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the European Space Agency. The Europeans will control Ulysses from NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, while NASA officials will provide tracking and other ground support. NASA's Johnson Space Center in Texas serves as mission control for the shuttle flight. About 50 ESA and NASA engineers and scientists in the Jet Propulsion Laboratory's mission support area broke into applause and shook hands with each other as Discovery lifted off. Another 50 VIPs watched the launch on closed-circuit television from the laboratory's auditorium. ``We are very pleased this was such a wonderful launch,'' said Willy Brado, ESA's assistant director of operations. ``Now an exciting and very interesting mission can begin.'' Meeks said the idea for a mission to explore the sun's polar regions was devised in 1959 by John Simpson at the University of Chicago. Discussions between NASA and ESA started in 1972, said Edgar Page, Ulysses science coordinator for the European agency. The launch of twin spacecraft first was planned for 1983, then rescheduled for 1985. In 1981, NASA's budget woes reduced the mission to a single satellite due for launch in May 1986. The Jan. 28, 1986, explosion that destroyed the shuttle Challenger forced another delay. ``We had a lot of hiccups over the years,'' Page said, adding that finally seeing Ulysses in space means ``you can't help but feel good.'' ``I've been waiting for this since the early 1970s,'' said Bruce Goldstein, NASA's deputy project scientist for Ulysses. ``It's been a long time.'' Brado said the launch will help restore the confidence of European governments in manned space flights for launching scientific spacecraft. ``I have to congratulate NASA on this very successful and very impressive launch,'' Brado said. ``If this had failed, it would have had repercussions at ESA.'' Meeks added: ``I'm feeling really great. We needed this one.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Accuses United States of Oil Grab, Washington Calls It `Lies'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Saudi Arabia recalling envoy to Jordan, Arabs arrested in Cairo, PLO call not to attack Egypt, Briton dies in Kuwait, Britain withdraws two staffers from Kuwait Embassy; Editing; No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2,3 XJFD1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq told U.N. members that the United States and its allies were trying to control the world's oil reserves, but the U.S. ambassador dismissed the charges as lies. Other nations, including the Soviet Union, joined the angry replies to Iraq's latest accusations, made in a speech at the United Nations on Friday. Saudi Arabia's ambassador said Iraq had committed ``an unforgivable crime, a crime to shine in the history of crimes'' by invading Kuwait on Aug. 2. Saudi Arabia, meanwhile, has recalled its ambassador to Jordan, diplomatic sources said today, in another indication of souring relations between the Arab neighbors over the Persian Gulf crisis. Jordan has shown pro-Iraqi sympathies. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, had no information on the reasons that precipitated the Saudi decision. The recall of ambassador Mohammed al-Fahd al-Isa is tantamount to a freeze of relations between the two kingdoms. In Washington, there was renewed concern over Iraq's military potential. Five senators called for a Pentagon study of how Iraq might have gained technology to make so-called fuel-air explosives. The bombs have 10 times the power of conventional explosives without the fallout of nuclear weapons. Military officials say the United States has no ready defense against the explosives, which could devastate oil fields, air bases and troops, the Los Angeles Times newspaper reported Friday. In a prepared speech to the U.N. General Assembly, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz accused the United States and its allies of bringing ``the entire world to the brink of a devastating war'' in a quest to control the Middle East's oil. He said the United States and its friends ``are seeking to gain control over the oil reserves in the gulf so as to have a free hand in manipulating the needs of the world, and especially the needs of the peoples of the Third World, for this important commodity.'' Aziz said the U.N. Security Council was hypocritical when it penalized Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait while allowing Israel to continue occupying Arab lands seized in wars in 1967 and 1973. In the speech read by an Iraqi envoy, Sabah Talat Kadrat, Aziz said all Middle East problems - ``Palestine, Lebanon, the gulf and others'' - should be considered on the same basis. Aziz did not come to New York to deliver it because the United States denied landing rights for the Iraqi delegation's plane. Kadrat and the Iraqi delegation left the hall when a Kuwaiti delegate, D. Razzooqi, replied that ``there are no falsifications of facts similar to what we have heard from the representative of dictator Saddam Hussein.'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering called Iraq's address ``an insult to the Iraqi people, who deserve to be told no more lies.'' Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir Petrovsky rebuked Iraq, saying, ``We cannot but feel some satisfaction at the unprecedented unity in the Security Council.'' The United States and other nations have sent tens of thousands of troops and scores of warships to the gulf region in a bid to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The United Nations has imposed air and sea embargoes on Baghdad and said force may be used to uphold it. In other developments: -In Cairo, a state newspaper said today that authorities have arrested 30 Arabs - 23 Palestinians and seven Iraqis - sent by Iraq to attack city squares, tourist attractions and other targets to create disorder. -Also in Cairo, the PLO's chief representative in Egypt today urged Palestinians living here not to be drawn into actions aimed at ``destabilizing Egypt's security.'' -In London, the Foreign Office said today a 46-year-old British man has died in Kuwait after suffering an undisclosed illness. The man, William Norrie Atack, a Scottish scientist, had worked in Kuwait for eight years as a scientific officer at the ministry of public health, his family said. -The British Foreign Office also said that two of the four British Embassy staff in Kuwait left today for Baghdad. Britain made the decision to withdraw the two men last month, to leave more supplies for the two remaining. -An aide to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev left Iraq today after meeting with Saddam a day earlier. He reportedly carried a message to Saddam from the Soviet leader. Its contents were not disclosed. -In Washington, the State Department said 300 Americans and foreign-born family members have signed up for an evacuation flight to leave Kuwait on Wednesday. U.S. officials say that 900 Americans remain trapped in Kuwait and Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Airlines Sign Deal For Direct Paris-Phnom Penh Flights
DOC.TEXT: The French charter company Air Liberte has signed a pact with Cambodia's national Air Kampuchea to provide the first direct flights between the West and Cambodia in more than a decade. Both airlines announced plans Friday to provide weekly service for passengers and freight between Paris and the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh. The flights from Orly airport to Phnom Penh will be scheduled for Wednesdays, with a base round-trip ticket costing 7,950 francs ($1,520.) It was not announced when the service would start. Phnom Penh has been cut off from Western air service since Vietnam invaded Cambodia in 1978, driving the murderous Khmer Rouge from power and installing a Vietnam-backed government. Westerners wishing to visit Cambodia have had to make a connection through Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Five Die As Boat Capsizes on Swollen River
DOC.TEXT: A boat capsized in a flood-swollen river, drowning four women and a child who were trying to flee their inundated village, news reports said Saturday. The accident Friday on the Padma River, 25 miles north of Dhaka, raised to 20 the number of people who have drowned since floods hit northern Bangladesh last week. At least 1 million people have had to leave their homes because of flooding that has washed away dozens of villages in six of the country's 64 districts, authorities said. Floods earlier in the monsoon season killed at least 70 people. The New Nation, a Dhaka-based daily, said the accident victims were attempting to reach safer areas from their inundated village. Floods are an annual occurrence in Bangladesh during the summer monsoon. During the 1988 monsoon, about 1,400 people were killed in flooding and about four-fifths of the low-lying nation was inundated.

DOC.HEAD: German Rightist Banned From Entering Britain
DOC.TEXT: The British government has banned a German described as a neo-Nazi from entering the country on the grounds his presence would not be conducive to the public good. Home Secretary David Waddington said in a statement Friday that Manfred Roeder, 61, would be refused entry. Roeder was due to address the annual rally of the far-right, anti-immigrant British National Party in London on Oct. 13. The British domestic news agency Press Association described Roeder as a convicted right-wing terrorist and former member of the Hitler Youth organization in Nazi Germany. It said he heads the extreme nationalist organization German Citizens' Initiative. It said he was released from prison in Germany earlier this year after serving eight years of a 13-year sentence for his part in firebomb attacks in which two Vietnamese immigrants died. The decision to ban Roeder follows a letter to Waddington by opposition Labor Party legislator Greville Janner, a former president of the Board of Deputies of British Jews, urging him to make the exclusion order.

DOC.HEAD: Relative Of Mandela Killed in Attack
DOC.TEXT: A grenade and shotgun attack Saturday killed a baby girl related to Nelson Mandela, and his African National Congress called the incident a ``curious coincidence.'' Police said unknown assailants hurled a grenade and fired shots before dawn at the home of Monde Mandela in the black township of Soweto. The attack killed Gloria Mandela, 1, and injured her parents, Monde, 43, and Susan, 29, police said. There were no immediate claims of responsibility for the attack. Police said they did not know if the attack was deliberate or a random incident linked to the chronic violence in Soweto and other townships. ANC officials said Nelson Mandela is close to the Monde Mandela family, who are distant cousins. They said Nelson Mandela's father was the brother of Monde Mandela's grandfather. The blast and ensuing fire badly damaged half the house. One room was destroyed, with the roof collapsed and charred debris strewn throughout. The body of a badly burned dog lay inside. Monde Mandela, who runs a small grocery store, and his wife were hospitalized with serious burns, police said. Nelson Mandela has led the ANC since his February release from 27 years in prison for trying to overthrow the white-led government. His supporters have been fighting Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement for supremacy among South Africa's black opposition groups. The warfare has killed 5,000 blacks in eastern Natal Province in five years. It spread in August to black townships around Johannesburg, where some 800 people have died. The government and ANC have held peace talks since May on ending the apartheid system of racial segregation and setting up negotiations on sharing power with the black majority. Mandela has repeatedly accused security forces of instigating the black-on-black violence to try to destabilize the country and derail peace talks. Police have denied the charges. Mandela, the ANC deputy president attended political meetings Saturday in Durban and issued no immediate comment on the attack, ANC officials said. An ANC statement said the assailants hurled a grenade and fired shotguns in the attack. It said the organization noted ``the curious coincidence of an attack on a man bearing the Mandela name at this time.'' Since his release from prison, Mandela has been closely guarded by ANC operatives. There have been reports of threats against his life. Right-wing extremists who support strict apartheid have opposed the ANC-government talks and possible power-sharing with blacks. Some right-wing groups have threatened armed struggle against a black government and claimed responsibility for bombings and other violence in recent months.

DOC.HEAD: Five Years After Achille Lauro, New Threats from Abbas
DOC.TEXT: Five years ago, Italy had its hands on Mohammed Abbas but let him go. Now the man convicted of masterminding the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro is back in the headlines and threatening new attacks on Western interests. The Baghdad-based Palestinian guerrilla leader, also known as Abul Abbas, has warned he will attack U.S. aircraft if Iraqi planes are hit during attempts to enforce the U.N. air embargo against Iraq. The hint of possible bombings or hijackings have raised the specter of a new wave of terrorism in the Mediterranean area, which was bloodied by terrorist atrocities in the mid-1980s. One of the most daring assaults of that time was the hijacking of the Achille Lauro as it steamed off the coast of Egypt on Oct. 7, 1985, with 511 passengers aboard on a cruise that began in Genoa. A wheelchair-bound American passenger, Leon Klinghoffer, was killed by the hijackers, who dumped his body overboard. American attempts to bring Abbas to justice led to severe strains in U.S.-Italian relations. The ship was hijacked by four young men belonging to an extremist PLO splinter group headed by Abbas, called the Palestine Liberation Front. They demanded that Israel release 50 imprisoned Palestinians. The hijacking ended Oct. 9 after Egypt negotiated with the hijackers. Abbas, who was involved in negotiating the surrender, and the four hijackers were flown out of Egypt on an Egyptian jet that was intercepted by American fighters and forced to land in Sicily. Tensions arose as soon as the plane landed. Armed U.S. and Italian soldiers faced off, each side demanding custody of the hijackers. The situation was only resolved after feverish telephone calls between Premier Bettino Craxi and President Reagan. The Italians took custody of the four and promised to try them, but refused to detain Abbas, saying the evidence compiled by Washington was insufficient and that he held an Iraqi diplomatic passport. Within two days, he was slipped out of the country. In an elaborate ruse, Abbas was kept aboard the Egyptian plane and flown from one Rome airport to another to board a Yugoslav airlines commercial flight to Belgrade. Craxi's office later said the mode of departure was arranged at the request of Egypt to prevent another interception by the Americans. But two weeks later, Italian magistrates filed charges against Abbas and issued an arrest warrant. In June 1986 he was tried in abstentia, convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment for masterminding the hijacking. The sentence was upheld on appeal. The Italians still have warrants outstanding for Abbas' arrest, but in January 1988 the U.S. Justice Department withdrew its warrant to the dismay of the Klinghoffer family. His dauhters said Abbas should be held accountable in U.S. courts. The Justice Department said it acted after a review of the case and Abbas' conviction and sentence by an Italian court. At the trial in Genoa, prosecutors charged that the hijackers shot Klinghoffer in the head and chest after Syria refused a request to help arrange negotiations for the Palestinians held by Israel. They said the hijackers planned to kill American and British passengers, one every five minutes, unless the prisoners were freed. But the prosecutors insisted they developed the case in the days following Abbas' departure. The government vigorously denied it had been soft on terrorism or had struck some deal with the PLO. In recent interviews at his heavily guarded office in Baghdad, Abbas was unrepentant about the killing of Klinghoffer. ``Can you name one Palestinian killed by the Israelis?'' he demanded of a Newsweek correspondent when questioned about the death of the 69-year-old American. He repeated his contention that the hijackers' real intention was to launch a raid in Ashdod, the Israeli port that was the ship's next stop after Port Said, Egypt. Abbas' latest threats come amid other recent warnings from Palestinian groups threatening retaliation for any harm that comes to Iraq. In the days since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Italy, for one, has taken seriously the possibility of new terrorist attacks. Italian officials decline to give details but security has been increased on roads leading to the main Rome airport and extra guards have been posted outside government buildings, U.S. installations, embassies and other possible targets.

DOC.HEAD: Frenchmen Climb Mount Everest
DOC.TEXT: A Frenchman who already holds the record for the fastest ascent of Mount Everest has climbed the world's tallest mountain again with two compatriots, the Tourism Ministry said. A ministry statement said Marc Batard, a 39-year-old alpine guide, reached the top of the 29,028-foot mountain Friday through the traditional southeast ridge. The statement, citing a radio message from the base camp, said Batard was accompanied by Pascal Tour Naire, a 40-year-old photographer, and the team physician, Christin Janin, 32. Five hours before the three men reached the top, another Frenchman, Eric de Camp, 35, and two Nepalese Sherpa guides reached the peak. Batard had climbed the Everest in 1988 in 22 hours, the fastest ascent ever by a mountaineer. It was not known how long he took to reach the peak Friday.

DOC.HEAD: United Germany: Now Comes the Hard Part
DOC.TEXT: Goodbye East Germany. Hello headaches, huge expenses and probably higher taxes. First, that ``wall in the mind'' must be broken through as Germany perfects its union. Then there is the problem of how to play a greater international role without frightening the neighbors. Two recent announcements foreshadow what awaits now-dissolved East Germany economically: an enormous investment to modernize telecommunications, but no help for a camera company that employs thousands. Jobs will be created by the telecommunications project, but gradually, over seven years. Pentacon, the camera company in Dresden, will close, throwing nearly 4,000 people out of work. It is the biggest business failure yet in the collapsing economy of what was an independent nation until midnight Tuesday. The holiday for unification was Wednesday, a day for prayers in ecumenical church services and thoughtful speeches by national leaders, framed by the glorious music of Germany's great composers. On Thursday, it was back to business, to news of burgeoning unemployment and the slow, expensive process of dragging the formerly Communist region up to national standards. Psychological problems accompany the economic. More than 40 years of stark political division created two kinds of Germans. ``It will take a long time to have one state with one people who really understand each other,'' Mayor Walter Momper said on the eve of unification of his nation and of Berlin, his city. People in the East ``have less initiative than we have,'' he said. ``Everything was determined by the party, the bureaucracy and the government.'' He said another major problem was the legacy of the Stasi, the defunct East German secret police. Its 6 million files are sealed, their fate to be determined by Parliament after national elections in December. ``The poison is everywhere,'' Momper said of the Stasi. Markus Wolf, the retired East German spymaster, is reported to have fled to the Soviet Union. His successor, Werner Grossman, was arrested Wednesday in eastern Berlin. It may have been a holiday, but prosecutors hunting East German spies did not take the day off. Chancellor Helmut Kohl used the occasion to tell other countries a united Germany would strive for peace and never forget the harsh lessons of its Nazi past. Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced plans to visit Germany in November, making him the first important foreign guest after unification and illustrating the swift improvement of relations with the Soviet Union. A friendship treaty has been initialed and Germans generally credit Gorbachev with the collapse of East German communism. Germany has promised $9.5 billion to finance the withdrawal of the 370,000 Soviet troops in former East Germany by the end of 1994. Kohl has pledged that Germany will strive for European unity without seeking domination, sign a treaty with wary Poland guaranteeing its border, alter laws to permit German troops to serve on foreign peace-keeping missions, and aid poor nations. Most Germans foresee higher taxes, but the government has said nothing definite. Kohl speaks of ``sacrifices'' ahead, and estimates of the cost of rehabilitating eastern Germany's five states range up to 1.2 trillion marks - $775 billion - over five years. Deutsche Telekom, a telecommunications arm of the government-owned postal service, said Thursday it would invest $35 billion over seven years to modernize the East's obsolete communications network. Managers from East and West were assembled in a chandeliered hall of a Prussian palace on the Unter den Linden and given marching orders for the ``fused'' national telephone company. Several hundred phone workers from the East, worried about their jobs, demonstrated outside. Helmut Ricke, the Telekom board chairman, announced that most of the 40,000 eastern employees would be retained, but ``not all the old bosses will be bosses tomorrow.'' He said pay would be raised gradually to the level of western employees. Political tests and unequal pay await people in the East. ``We feel we will be second-class citizens,'' said Klaus Rieck of Potsdam, who like other East Germans lived under dictators for nearly 60 years, first Adolf Hitler and then the East German Communists. ``We were under pressure the whole time - no freedom, no freedom of speech or the press,'' he said. Now ``the joy is great, but the uncertainty is, too.'' Uncertainty and bad news about jobs are daily fare. Treuhandanstalt, the trustee agency trying to rescue formerly state eastern enterprises, confirmed Thursday that the Pentacon camera company would shut by year's end. It advised the management to make its closing plans with social needs in mind. Fifteen regional managers have been chosen to decentralize the agency's efforts. One of them, Peter Langner, said he would apply a mixture of U.S., German and Japanese managerial methods to help restructure about half of 600 to 1,000 enterprises in Leipzig. Langner, a physicist, said he helped found Nicolet Instrument, a successful high-tech company in Madison, Wis., in 1968, and worked as a director of the company in Europe until 1981. Recently, he has been a management consultant, concentrating on East Germany's infant businesses, and believes the greatest difficulty is an unwillingness to take responsibility. ``For 40 years, you have a country which was never trained to make its own decisions,'' he said. ``Everything was told to them.'' The trustee agency needs to act more quickly, he said, because ``decisions are more important than right or wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: EC Monetary Officials Approve Britain's Decision on Pound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with EC approving Britain's decision on pound. Pickup 4th pvs, `Western European...' Minor editing to TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's monetary committee today approved a British plan to tie the pound into Europe's exchange rate mechanism. Britain's decision on Friday reversed long-standing economic policy and appeared to signal the government's willingness to play an active role in efforts to shape an economic and monetary union of the community nations. Hans Tietmeyer, a member of the board of the German central bank, said the monetary and finance officials agreed to the British proposal to peg the pound at 2.95 German marks in the exchange rate mechanism. The pound will be allowed to swing up or down by 6 percent from that central rate for an unspecified ``transitional period,'' he said. The move is effective Monday. The decision was adopted unanimously by the committee of the 12 nations of the European Community trading bloc, said Michael Somers, a represenative of Ireland's treasury. The exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System seeks to prevent wide fluctuations in exchange rates and hold down inflation and interest rates. With the pound's entry, the currencies of 10 of the community nations will be tied to the arrangement. Only the Portuguese escudo and the Greek drachma are apart. Western European countries intend to create a vast common market without national barriers by 1993. They are also trying to form closer political ties. The announcement Friday by British Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major was coupled with word that Britain's base interest rate will drop by one percentage point to 14 percent on Monday. The pound is joining the European exchange rate mechanism at a high level, which the government hopes will ease Britain's 10.6 percent inflation rate. The country's switch from a free-floating currency to a linked one is designed to promote economic stability by limiting disruptive exchange rate movements. The pound and London's stock market rose sharply on the news because joining the mechanism would set a stable floor under the currency. Thatcher agreed in principle to link the pound to the other currencies at a community summit meeting in Madrid last year, but she said she would move only when Britain's inflation rate was lower to the European average of 5.5 percent. Britain decided to go ahead because Britain's double-digit inflation is expected to decline, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said. The twin moves of entry into the 11-year-old mechanism and the one-point interest rate cut are ``right for the times,'' the prime minister said Friday. Opposition Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock said it was correct to cut interest rates and join the mechanism but that the moves were ``action of cornered government.'' Britain previously linked the pound to other currencies from 1944 to 1971 under a system of fixed but adjustable exchange rates. It then participated in a rate movement-limiting European ``snake'' until 1973. The pound, which has risen sharply in recent months on speculation that it would soon join the exchange rate mechanism, soared to $1.9455 from $1.9185 before the announcement, and to 2.9933 marks from 2.9492 marks. London's Stock Exchange extended trading for an hour because of the announcement. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed Friday at 2,143.9, up 73.5 points, or 3.6 percent, from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Back in the Saddle Again, Stumping for GOP Candidates
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan is back on the GOP campaign trail, appearing at fund-raisers from California to Florida to raise millions of dollars for Republican candidates. The public relations fallout from the Iran-Contra scandal, a lucrative Japanese tour, and Nancy Reagan's controversial book has done nothing to dampen the demand for Reagan at luncheons, cocktail parties and dinners. A Reagan appearance commands ticket prices of more than $1,500, rivaling the dollar drawing power of events featuring Reagan's successor, President Bush. ``There is just a great deal of affection out there for this man,'' said Otto Bos, campaign director for California GOP gubernatorial candidate Pete Wilson. ``There's a recognition that you're looking at one of the great lions of the century.'' Wilson, locked in a tight race with Democrat Dianne Feinstein, has benefited from five Reagan appearances, the most for any candidate. Reagan plans to attend two more Wilson functions this month, and more appearances are being considered. But Wilson isn't the only candidate Reagan has been stumping for. Since February, Reagan has attended functions in Oregon, Illinois, Georgia, Florida, Kentucky, Alabama, and Nevada, and has appeared at Los Angeles-area events for candidates from Iowa and Idaho. This month, the former president is likely to make appearances for Republican candidates in Colorado, Indiana, Michigan and Texas, his office said. ``President Reagan is continuing a pattern that has been his for many, many years,'' said Reagan spokesman Mark Weinberg. ``He did not view the end of his presidency as retirement by any means.'' Reagan isn't commanding his $30,000 or more speaking fee at party events, but his partisan appearances sometimes come at cities where he also is delivering a moneymaking speech. On Thursday, for example, Reagan popped into a $1,000-a-person cocktail party fund-raiser for Nevada gubernatorial candidate Jim Gallaway. He also was delivering a speech to the Mobil Oil Dealers convention at the adjacent Las Vegas Convention Center. The California gubernatorial race, viewed with strong interest by national Republicans, has been the focus of much of Reagan's political attention. Reagan, a former California governor, has appeared at events in Los Angeles, Beverly Hills, San Diego, Fresno and San Francisco. The party wants to ensure it has a strong voice in reapportionment next year, when the governor and Democratic-controlled Legislature draw districts for the nation's largest congressional delegation. In addition to Reagan, the Wilson campaign has featured stump appearances by Bush, Vice President Quayle and First Lady Barbara Bush. The GOP strategy has been to lump Reagan's appearances for Wilson in the beginning of the campaign and in the final stretch. This was intended to give Wilson - who ran unopposed in the primary - an early fund-raising push, then cash in on the late increase in voter interest. ``Whether it's Ronald Reagan or Arnold Schwarzenegger, no matter who the surrogate is, taking them out to an event in the middle of July doesn't have the same kind of effect as later in the campaign,'' said California GOP spokesman Dan Schnur. Democrats can't really match the appearances by Reagan and other heavy hitters. ``I think Reagan's popularity rating is particularly high. I don't think they'd be doing it if it wasn't,'' said Feinstein spokesman Richard Martin. ``Democrats don't have the big guns right now that the Republicans do. That definitely makes a difference.''

DOC.HEAD: Easy Times For Many Incumbents
DOC.TEXT: Despite all the talk about an anti-incumbent mood building among voters this election year, nearly 80 House members and four senators are coasting to November with no major party opposition. And those figures don't tell the full story of the diminishing level of competition for seats in Congress. Half the 35 senators up for re-election are expected to overwhelm little-known and underfinanced opponents. Of the 326 House members who have opponents, 217 were described by Common Cause as ``financially unopposed.'' The self-styled citizen's lobby said challengers to those 217 incumbents had raised less than $25,000 each in campaign resources. The Associated Press tally of House races found 61 incumbents with no opponents and 18 with only third-party opposition. Sens. Thad Cochran, R-Miss., David Pryor, D-Ark., and Sam Nunn, D-Ga., have no opposition. The only opponent on the ballot to Sen. John Warner, R-Va., is a follower of political extremist Lyndon LaRouche. Several explanations, starting with the escalating cost of campaigns, are offered for the decline in competition. ``We didn't have the money in the state of Georgia to finance a campaign against Sam Nunn,'' said Carl Gillis, Republican National Committeeman from Georgia. He estimated that a credible campaign against the senator, who got 80 percent of the vote in 1984 and 83 percent in 1978, would cost between $3 million and $4 million and still would be a long shot effort. In Virginia, Democratic Gov. L. Douglas Wilder discouraged his party from challenging Warner on the theory that it would be a waste of resources. ``Given the cost of mounting a campaign, if you don't have a pretty good chance of winning, why do it,'' said political scientist Gary Jacobson, an authority on congressional elections. ``You see the (re-election) record of incumbents, you see them use their resources so effectively, and you hate to make a fool of yourself running and getting absolutely wiped out,'' said Tom Mann, a political scientist who heads the Congress project at Brookings Institution. Mann suggested that the decline in competition did not signify a growth in the strength of political parties. ``We have moved from safe party seats to safe incumbent seats,'' said Mann. Two of the senators and several House members without major party opposition are southern Republicans, a remarkable shift from the days when the Democrats were dominant in the one-party South. In addition to Cochran and Warner, Republican Sens. Phil Gramm of Texas and Strom Thurmond of South Carolina are expected to win re-election by huge margins over Democratic opponents. In Thurmond's case, the lack of an opponent is all the more remarkable given that he will turn 88 in December. The steady shift of South Carolina to Republicanism is demonstrated by the fact that Gov. Carroll Campbell also is favored to overwhelm his Democratic opponent. ``The Southern habit of not contesting seats, transferred to the Republicans,'' said Jacobson. The lack of competition for Senate seats this year is not expected to be repeated in 1992. ``This is a fairly entrenched group of senators up in '90,'' said Anita Dunn, spokeswoman for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. ``I do not expect that in 1992 you will have a similar number of relatively uncontested seats despite the fact that everybody (incumbents) will be raising plenty of money for those seats.'' Of all the non-competitive races, none has provided more strange twists than the GOP effort to challenge Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York. Cuomo is a potential challenger to President Bush in 1992 and Republicans would have liked nothing better than to give him a hard time in his bid for a third four-year term. But challenging Cuomo was a multimillion-dollar task that no major party figure was willing to undertake. Enter economist Pierre Rinfret, who had to admit he wasn't even certain he was a Republican. He got the nomination and then discovered it didn't come with enough money to run a credible campaign. Rinfret has since spent more time attacking Republican leaders than tilting with Cuomo. ``They want me to lose because I'm going to upset their apple cart,'' he said. ``We understand the guy's frustration,'' said state GOP chairman J. Patrick Barrett. ``But he's saying, `I need a million dollars' ... and nobody's got the million dollars.''

DOC.HEAD: Harvard, Amherst Picked Best of Big and Small
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, bgng U.S. News, 12th graf, New York, to CORRECT
DOC.TEXT: spelling of Juilliard; DELETES day in lede

A world-class faculty and ``the nation's choosiest admissions office'' made Harvard University the top large school in a poll, and Amherst College was selected the best small liberal arts college. U.S. News and World Report, in its annual survey, also selected Juilliard School, Babson College and Harvey Mudd College as the best specialty schools. Selected as top regional colleges and universities in its special report on ``America's Best Colleges'' released in Monday's editions of the magazine were Villanova University, Wake Forest University, Illinois Wesleyan University and Trinity University. The country's oldest institution of higher learning, Harvard was selected as the country's leading liberal arts university for the first time since the survey began in 1983, although it had ranked among the top five in the other years. The Cambridge, Mass., institution was chosen over 203 national universities because of its ``a world-class faculty,'' its cutting-edge research and its stringent admissions standards, the magazine said. For last fall's freshman class, Harvard accepted about 18 percent of 12,843 applicants, the magazine said. Following Harvard as top national universities were Stanford, Yale, Princeton, California Institute of Technology, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Duke, Dartmouth College, Cornell and Columbia. Amherst College also was a first-time winner among America's 141 national liberal arts schools. The magazine touted its ``commitment to academic flexibility and the intimacy of a small student body.'' Last year, Amherst accepted only 22 percent of the 4,504 students who applied for the freshman class. The Amherst, Mass. school edged out Swarthmore and arch-rival Williams College. Swarthmore was the winner the last two years. Bowdoin College ranked fourth, followed by Wellesley, Pomona, Wesleyan University, Middlebury, Smith and Davidson. U.S. News ranked the 1,374 four-year colleges and universities based on results of questionnaires from college presidents, deans and admissions directors and the institutions' records in five key areas, including reputation for academic excellence, financial resources and ability to retain undergraduate and graduate students. New York City's Juilliard School was ranked as the nation's foremost music conservatory and the No. 1 arts school in the U.S. News survey. The Rhode Island School of Design ranked second, followed by the North Carolina School of the Arts. Babson College ranked top among the 24 business colleges in the survey. Harvey Mudd College ranked first out of 18 engineering schools. Topping the regional liberal arts colleges category were Simon's Rock of Bard College in the north, Wofford College in the south, Wittenberg University in the midwest and Southwestern University in the west. Sixty percent of 4,131 college presidents, deans and admissions directors responded to the questionnaire and also listed the country's up-and-coming schools. Emory University topped the national universities category, Rhodes College of Tennessee led the national liberal arts colleges and, under regional colleges and universities, the University of Hartford, George Mason University, University of St. Thomas, Minn. and the University of Nevada at Las Vegas led. In a less flattering category, Brandeis University and Bennington College were listed as the most expensive national university and liberal arts college, respectively.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners Fleeing Rwandan Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Fighting raged Saturday in Rwanda's countryside between government troops and invading rebels, and foreigners fled the capital of the central African nation by the hundreds. No further fighting was reported in the Rwandan capital of Kigali, where French Foreign Legionnaires and Belgian paratroopers secured their embassies, parts of the city, the airport and its access highway. But fierce clashes were reported in the northern part of the country and 500 soldiers from neighboring Zaire arrived in Kigali to reinforce the 5,000-strong Rwandan army. The rebels, who call themselves the Rwandese Patriotic Front, invaded last Sunday from Rwanda's northern neighbor, Uganda, where they had been living in exile.They want to oust the government, which they accuse of corruption. Many are deserters from the Ugandan army and most are members of Rwanda's Tutsi ethnic minority, which was removed from power by the majority Hutu tribe in the late 1950s and early 1960s in fighting that left tens of thousands dead. Their number has never been reliably estimated. On Saturday, an Air France Boeing 747 carried 232 French and other European nationals to Paris and another Air France plane and a chartered Lufthansa jet were expected to pick up about 500 more later in the day. The Soviet news agency Tass said measures were being taken to ``ensure the safety and the evacuation of the families of Soviet personnel.'' It gave no further details and it was not known how many people were involved. The German embassy in Nairobi said the Lufthansa plane would bring mostly wives and children of German aid workers out of Kigali. In Brussels, the Belgian government said it was withdrawing its offer to place four C130 transport planes at the disposal of its allies in the Persian Gulf because of the fighting in Rwanda. Belgium already has sent 500 paratroopers to Rwanda to protect its 1,630 citizens living in the former Belgian protectorate. Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said in Brussels Friday that Belgian citizens who wanted to leave Rwanda could fly out on the same planes that brought in the 300 troopers. Although Kigali appeared calm, the British Broadcasting Corporation's African Service broadcast a message from the Foreign Office urging British citizens to stay indoors. A dusk-to-dawn curfew announced Tuesday was extended round the clock and a Belgian reporter in Kigali said some people confined to their homes were running short of food. rrance has 670 citizens in Rwanda, Germany 400 and the United States 250. Most are attached to embassies or engaged in foreign aid projects. The exodus of foreigners was touched off by fighting in and around the capital early Friday morning and fears that the conflict could degenerate into more serious inter-ethnic violence. Diplomatic sources in Kigali reported sporadic gunfire Saturday, but one said it appeared to be from nervous government soldiers. One Western diplomat said on condition of anonymity that Belgian paratroopers were patrolling the capital's streets and guarding its main hotel, the Meridien, where foreigners evacuated from the countryside were being housed. Both the Belgian and French governments said their troops were sent to Rwanda to protect their property and citizens and would not get involved in the fighting. But the French army press service said the legionnaires ``were obliged to ripost (fire defensively)'' at ``armed elements'' Friday morning. Rwanda's president, Juvenal Habyarimana, said in a nationwide radio broadcast Friday government forces were ``in full control,'' but acknowledged that ``although the worst is over, the fighting continues.'' The rebels are led by Maj. Gen. Fred Rwigyema, a seasoned Ugandan army officer of Rwandan descent. They accuse President Habyarimana of abuse of power and corruption and say they want to install a democratic government. The rebels also say they would like to end the refugee problem. There are more than 100,000 Rwandan refugees in Africa and the guerrillas give an estimate of 1 million worldwide. A main stumbling block to the refugees' repatriation has been lack of space. Rwanda is Africa's most densely populated nation, with an average of 566 people living per square mile.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Government Begins Shutting Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs afer pvs 9th graf bgng ``These were...'' to add Bush veto of new measure to keep government operating while negotiations resume; INSERTS 1 graf after pvs 10th graf bgng ``Each agency ...'' to add that shuttle lauch not affected by shutdown
DOC.TEXT: The federal government, its coffers dry, began shutting down non-essential services today, closing the Washington Monument and other favorite tourist spots but maintaining the military and air traffic safety. Congressional leaders, arrived for a mid-morning meeting with President Bush to discuss the budget crisis and found most of the White House dark. Visitors to the Washington Monument and national symbols in the nation's capital were turned away. Tourists were turned away from the Smithsonian's museums and art galleries and the Library of Congress scheduled an early afternoon closing. Guards at the White House gates directed baffled tourists to the open-air Vietnam Veterans Memorial, suggesting it was the only one of the dozens of government-run memorials and museums in the nation's capital not locked up. White House tours were suspended. Non-essential White House employes, ranging from press information officers to cooks, were told not to work along with weekend federal workers across the country. The shutdown came at 12:01 a.m. Saturday when the government lost its authority to spend money. These were the early casualties of a government shutdown that could become devastatingly disruptive by Tuesday - after the three-day Columbus Day weekend - if the budget impasse between Congress and the White House isn't broken. That deadlock deepened as Bush said today he would veto a second stop gap measure to extend the federal government's financial life while negotiations continued. ``No more business as usual,'' said Bush as he left the meeting with congressional leaders. ``Do not keep putting off the day of reckoning,'' he warned Congress. An earlier continuing resolution had kept the government running since last Sunday when congressional leaders and administration negotiators first reached a compromise. But shutdown activities began after they failed to convince enough members of Congress to go along with the compromise. Each agency decides what is an essential service. But, generally, staying on the job will be workers dealing with national security, health, emergency and other essential services. The military, air traffic controllers, border guards, medical institution personnel and prison guards also would be unaffected. NASA's much-delayed launch of the space shuttle Discovery also took place despite the budget dispute. Officials at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the mission was unaffected because the funds had already been set aside and If a budget agreement isn't reached by then, all but ``essential'' employees among the 2.4-million-member federal work force will be told to go home within a few hours after reporting for work. Budget director Richard Darman on Friday sent a memo to all agency heads telling them to be ready to send home workers scheduled to work today. Only essential employees, generally those needed to ``protect life and property,'' will be permitted to work during the shutdown, Darman said. An hour before the disruption, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters, ``At midnight tonight, our national parks and monuments will close, cleanup of hazardous waste sites will cease, Social Security offices will accept no new applications, border inspections will be delayed.'' The government has shut down for lack of spending authority three times before, in 1981, 1984 and 1986, although never for more than a day. The government's authority to spend money was to initially run out on Oct. 1, the start of the new fiscal year, but President Bush signed a stopgap five-day extension to give Congress a chance to begin working on a $500 billion, five-year deficit-reduction package he and congressional leaders crafted. But the House rejected the plan early Friday and Bush refused to go along with another short-term government spending bill. The shutdown was hitting home at the White House, where aides said daily public tours would be suspended. Deputy press secretary Stephen Hart said a scheduled Monday reception in the East Room for incoming Supreme Court justice David H. Souter, would also be canceled. And Hart said he and other presidential spokesmen would be sent home. Manny Strumpf, National Park Service spokesman in New York City, said the staffs at both Liberty Island and Ellis Island have been told to report to work. But administration officials in Washington said that they likely will be sent home in the absence of a budget deal. The Park Service is prepared to ``padlock everything that can be padlocked,'' said Interior Department spokesman Bob Walker. ``If a visitor wants to drive into Yellowstone or Shenandoah Park, there'll be no one there to keep them out - or charge them a toll to get in. But those people would be largely on their own,'' Walker said. ``If their car broke down, there would be no friendly ranger to help them.'' A Federal Aviation Administration spokesman, Bob Buckhorn, said that ``if we have a shutdown, essential services remain in place,'' including air traffic control. However, if the deadlock persists, there would be a reduction in the number of controllers allowed to work. At the Agriculture Department, employees who normally work on weekends - primarily Forest Service workers - were told to be prepared to go home today. Kelly Shipp, a department spokeswoman, said that only a handful of the 100,000 USDA employees nationwide would be considered essential and expected to report to work during a shutdown. State and county offices of major USDA agencies, such as the Farmers Home Administration and the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, would close. Federal meat and poultry inspection, however, would continue during a general shutdown, Shipp said. The Defense Department has more than 3 million employees, including 2.1 million uniformed personnel. But it appeared unlikely that any curtailment of Pentagon operations would affect the deployment of more than 170,000 servicemen and women in the Persian Gulf. At the State Department, officials said all employees are expected to show up Tuesday but that non-essential workers would be sent home. The Postal Service is not affected because it is nt dependent on government appropriations. And there was no immediate impact on Amtrak, although the passenger railroad receives a large government subsidy and its operations would be hard hit if the budget impasse is long lasting. Joan Baran, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Customs Service in New York said customs agents are considered essential and would work this weekend. ``Everything will be business as usual,'' she said. If the president fails to sign a continuing resolution by Tuesday, then non-essential employees, mostly clerical workers, could be sent home, Baran said. ``Nobody likes to be told they're non-essential,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait's Exiled Rulers Call Meeting On ``New Type of Kuwait''
With AM-Gulf-US Buildup, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's exiled rulers have invited 450 prominent citizens of their occupied land to discuss a new type of Kuwait for when Iraq eventually retreats, the emirate's Crown Prince Sheik Saad said Saturday. In the meantime, he said, Kuwait refuses to consider any negotiated compromise that does not involve Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from all Kuwaiti territory seized on Aug. 2. Saad said Kuwaiti notables will meet in Jiddah Oct. 13 for three days to discuss the situation and make plans for the future. ``We have this question in our minds, how to rebuild a new Kuwait,'' he said in an interview. ``It will not be easy. We'll have to work very hard.'' Saad, whose full name is Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, is crown prince and prime minister of Kuwait. He is a cousin of the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. Although he was reluctant to elaborate, Saad made it clear the meeting would look at everything from defense arrangements to the basic rights of Kuwaiti citizens and foreign residents. ``After the invasion, we learned many things as Kuwaitis,'' he said. ``We'll have a new policy for security in the future, closer cooperation with our brothers in the gulf and with our friends.'' Asked about Kuwait's dependence on foreign workers, with few rights or little attachment to the wealthy state, he said, ``We will talk about all of these things.'' Invitations have been sent to exiled Kuwaitis, including present or past members of the elected legislature, senior diplomats, businessmen, judges, civil servants, journalists, students and others. Delegates will arrive from London, Paris and Middle Eastern capitals, Saad said. He declined to speak about the Kuwaiti resistance movement or the situation of royal family members still in the occupied emirate. But Kuwaiti sources said later the government-in-exile had tacitly agreed not to press ahead with armed resistance against the Iraqis to avoid massive reprisals. Saad described continuing human rights abuses and massive destruction by Iraqis in Kuwait. He said many Kuwaiti men have been taken to Iraq. Some were killed, and women and children have been tortured, he said. ``The damage is very much, you can't believe it,'' he said. ``I feel very sad.'' Saad was asked about suggestions that Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein might be prepared to withdraw from most of Kuwait while holding onto an oil-rich strip along the border, and the islands of Bubiyan and Warbah, which control Iraq's outlets to the gulf. ``We don't accept any sort of formula or suggestion less than the U.N. Security Council resolutions,'' which call for unconditional Iraqi withdrawal and restoration of the royal al-Sabah family, he said. Asked if Kuwait would maintain that position if the crisis dragged on for months or years, he said: ``Yes, we would stick to it.'' Aides to the crown prince said the exiled government not only has access to considerable financial hldings abroad, but also expects to collect reparations from Iraq's seized assets abroad. Iraq invaded Kuwait only five hours after Saad returned from talks with senior Baghdad officials in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia. He had gone there to discuss Saddam's claims over border areas and allegations that Kuwait had stolen oil worth $2.4 billion from oilfields along Iraq's southern frontier. Asked if he thought at the time Iraq would invade, he said: ``No, never.'' Kuwait's displaced rulers are ensconced at the al-Hada Sheraton, perched dramatically on a mountaintop at Taif, the Saudi royal family's summer retreat east of Jiddah. Princes, Cabinet ministers and officials while away their days in the seven-story hotel, contemplating lush gardens, sipping coffee and fruit juice and gathering at meal times for sumptuous spreads. Asked if he planned to move from the Sheraton, Saad said: ``Yes. I will move to Kuwait.''
