WASHN: domestic programs.
DOC.TEXT: Bush said he still strongly supports the $500 billion, five-year deficit cutting package that the House rejected in a post-midnight vote Thursday night. He spoke disparagingly of members of Congress who were opposed to individual items in the plan, mentioning unnamed committee chairmen whom he said complained ``my little empire's being invaded.'' The Democratic-controlled House was scheduled to convene at midafternoon and a vote was expected on overriding Bush's veto of the stopgap spending bill. But the veto seemed secure, as Senate GOP leader Bob Dole of Kansas said there were enough votes in the Senate to sustain it. The House vote on the stopgap measure had been 300-113, and the Senate added voice-vote approval. Bush said he thought a short-term solution could emerge by later in the day, and Dole said Bush was prepared to sign a spending bill that would avert the shutdown of government services as long as it incorporated an estimated $41 billion in across-the-board spending cuts. The full force of the shutdown in non-essential services was not expected to be felt until Tuesday, after the Columbus Day holiday for government workers.
DOC.HEAD: Despite pleas, 13th graf, a0498.
Sketches of 5 Discovery Astronauts
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Navy Capt. Dick Richards, Discovery's commander, is traveling into space for the second time in a little more than a year. The former test pilot made his first shuttle flight August 1989 on a secret Defense Department mission. Richards, 44, said before the flight that he believed a successful mission would help people forget about NASA's recent troubles, which include hydrogen leaks aboard the Atlantis and Columbia space shuttles. ``Right now, we don't look so good,'' he said. But he denied that NASA's recent misfortunes have put additional pressure on his crew or the launch team at Cape Canaveral, Fla., to get a space shuttle into orbit. ``They treat us like we're fragile commodities down there,'' he said, adding he believes the space agency has been quite conservative in handling mechanical problems in the post-Challenger era. Richards was born in Key West, Fla., but grew up in St. Louis where he graduated from Riverview Gardens High School. He earned a bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from the University of Missouri and a master's degree in aeronautical systems from the University of West Florida. After earning his bachelor's degree, he joined the Navy. He became a naval aviator and later went to the U.S. Navy test pilot school. Richards served as a project test pilot for development work on automatic carrier landing systems for F-4 and A-7 aircraft. He was on his way to an assignment with a fighter squadron when he learned he had been selected as an astronaut candidate in 1980. Richards is married. His flight experience includes more than 4,000 hours in 16 different kinds of airplanes.

Marine Lt. Col. Robert Cabana is making his first trip into space as the pilot aboard Discovery. The 41-year-old astronaut said before the launch that he was looking forward to his first trip into space, calling it ``the culmination of a lot of years of work on my part.'' Cabana is quick to defend NASA, attributing the recent rash of problems to mere coincidence, not carelessness. ``I think NASA is going to come through this and do just fine. ... I haven't seen any complacency at all,'' Cabana said. ``There's no push to do anything unsafely.'' Cabana was born in Minneapolis where he graduated from Washburn High School. He earned a bachelor's degree in mathematics from the Naval Academy. He also graduated from the Navy test pilot school and later served as a test pilot for flight systems and ordnance separation testing on aircraft. NASA selected him as an astronaut in 1986. He and his wife have three children. When the Discovery mission ends, Cabana said he plans to get back in line and wait for another flight assignment. He hopes to command his own shuttle mission. ``I want to stay here and fly shuttles as long as they let me,'' he said.

Navy Capt. Bill Shepherd, a veteran of a previous shuttle mission, is the flight engineer aboard Discovery. Shepherd, 41, first flew into space aboard Atlantis on a secret Defense Department mission in December 1988. He was a mission specialist on that flight. On this mission, Shepherd is taking on the additional role of flight engineer, who assists the commander and pilot during takeoff and landing. Shepherd was born in Oak Ridge, Tenn. He graduated from Arcadia High School in Scottsdale, Ariz., and earned a bachelor's degree in aerospace engineering from the Naval Academy. He also attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he earned a master's degree in mechanical engineering. After graduating from the Naval Academy, he served with an underwater demolition team and two SEAL teams. Shepherd, who's single, was selected as an astronaut in 1984.

Discovery mission specialist Bruce E. Melnick is the first astronaut selected from the U.S. Coast Guard. Melnick, a Coast Guard commander, is one of two Discovery astronauts designated to perform a spacewalk during the mission should an emergency arise. Melnick said he first wanted to be an astronaut as a youth when he watched Alan Shepherd become the first American to fly in space. ``But I didn't think it was a realistic goal,'' Melnick said. Melnick was born in New York City, but he grew up in Clearwater, Fla., where he graduated from Clearwater High School. He worked on fishing boats in Florida and became interested in the Coast Guard planes he saw flying in the area. Being a Coast Guard pilot, he said, seemed a more realistic goal - ``so that's the direction I took.'' After earning a bachelor's degree in engineering from the Coast Guard Academy, he was assigned as a deck watch officer aboard a cutter. Sixteen months later, he went to Navy flight training. He earned his wings in 1974 and a master's degree in aeronautical systems from the University of West Florida a year later. He worked as a Coast Guard rescue pilot and an operations officer before being selected as an astronaut. Melnick is married and has two children.

Air Force Maj. Tom Akers, who is making his first trip into space, was assigned to deploy the plutonium-powered Ulysses sun probe during the mission. He also is one of the crew members trained to do a spacewalk if necessary. Akers was born in St. Louis but considers Eminence, Mo., his hometown. He was the 1969 high school valedictorian from Eminence High School. He earned a bachelor's and master's degree in applied mathematics from the University of Missouri-Rolla. Akers worked as a National Park Ranger at Alley Springs, Mo., during the summers from 1972 through 1975. He also spent four years as a high school principal in Eminence. He joined the Air Force in 1979 and attended the Air Force Test Pilot School three years later. Akers, married and with two children, was serving as the executive officer to the armament division's deputy commander for research, development and acquisition when selected as an astronaut in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: No Sign of Nessie in First Day of Monster Hunt
DOC.TEXT: Pouring rain and a thick mist Saturday failed to dampen the enthusiasm of hunters hoping to win a half-million-dollar reward in the first major search for the Loch Ness monster in three years. But there was no immediate sign of the legendary beast. National oddsmakers at the William Hill Organization Ltd. have put up the cash - 250,000 pounds, or $477,500 - for the first person or team to discover ``conclusive evidence'' of the creature's existence. Based at the village of Drumnadrochit near the northern shore of the loch - or lake - in the Scottish Highlands, four groups are taking art in the two-day search. They range from serious contestants to publicity seekers. William Hill has offered an additional $2,865 prize for the best search method. Daniel Isted, the 25-year-old London-based editor of a corporate in-house magazine, said he was using what he called ``crystal divination.'' He said a tourmaline crystal, suspended from a yacht over the inky waters, would swing to indicate Nessie's direction. Former rock singer Screaming Lord Sutch, head of a political group called the Monster Raving Loony Party, said his secret weapon was a whistle that produces the mating call of monsters. Tongue in cheek, he announced he would use haggis - a Scottish delicacy consisting of chopped entrails and oatmeal cooked in the lining of a sheep's stomach - as bait to lure the creature to the surface. The Raving Loony Party, created to poke fun at politicians, runs candidates in most elections. Andy Gray, 38-year-old managing director of a Scottish company that supplies underwater sonar equipment for the North Sea oil industry, is taking a more scientific approach with a sophisticated underwater radar. ``Typically this system can work 3,280 feet beneath the sea. If Nessie comes within our search scan we will find it.'' Loch Ness is 754 feet deep, 23 miles long and a mile wide. Iain Bishop, deputy keeper of the zoology department of the Natural History Museum in London, will examine any evidence found on behalf of the oddsmakers. Standing in the pouring rain and looking out at the mist-covered lake, he acknowledged some skepticism. ``I don't expect to be overwhelmed by it (evidence),'' Bishop said. Locals, who have seen it all before, picked their way through the army of news people and television crews from the United States, Japan, France, Britain and elsewhere that have invaded the village. The legend of the Loch Ness Monster dates from A.D. 565 when St. Columba castigated the creature for attacking a follower. In modern times there have been more than 4,000 reported sightings, including the October 1987 sighting that spawned the last major hunt. That search, Operation Deepscan, used sonars and reported detecting what was called a large ``fish-like arch'' at a depth of 450 feet on the southern end of the lake. Deepscan spokesman Guy Pearse said then the object registered as a clear, large blip on the sonar but when the same boat scanned the area again the object had disappeared. Skeptics have explained away the sightings as everything from waves, logs and rotting vegetation to otters, swimming deer and overindulgence in Scottish whisky. A study by a Scottish company, Mackay Consultants, printed in The Times of London in May, said the Loch Ness Monster was worth $47 million a year in tourist revenue and responsible for 2,500 tourist industry jobs. It said half a million visitors a year from all over the world come to Loch Ness in hopes of seeing the fabled creature.

DOC.HEAD: `Buckwheat' Who Appeared on TV Was Fraud, Say Actor, Biographer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Richard W....', to CORRECT date of book to 1976 sted 1986.
DOC.TEXT: A man who appeared on ABC's ``20-20'' claiming he played Buckwheat in the classic ``Our Gang'' comedies was an impostor, the actor who played Spanky said. The child actor who portrayed Buckwheat died nearly a decade ago at age 49, George ``Spanky'' McFarland said. A ``20-20'' news magazine segment narrarated by Hugh Downs reported Friday that an elderly man who portrayed Buckwheat in the Hal Roach film comedies was found working as a grocery bagger in Tempe, Ariz. The man, who identified himself as Bill English, said he had changed his name from Bill Thomas. The real Buckwheat, whose name was William ``Billy'' Thomas, died nearly 10 years ago, McFarland said. ``I don't have the slightest idea who he was, but he wasn't Buckwheat,'' said McFarland, 62, who watched the ``20-20'' program. McFarland said from his Fort Worth home that he last saw the real Buckwheat at an ``Our Gang'' reunion in Los Angeles in 1980, shortly before Thomas died of a heart attack. Richard W. Bann, who co-wrote a 1976 book on the ``Our Gang'' stars, also said the real Buckwheat is dead. ``Buckwheat ain't giving no more interviews,'' said Bann, who watched the show in Los Angeles. ``20-20'' spokeswoman Maurie Perl said the show thought it had the right Buckwheat. ``We did our research, and to the best of our knowledge, we're not aware that he passed away,'' she said. The man claiming to be Buckwheat could not immediately be reached for comment. There was only one William English listed in the Tempe-area phone directories, and a person who answered that number said it wasn't the same one. According to the book ``Our Gang, the Life and Times of the Little Rascals,'' by Bann and film critic Leonard Maltin, William ``Billy'' Thomas appeared in 89 ``Our Gang'' films from 1934 until the series ended in 1944. The ``Our Gang'' series, which included 221 short films and one of feature length, began in 1922 with the billing: ``Hal Roach presents his Rascals in their latest Our Gang comedy titled ...'' The term ``Little'' was added to ``Rascals'' when the films were broadcast on television beginning in 1955. A number of well-known actors starred in the shows over the years, including Robert Blake and Jackie Cooper.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Examine Documents For Evidence Against Stasi Chief
With AM-Germany-What Next, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Investigators have begun examining documents in Berlin that could be used as evidence against Erich Mielke, the jailed chief of East Germany's Stasi secret police, officials said Saturday. Three days after the fanfare of unification, the Stasi legacy resurfaced as a serious and possibly troubling issue for the new German nation. Earlier Saturday, a newspaper reported that lawmakers from former West Germany want to bar rrom a united Parliament any newcomers from East Germany who had Stasi links. In Berlin, protesters outside the former Stasi headquarters were surprised late Friday when strangers showed up and said they were from the Bundeskriminalamt, a sort of German FBI. The protesters have been demanding that only citizens of former East Germany have access to the highly sensitive files, and immediately denounced the investigators' actions. Rolf Hannich, spokesman for the Federal Prosecutor's Office in Karlsruhe, confirmed that investigators were at the complex to look for evidence. But he insisted the action was not violating an agreement strictly limiting access to 6 million Stasi files and keeping them under East German control. He said investigators were examining documents that could be used against Mielke and other former secret police officials. Those documents had been made available by East German officials before unification and the investigators wanted to have another look at them, said Hannich. Earlier, the ADN news agency said federal law officials plan to comb through the former Stasi secret police headquarters in search of evidence. Mielke is suspected of harboring Palestinian and leftist German terrorists and faces a host of other accusations as well. Federal law officials aren't the only ones interested in what's inside the Stasi files. The newspaper Bild am Sonntag said western lawmakers want to have a look at the files after Dec. 2 elections to make sure parliamentary newcomers from the east aren't tainted by a Stasi past. It quoted Juergen Ruettgers, a top parliamentarian from Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition, as saying: ``Without a doubt we will want to know after parliamentary elections whether new members were Stasi workers.'' ``The Bundestag (Parliament) must not be occupied by former spies,'' Wilfried Penner, a top Social Democrat, was quoted as saying. Western lawmakers want to establish a committee that would investigate the pasts of new parliamentarians from the east, the newspaper said in a telex sent to other news organizations in advance of Sunday's publication. Penner said such a committee should be permitted to examine the Stasi files, which are potentially explosive because of the damage they could do to political careers and to private lives if their contents were made public. During one of the last sessions of the Volkskammer, East Germany's parliament, a number of members confessed they once had Stasi links. The Stasi secret police snooped on all facets of East German life in order to maintain the Communist rulers' iron grip on the now-dissolved nation.

DOC.HEAD: Five Americans Die In Plane Crash in Northeastern Brazil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th pvs, `The victims...' to DELETE extraneous material. Pickup 10th pvs, `Wagner said...'
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine plane carrying five Americans nose-dived into a farm on Brazil's northeastern coast, killing all aboard, officials said Saturday. Among the Americans killed was a Navy officer, officials said. The privately owned Cessna plane crashed Friday afternoon in the rural town of Itamaraju in Bahia state, 580 miles northeast of Rio, police Inspector Ana Maria de Jesus Cesar said by telephone. Ms. Cesar said the plane took off from Rio de Janeiro shortly after noon Friday under clouy skies and drizzle for an 80-minute flight to the beach resort of Porto Seguro, 600 miles northeast of Rio. As the craft went into its descent, it wavered and abruptly nose-dived into a clearing of a ranch owned by the local mayor, she said. ``There was no explosion, but the craft hit with such impact that the nose of the plane was completely buried in the ground when we found it,'' Ms. Cesar said. All five aboard were killed on impact, she said. Though the precise cause of the accident was not known, Cesar said the plane's engine apparently ``suffered problems of a technical nature.'' The victims were identified as Navy Lt. Daniel T. Humphreys, David Norbert Michalak, Joseph Francis Bonacci, Timothy T. Pohlman and Mark L. Evans, said David Wagner, public affairs officer at the U.S. consulate in Rio. Wagner said Michalak was 28 years old but had no ages for the other victims. Their hometowns also were not yet available, he said. He said the victims were headed for a weekend holiday in Porto Seguro. Humphreys was in Rio on a Navy exchange program. Bonacci, the plane's owner, and Pohlman, who was flying the plane when it crashed, were Rio residents, Wagner said. Evans, formerly an employee of the Boeing Co., and Michalak, an employee of General Electric Co. in the United States, were in Rio on vacation, he said.

DOC.HEAD: 1,100 Riot For Fifth Night in Slum Area
LaserPhoto TOK6
DOC.TEXT: Young people set pools of gasoline ablaze in the street and hurled rocks at riot police in Japan's largest slum Saturday night in demonstrations touched off by charges of police corruption. Huge piles of burned bicycles, broken glass and hulks of burned-out cars littered the streets in the Nishinari district of Osaka, the country's No. 2 city. Police said 171 people, including 134 police, have been injured in the violence since it began Tuesday, when a police sergeant was reported to have received bribes from gangsters active in the neighborhood. Fifty-seven people have been arrested, they said. The scope of the violence is extremely unusual for Japan, where public issues rarely inflame passions to such a degree. About 2,500 riot police in thick padded uniforms and blue helmets formed a barricade with metal shields near the Nishinari police station to keep the crowd of about 1,100 from approaching. Four vehicles equipped with water cannons guarded the station's main entrance and regularly sprayed the crowd. Every few minutes, groups of young people dashed toward the riot police, yelling insults and pounding the troopers with stones. Some poured pools of gasoline over the street and lit it, but the blazes were quickly extinguished by the water cannons. Another group broke into a nearby hotel and attempted to set it on fire, but that blaze also was put out by the water cannons. After midnight, the crowd began thinning, police said. ``I think the crowd is getting tired,'' a police official said on condition of anonymity. ``But we will continue to keep 2,500 riot police here just in case.'' Earlier last week, after the arrest of a local policeman on suspicion of having taken $81,000 in bribes from gangsters, most people involved in the nightly violence were day laborers from the neighborhood. News reports said the arrested policeman had confessed he accepted the bribes in exchange for providing information about police operations against the gangsters, who control the allocation of some jobs to the day laborers and receive a percentage of their wages in return. Many in the crowd Saturday were hooligans and students from outside the neighborhood, police said. The rioting has not spread beyond the neighborhood, but has caused traffic tie-ups in parts of Osaka as police blocked off several major streets. The area, nicknamed the ``Airin'' district by locals, is Japan's largest slum and is notorious for gangs, transient laborers and shabby hotels. Local residents and human rights activists have complained about police anti-crime measures, including 24-hour surveillance cameras on street corners. Menial laborers in the area have previously demonstrated against low wages and other issues, but the level of last week's violence was unusual.

DOC.TEXT: Here is a transcript of President Bush's press conference Saturday with reporters in front of the White House. President Bush: Well, I just want to comment. I know the leaders have been speaking, and I have not yet signed, but within the next couple of minutes will veto the continuing resolution. We've had good cooperation from Democrat and Republican leaders, and the Congress has got to get on with the people's business, and that - I'd like them to do that business, get a budget resolution and get it done in the next 24 hours or 48 hours. But, as president, I cannot let the people's business be postponed over and over again. I've jotted down the numbers. There have been three dozen in the last decade, three dozen continuing resolutions - business as usual, and we can't have it. And the president can only do this one thing - send that message back and say this is not a time for business as usual. The deficit is too important to the American people. So I expressed my appreciation to the speaker, the majority leader in the Senate, the majority leader in the House, two Republican leaders, thanked them for coming together in a spirit of compromise to get an agreement that I strongly supported. Didn't have everything I wanted in there, but now I'm calling on those who did not vote for it on the Republican side and on the Democratic side to get up with the leadership and send down something that will take care of the people's business once and for all. And I am sorry that I have to do this, but I made very clear that I am not going to be a part of business as usual when we have one deficit after another piling up. And I've had enough of it, and I think the American people have had enough of it. Q: Mr. President, Mr. Mitchell came out here just a minute ago and said that this serves no useful purpose, the shutting, what useful purpose ...? A: That's where we have a disagreement with him. I think it serves, I think it disciplines the United States Congress, Democrats and Republicans. They're the ones that have to pass this budget, and they ought to get on with it. And the leaders, to their credit, tried. But a lot of members think they can get a free shot, right and left. And, that, what this message says is no more business as usual. So we did have a difference on that particular point. I think both the speaker and the majority leader did not want me to do this. But look, let me take you guys back awhile. In August, I wanted to keep the Congress in. That story was written. And I listened to the leadership, both Republicans and Democrats. So I said, ``No, we'll acquiesce.'' Because they said to keep the Congress here in August will be counterproductive. Everybody will be angry with you. That the way to get it done is with the discipline of the calendar running after the summer recess. And so I acquiesced. I compromised. I gave. I'm not going to do it any more. I'm very sorry if people are inconvenienced, but I am not going to be a part of business as usual by the United States Congress. Q: Mr. President, Senator Dole said that you had agreed to sign, to send up a new short-term spending bill that would include spending cuts, a sequester. Could you tell us something about that? A: Well, I'm going to stay out of exactly what we're going to do and let the leaders handle the details of this now. It's in the Congress and we will strong, I still strongly support the agreement that both Democrat leaders and Republicans leaders came down on. And I'll say this, I do think that there's a lot of agreement, goodwill still existing for that. It's not going to be passed exactly that way. It was defeated, but let's leave the details of negotiation on that to the Congress. They're starting back in right now. They're going to have to contend with this veto I sent up, and obviously I want to see that veto sustained.

DOC.TEXT: Q: You say no more business as usual, in one breath you say no more CRs (continuing resolutions), but in the next breath Dole says you'll sign a CR with a sequestration. A: Well, if the, well, if it has some discipline. What I'm saying is I want to see this system disciplined. If it has, if it, what Bob Dole said is correct, I'll sign one, if it puts some discipline on the system. And if it doesn't discipline the system, then I stay with my current position. No, excuse me, I'm glad you brought that up, because I would strongly support that. Q: The leadership made a strong point in saying that it's the average Americans who are going to be hurt, federal workers and so on, it's not congressmen. But, you know, average Americans who are going to be strongly hurt by this. A: The average American is smart. The average American knows what's going on, I think. And I think they know that the Congress has continued to kick this can down the road, and they think they ought to act. And I'm very sorry for people that are inconvenienced by this or hurt by this, but this is the only, only device one has for making something happen. And that is to get the Congress to act, to do its business. Q: Mr. President, you seem to be blaming Congress but in fact a lot of their constituents are the ones that urged them to vote against it. They say it's unfair, the burden is unfairly divided, that the poor and the middle class are paying too much. Is it possible that maybe this program that you propose with the leaders just was not acceptable to the American public? A: Well, certainly certain aspects of it might well not have been acceptable to the American public on both the right or the left. But when you're trying to do the country's business, I've discovered you have to compromise from time to time. And that's exactly what I did, took a few shots in the process, but it doesn't matter. What matters is let's move this process ahead now. But, yeah, you're right. Some people didn't like one aspect or another. We had Republicans jumping up on the side, of our side of the aisle and said, ``Well, I'll vote for it if you change this, or I don't like this part of it but if you change that.'' And similarly you've got people that you were quoting that were on the other side. So, but at times, one has to come together to do the country's business for the overall good. And these outrageous deficits cannot be permitted to go on, and on, and on, and on. And I'm worried about international markets, I'm worried about this country to be - the opinion that it can't take care of its fiscal business. And to their leaders' credit, Democratic and Republican. They tried very hard and they failed to get a majority on the Democratic side, and the Republican leaders, with the help from this president, all I could bring to bear on it, we failed. Because we had people who were looking at one narrow part of the package and not at the overall good. And I am hopeful now, that with the urgency this veto brings to bear on the situation, that reasonable people, men and women in the Congress, can come together. Q: Mr. President, what kind of progress is being made on a new budget resolution? And, sources on the Hill are saying that there is glowing support for raising the tax rates of the wealthy in exchange, perhaps, for the cuts on premiums for Medicare. But you've opposed that in the past. Are you willing to give on tax rates for the wealthy? A: I am, I don't know the answer to your question. They're just going back up now to try. I like the parameters of the other deal, wherein I compromised. We've got people - your question reflects the views of those on the more liberal or left side of the political spectrum who raise those questions. We have some on the right side of the political spectrum coming at the process from another way. Now I say let them go up and negotiate. This is the business of the Congress, and our people will stay in touch. I won't mislead them. If there's something that's so outrageous I can't accept it, I'll let them know at the beginning so they don't waste their time. But we're flexible. I've already compromised. And I'm not saying that I can't take a look at new proposals, but you've got to put together a majority in the Congress. And that's where the leaders are having great difficulties.

DOC.HEAD: Battle Over Censorship Reaches New Levels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: The trials are over, but the split decisions in two climactic obscenity cases makes it certain that the controversy over the bounds of artistic expression will continue. ``It doesn't start the war; it doesn't end the war. It's just another battle,'' Donald Wildmon, founder of the conservative American Family Association, said after a jury exonerated an art gallery and its director of obscenity charges. Cincinnati's Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, were found innocent Friday of the charges stemming from their display of photographer Robert Mapplethorpe's work. It was the nation's first obscenity trial for an art gallery and its director. On Wednesday, however, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., jury convicted record store owner Charles Freeman of obscenity for selling a sexually explicit record by the rap group 2 Live Crew. Freeman could face a year in jail. Standards have changed markedly since Elvis Presley was televised from the waist up to avoid showing TV viewers his wriggling hips, and Hollywood cringed over Clark Gable ending ``Gone With the Wind'' with, ``Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn.'' Such instances appear tame now, compared with 2 Live Crew's graphic raps on the album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' On such songs as ``Me So Horny,'' the Florida group describes exactly how they would mistreat women to satisfy their desires. Similarly, one photograph in the late Mapplethorpe's exhibit showed one man urinating in another man's mouth. Three photos showed penetration of man's anus with various objects and two show children with their genitals exposed. To some, that's trash. To others, it's art. ``Sophie's Choice'' author William Styron calls the obscenity battle ``uncalled-for. It's a violent exhibition of the kind of puritanism that is still the governing spirit in many ways in this country. ``I don't like anything that puts a damper on artistic expression.'' But Wildmon said the Americans' common sense is simply coming to the fore, spurred by an outbreak of permissiveness in the arts. ``Eight or 10 years ago, the average American was not confronted with this,'' Wildmon said. ``More Americans are being confronted with this and they don't like it. More than that, their children are being confronted with this and they don't like that.'' Inspired by the Mapplethorpe trial, the Brooklyn Museum in New York City has put together an exhibit showing several centuries of objectionable art. The point is to show that what's considered art or obscenity frequently changes over the years, said curator Charlotte Kotik. Among the artwork on display are Rodin's bronzes of lesbians embracing, 19th century paintings of nude children and an 18th century Hindu painting of a man urinating into another man's mouth. Like Wildmon, Kotik can see the nation's conservative drift over the last decade. The difference is, she disagrees with it, and worries that more art might fall victim. ``It starts with small things and can unfortunately turn into a big issue,'' she said. ``What we are trying to say is, `Wait a minute. Stop and think about what we are doing before it goes too far.' '' 2 Live Crew's legal troubles are continuing even as their music may be becoming pass. Leader Luther Campbell and two other band members are to go on trial this week in Miami on charges of performing obscene material at a nightclub. The group also canceled shows on its current tour because of lagging ticket sales. Meantime, along come the Geto Boys. Members of this Texas rap group brag they make 2 Live Crew sound like ``choir boys.'' They lace their sexually explicit raps with extreme violence and misogyny. Last month, giant Geffen Records announced it would no longer distribute the Geto Boys' record label, Def American. ``I'm an editor of a rap music magazine and I have trouble with the Geto Boys,'' said Jon Shecter, editor of The Source. ``I support everyone's right to say what they want, but the Geto Boys are in another league.'' Shecter said such bands as the Geto Boys and others who send him clippings of their arrests seem interested in obscenity for the sake of attention, not art. Florida lawyer Jack Thompson, who's crusaded against 2 Live Crew, warned the record industry in a pointed Billboard essay that if they don't see that acts clean up their lyrics, courts will do the job. ``Life imitates art and art imitates life,'' Thompson said. ``We need to enforce laws against the people who are calculatingly going after the almighty dollar at the expense of women and children.''

DOC.TEXT: A: One follow-up and then we'll come over here. Q: Following up on that, members of your own party dislike the deal so much, how could you and your advisers have misjudged the sentiments of members of your own party? A: Because it's easy when you don't have to be responsible for something. It's easy to get up and say, ``Hey, I've got an election in three weeks and I'm going to stay up against this particular package, Medicare, the tax on the home heating oil, or the fact there's not enough growth or not enough incentive.'' Any individual member can do that. And maybe it plays well at home. The president and the leadership in both houses have to be responsible for the overall good of the country, have to make something happen. I can't get it done just my way. I don't control both houses of Congress. I'd love to think that that luxury would come my way someday, but it hasn't. And therefore we've had to compromise. So I will keep trying in that spirit, that cooperative, positive spirit. But when it comes to the discipline that comes from saying, ``I'm sorry, no more business as usual,'' that's where I can stand up. I don't need a consultation to do that. And I get plenty of advice on one side of that question or the other, but I am absolutely convinced this is right. And even those who are inconvenienced by this are going to say, ``Thank God we get the American people's business of getting this deficit under control done.'' And that's my objective. And I think every parent out there who sees his kid's future being mortgaged by these outrageous deficits, sees a shaky economy that's being affected by these, prolonging these deliberations, will be grateful in the long run. In the meantime, you've got to take a little heat. Q: Mr. President, the budget resolution that failed is one that you worked hard for. Despite the fact that you gave a nationally televised speech and despite the fact that you're popularity is very high, you failed to sway even a majority of votes in your own Party. Does that concern you? And do you think this is a major setback for your presidency? A: No. I don't think that at all. But I do think, yes, it concerns me. I'd like everybody to do it exactly the way I want, but it doesn't work that way. And so now we have to use a little discipline - (unintelligible) - nice guy stuff and we'll try. This is a tough decision. It's not an easy decision I've made, but it is the right decision. So I'm disappointed they didn't do it my way, but I'm in this, I'm in here to do what is best for the country. And what is best for the country is to get this deficit under control, to get this economy moving again and to see people at jobs not out on some welfare line. And that's what's at stake here, the economic soundness of the United States. And we've got a lot of things going on in the world and a strong economy is absolutely, is vital to what I want to see achieved for this country. So you have to take some hits. I mean, you don't get it done exactly your, your own way. But I read these speculative stories. Tomorrow there's going to be another vote. Tomorrow somebody else will move the previous question or second the motion or some committee chairman will jump up and say, ``Hey, what about me? My little empire's being invaded here.'' And I'll say, ``Hey, the President's the guy that has to look at the overall picture.'' I can understand Congressmen doing that. But we came together on a deal. We worked for it. Everybody had a chance to posture that didn't like it. They had no responsibility. But I feel a certain responsibility to the American people to move something forward here. So I've compromised. Now, we're going to say, we're going to try it this way. No more business as usual. Do not just keep putting off the day of reckoning. And I don't want to be a part of that and that's why I've had to veto this resolution.

DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, you talked a lot about discipline today. Do you think the American people on average are willing to accept the discipline of a tough budget agreement? A: That's a very good question. And if you look at the vote in both, in the House of Representatives, you might say no. But I think in the final analysis, the answer will be yes because I think the, I think we sometimes underestimate the American, the intelligence of the American people. I can see where a congressman can jump up on a specific, a specific spending program that will help him in his district. Or I can see when somebody'll give you the broad tax speech or some, help him in his district. But in the final analysis, the -- what the American people look at is, ``Do we have an economy in which I can feed my family, where I can have an opportunity to work for a living and where I can put a little aside to educate my kids?'' And therein lies the problem, because that's what we're working for, is we're trying to get this federal deficit down. But I think you raise a good point, I think a lot of these congressmen can jump up without any responsibility for running the country, or even cooperating with their leaders, and make a point that's very happy for the home folks. But I think you underestimate, I think that view underestimates the overall intelligence of the American people, whether conservative, whether a guy's working on a factory line some place, whether he's an investor some place. So that's why I think this is very important that the Congress now finally come to grips with this. Excuse me, Ann. Q: Mr. President, it sounds like you're now saying hands off, it's up to the congressional leaders to do the negotiating. A: Well, they are, they've already started up the road there to go to Congress and start negotiating. But, no, we've made very clear that we're continuing to help. I don't want to mislead them. There are certain things I can accept, and certain things I can't. So I think it's very important that our able team, in whom I have total confidence, stay in touch with them. But - Q: But not sit at the negotiating table with them? A: Oh, I think they'll be there. I think it all depends on what the forum is. I think there is some feeling, Ann, on the part of members, both Democrat and Republicans - ``Hey, you know, you summiteers handled, handed us a deal.'' Well, what the heck? I mean, how do you expect to get, to get as far along toward an agreement as we did get? But what I want to do is facilitate it. And if they want to know where the White House is, fine. If they want the ideas that that largely led to an agreement, fine. And I think they will. But we're not going to force our way in. This is the business of the Congress. The American people know that. They know that the president doesn't pass the budget and doesn't vote on all this stuff. It's the Congress that does it. Q: Mr. President ... A: And so I'm not trying to assign blame, I'm simply saying, ``We're available.'' If we want to talk, or in the way, fine. But we're not. I think both leaders in there indicated they wanted to stay in very close touch with the White House. Q Is there any talk of a constitutional challenge to Civiletti on the Hill, that, that the Attorney General's opinion is not sufficient to run the government, and it violates Article I, Section 7 of the Constitution? A: Haven't heard anything about that, doesn't worry me. Q: Mr. President, are you going to cancel your campaign schedule next week if this impasse is not resolved? A: I don't know. I've got to cancel everything that has to do with government, I guess, but whether that -- maybe that's a good chance to get out there in the political process.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Family Buries Caroline's Husband
LaserPhotos MON1,3,4
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 2nd pvs, `The private...' to correct age of cathedral. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `The tiny...'
DOC.TEXT: The grief-stricken royal family laid Princess Caroline's husband, Stefano Casiraghi, to rest Saturday in a plot overlooking the stretch of blue Mediterranean where he was killed in a boat-racing accident. The private burial at the tiny Chapel of the Peace followed a public funeral at Monaco's nearby cathedral. Thousands of people, including tourists in bright beach outfits and citizens in black mourning garb, crowded around the 115-year-old cathedral during the tearful ceremony. The tiny, wealthy Riviera principality appeared sad but not stricken by the same shock that accompanied the death of Caroline's mother, Princess Grace, in a car accident in 1982. Gambling continued at the famed casinos without interruption. Small businesses closed during the funeral but quickly reopened for the afternoon. Casiraghi, 30, an Italian businessman, died instantly Wednesday when his boat flipped during the World Offshore Championships. The somersault slammed him headfirst into the water. The other driver, Patrice Innocenti, was injured. ``The brutality of his death adds to our pain,'' Archbishop of Monaco Joseph Sardou said at the service. ``The sea, so calm today, holds dangers that must constantly be confronted.'' Princess Caroline, 33, wept occasionally during the 55-minute service as sunlight streamed through stained-glass windows and a Bach dirge wafted from the organ. The princess wore dark sunglasses, a black-lace head-covering and black dress. The three children from her seven-year marriage to Casiraghi were not present. Referring to Caroline, Sardou said: ``It was through his union with you, Madame, that he found the greatest expression of his Christian faith.'' Caroline occasionally leaned on her father, Prince Rainier, for support. Prince Albert, heir to the realm, comforted younger sister Princess Stephanie when she briefly fled the cathedral weeping. Only 1,600 of the several thousand mourners who began lining up Saturday morning fit inside the cathedral. The rest remained outside under the warm October skies. The mourners included Danielle Mitterrand, wife of French president Francois Mitterrand, actor Alain Delon, exiled King Michael of Romania, and fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld. Thousands of floral bouquets covered the cathedral's steps. The brightly colored shorts and T-shirs worn by tourists contrasted with stark black worn by Monaco's citizens. ``Oh, dear Stefano,'' sobbed one elderly Italian woman. ``I was here for Grace's funeral and now I'm here to mourn young Stefano. There is a curse on the royal house.'' A white-uniformed, five-man honor guard wearing red-tasseled hats stood stiffly at attention during the ceremony. Squads of police kept watch on the mourners outside. As the service ended, a weeping Caroline walked out of the cathedral clinging to the arm of her white-haired father. The princess decided to bury her husband at the simple chapel over the objection of her in-laws, who wanted him interred in Italy, French and Italian newspapers reported. Other commoners who have married into the ruling Grimaldi family are buried at the site, including dancer John Gilpin, the late husband of Rainier's sister, Antoinette. Princess Grace - the former Hollywood star Grace Kelly - is the only commoner buried in the royal family tomb. Casiraghi married Caroline in a civil ceremony in 1983. In the following seven years he became a prominent business leader here, with major interests in real estate and development firms. The couple had three children: Andrea, 6; Charlotte, 4; and Pierre, 3. Caroline has vainly sought a Vatican annulment of her unhappy first marriage to French playboy Philippe Junot so that her children with Casiraghi would be recognized by the Roman Catholic Church. Casiraghi had been racing at world-class level since 1984 and won the world championships in 1989 at Atlantic City, New Jersey. He had told friends he planned to quit after this season. This year's championship was canceled. Fellow drivers laid a wreath at the spot where he died, as did a helicopter from Monacair, a company owned by Casiraghi. Some drivers said Casiraghi was going far too fast on the choppy waters Wednesday. His catamaran, called a ``floating coffin'' by local newspapers, lies about 2,000 feet under water.

DOC.HEAD: Buildup Essentially Completed; Pentagon Sources Play Down Offense Talk
