DOC.TEXT: The planned U.S. buildup on the Arabian peninsula is virtually complete, but American forces still lack the firepower and supplies necessary to launch a successful ground offensive against Iraqi troops in Kuwait, according to military officials. The officials, in Washington and Saudi Arabia, said all of the heavy armor being shipped to Saudi Arabia should arrive by week's end, closing out the biggest phase of the two-month deployment and bringing to nearly 200,000 the number of American troops in the region. As evidence of the progress, Navy sources said that for the first time since the buildup began, significant numbers of cargo ships are returning to the United States from the Persian Gulf without orders to quickly reload and head back. One of these sources, all of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity, said at least 11 ships were heading home without new orders to pick up Mideast-bound cargo. ``We're about to pass the buildup phase and move into the sustainment phase,'' the Navy official said. ``The heavy lifting is over.'' Discussion of U.S. military options in the region has included speculation that the American mission might shift from the defense of Saudi Arabia to some offensive action against Iraqi forces once the final U.S. armored units arrived to support heavy ground forces already deployed in the northern Saudi desert. But as ships carrying those tanks, armored vehicles and heavy artillery made their way to Saudi Arabia last week, military officials were playing down the prospects for any offensive action. Indeed, most of the officials said the U.S. forces, even with the final planned shipments of heavy armor, still would be well short of the manpower and weapons capabilities needed to mount a successful assault on the more than 400,000 Iraqi troops in heavily fortified defensive positions in Kuwait and southern Iraq. ``We're in there for the long haul,'' said a Pentagon source. ``We do not have enough firepower nor do we have a logistical tail in country to conduct an offensive campaign. ... Our plans don't ever foresee us reaching that point.'' Another Pentagon official, also speaking privately, said administration officials at the White House or Pentagon who were discussing possible offensive actions ``need to take a more sober perspective.'' ``We can guarantee the defense of Saudi Arabia, but going on offense - that's wishful thinking,'' this official said. ``The enemy is digging in and digging in and digging in. It would take a lot more than we're planning on sending to move them out.'' While some troops and equipment will be trickling into Saudi Arabia and other U.S. positions in the region for as long as the deployment lasts, Pentagon planners will consider the buildup essentially completed when the final armored units en route take up positions in the Saudi desert. These include roughly 13,500 troops from the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment, from Fort Bliss, Texas; two brigades of the 1st Cavalry Division from Fort Hood, Texas; and one brigade fro the 2nd Armored Division, also from Fort Hood. Their equipment includes hundreds of M-1 tanks and Bradley armored infantry carriers. As of Friday, all of the major equipment belonging to those units was in or close to Saudi Arabia, with the exception of a shipment of anti-aircraft guns scheduled to leave port in the United States within days, according to Pentagon sources. To date 28,074 reservists have been called to active duty, said Pentagon spokesman Bill Caldwell. And Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Friday that the call up of reservists would remain within levels initially anticipated. Some previously announced support units have been told they would likely be activated but have not yet been called, Williams said. The next challenge for military planners, provided no hostilities erupt, will be sustaining the force in the Mideast, some 7,000 miles from the United States. Dozens of support trucks and scores of pallets loaded with materiel and supplies are being prepared for shipment to the region, and some of the ships now returning without orders might be called upon in the near future to make another trip to Saudi Arabia. ``There's all kinds of stuff that doesn't have to be there in the first days and weeks that we will need to stay there for any length of time,'' one of the Pentagon source said. ``But there's not the same sense of urgency with these things.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: political process.
DOC.TEXT: Q: How long, how long can you hold out? How long can you let the government stay shut down before you decide the cost has been too great? A: Watch and learn. Q: How long do you think government can stay shut before ... A: It's not a question of how long I can take it, it's how long the Congress can take it. The Congress is where the action is. It's the Congress that has to pass this in the House and in the Senate. That's where the action is. They've postponed this tough decision, as I mentioned, how many, 30-some times, and we just can't have it. The American people are saying, ``I want something done about this.'' And that's where the focus will be. So I don't think it's a question of taking heat here. These guys marching out here about honking their horns, of taxes, they know I don't like taxes. You get some other guy marching out here with a little placard demonstrating, giving something about the government employees. I, we've been supporters of the government employees, but we cannot have business as usual. The American people, I don't know about inside the beltway, but outside they are fed up with business as usual and so am I. And I wish I had total control so we could do it exactly my way, but we don't, so I've compromised and now we're prepared to say I'm not going to accept a resolution that just postpones it. I've told you I've tried that approach, tried it in August, let everybody go home on vacation when I had some good, sound advice I probably should have taken: make the Congress stay in August. And I listened to the leaders. And I said - they said, ``Oh, please don't do that. It'll be counterproductive.'' Now, they're saying to me, ``Please don't veto this, it'll be'' - when do the American people have a say? They want to see this deficit under control. And I don't have many weapons here as president, but one is the veto. And when I do it, cast it on principle I hope it is supported. Q: Mr. President, when Dole sends up another CR, or if the Congress sends up a CR with sequestration, when could that happen? Could you give us some timeframe? A: I don't know. Q Could it happen in the next couple of days, sir? A: Oh, yeah. Yeah. Absolutely. It could happen this afternoon. Q: So it could happen this afternoon? A: Sure. When they get together. Q: And it came up to ... A: Now, I'm not, that ... Q: Sure. A: That perhaps is a little oversimplification, because they are telling me there's some difficult problems right and left, both sides. But, no, they're going right back to negotiating. And let's hope it does. That's the way to serve the people. Q: If it came up this afternoon, sir, would you sign it this afternoon? A: Depends what it is. Q: You have vetoed the ... A: I'll be around. Q: You have vetoed the CR. A: Yeah, Well, I haven't actually signed it, but I've got to rush right in there now and do that and send it up to the Hill. They know that they've ... (inaudible). (Cross talk.) A: Last question. Q: What's all this done to the prestige and influence of you and your office? A: I think it will demonstrate that there is some power in the presidency to get the, to compel the Congrss to do something, and I think that's good. Q: You are veto ... A: Oh yeah, it'll, it hasn't been vetoed yet. But I just, it's had, needed, need a typewriter in there to get it done. But it, by the time we finish this press conference that has gone longer than I thought, it'll probably all be typed up. Q: Might you trade the bubble for capital gains, now? Do you foresee that an answer? A: Our negotiators are, have a lot of, the negotiators in the Congress have a lot of flexibility. I remain in a flexible frame of mind. Certain things I can accept and can't, but I'd like to think that now, they'll - those who postured on one side or another with no responsibility will join the leaders, Republican and Democrat, and say, ``Hey, we got a responsibility to the overall good, here. We can no longer just give a speech, we've got to pitch in and come together.'' And that's, that's what my pitch is. And that's why I'm doing this veto, saying, ``Hey, no more business as usual.'' And I, I think people understand that sometime a president has to make a difficult decision. And so I don't worry about the prestige. I, I'm selected to do what, what - faced like this - what I think is best and in the national interest, and that's exactly what I'm doing. Thank you, all, very much.
End BC-Bush Text - 5 Takes

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Waite, Other Hostages May Be Released This Week
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon's leading newspaper reported Saturday that Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite and some other Westerners held hostage by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups may be released this week. An-Nahar, which has a record of accurate reporting on the captives, attributed its short report to informed sources but did not identify them. The paper indicated that the releases would follow visits to Syria and possibly to Lebanon by Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati. Velayati was to visit Damascus ``in the next two days for consultations with the Syrian command'' of President Hafez Assad and might travel to Beirut for talks with President Elias Hrawi, the report said. ``The release of a number of foreign hostages held in Lebanon, topped by Anglican Chrich envoy Terry Waite, is possible next week,'' the newspaper said in its Saturday edition. It gave no further details. The one-paragraph reference to the hostages was part of the paper's main front-page story. An-Nahar did not disclose the nationalities of the hostages to be released, beyond identifying Waite. But the report was the latest of several to indicate that foreign captives would be freed following renewed diplomatic ties between Britain and Iran. The two nations restored ties last month after an 18-month break over British author Salman Rushdie's book ``The Satanic Verses,'' which Iran said defamed Islam. Hussein Musawi, the Shiite mentor of some hostage-holding factions, said Sept. 29 that the four British hostages would benefit from the development. Musawi said, however, that the six American captives were not expected to be released soon because of the U.S. military deployment in the Persian Gulf following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``Improving relations and the new British conduct toward Iran would serve British interests in general, including the British hostages,'' said Musawi, whose Islamic Amal movement falls under the Hezbollah umbrella. Waite, 51, the personal envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie, disappeared Jan. 20, 1987. He had left his hotel in Moslem west Beirut for a meeting with Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, the underground faction believed holding American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland. No group has claimed Waite's abduction, but former Irish hostage Brian Keenan, released in August, said he was held with the Anglican envoy for a while in the same house. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held foreign hostage in Lebanon. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. In addition to Waite, the British captives are journalist John McCarthy, World War II flier Jack Mann and writer Alec Collett. McCarthy, 33, was kidnapped April 17, 1986, as he drove to Beirut airport to catch a flight to London. Mann, 76, was kidnapped in Beirut May 12, 1989. Collet, a New York-based writer on assignment in Lebanon for the U.N. Relief and Works Agency, was kidnapped March 25, 1985. The Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Moslems, believed linked to Palestinian terrorist Abu Nidal, claimed on April 23, 1986 that it hanged Collett in retaliation for Britain's support of U.S. air raids on Libya. No body has been found, but British officials believe Collett is dead. The 13 Western captives, held mainly by pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon, also include two Germans and an Italian. The An-Nahar article also said Velayati was to develop, along with Syrian and Lebanese leaders, a settlement to the 3-year-old conflict between two rival Shiite Moslem militias - the pro-Iranian Hezbollah and the more secular Amal. On Saturday, the two militias fought a 30-minute battle in the slums of south Beirut before Syrian troops separated the combatants. Police said two people were killed and three wounded in the clash with automatic rifles and rocket-propelled grenade launchers a few blocks from where the western captives are believed held. That raised the overall toll of the Amal-Hezbollah power struggle to 1,099 killed and 3,225 wounded since the conflict broke out in June 1985. Syria is Amal's main ally and has a limited influence on Hezbollah through its close ties with Iran. About 40,000 Syrian troops went into Lebanon under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the 21-nation Arab League. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Turned Back at Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island
LaserPhoto NY17
With AM-Government Shutdown, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: No huddled masses assembled Saturday at the Statue of Liberty, which was shut down by a tired and poor federal government. Thousands of sightseers from around the United States and the world felt one of the first effects of the federal budget dispute. They trekked to lower Manhattan to catch ferries to Liberty and Ellis islands only to find the boats weren't running. ``It's very annoying,'' said Magdalene Kopp of Heidelberg, Germany. ``It's something I came to the United States to see.'' Instead of the outstretched arm of Lady Liberty or Ellis Island's cavernous waiting room, tourists were greeted by a disheartening monotone announcement over loudspeakers: ``Attention visitors: The Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island are closed until further notice. Sorry for the inconvenience.'' Helen Bealka, 62, traveled from St. Paul, Minn., to see Ellis Island, where her father first set foot in America. ``This is horrible. I don't know if I'll live long enough to come back,'' she said. The Ellis Island closing came less than a month after the renovated area was reopened to the public. The closures resulted from Bush's refusal to sign a stopgap spending plan as his administration and Congress haggled over a new budget. Getting turned away from the nation's symbol of freedom was enough to convince most visitors they were the victims of undue suffering at politicians' hands. ``It's a disgrace when reasonable people can't agree on something. Why can't these clowns get together on this?'' said Henry Bowman, 44, of Cookeville, Tenn. ``This was our one chance to go.'' Said Abigail Hoffman, 33, of New York City: ``I wish they'd make some hard choices. That's why they were voted in.'' National Park Service employee Eli Mecardo usually sells Liberty Island ferry tickets, but on Saturday he, too, was turned back. ``They just told us to go home,'' he said. ``They said the government ran out of money and we're not getting paid.'' Although most people grumbled and cursed Washington, a few thought the inconvenience was for the common good. ``I'm disappointed, but it's one of the things that happen in government,'' said Ruth Flaton, 72, of Elmont. ``Maybe it's one way to balance the budget. I think Bush did the right thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Halt Pro-Democracy Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Riot police wielding batons and shields prevented pro-democracy campaigners from meeting Saturday to establish Zambia's first legal opposition party in 17 years. Paramilitary units stood guard outside the Moon City Night Club in the Zambian capital, barring hundreds of would-be party delegates from entering. The legal committee of the so-called Movement for Multi-Party Democracy, which called the meeting, immediately filed an injunction with the High Court against the police. But High Court Judge Bobby Bwalya postponed the hearing for a week so officials from the movement and from President Kenneth Kaunda's ruling United National Independence Party could testify. There was no immediate comment from the government. Kaunda, 66, who led Zambia to independence from Britain as a Western-style democracy in 1964, imposed a one-party state in 1973. Last month, under mounting pressure from lawyers, students, trade unionists and businessmen, Kaunda agreed to rewrite the constitution to legalize opposition parties. Earlier, he legalized the pro-democracy group and announced multiparty elections would be held next August to allow his 7.5 million people to decide what political system they want. But police refused to issue a permit for Saturday's conference, despite earlier government assurances that opposition groups could hold meetings. Levi Mwanawasa, head of the movement's legal committee, told 400 supporters at the group's headquarters that the meeting had to be canceled because of the police blockade. ``We are not going to give up,'' chairman Arthur Wina, a former Kaunda loyalist and onetime Cabinet minister, told the gathering. ``But our patience is running out. We're being pushed against a wall.'' In the central Copperbelt province mining city of Kitwe, the Zambian Congress of Trade Unions passed a motion Saturday calling for Kaunda's resignation. Similar calls for Kaunda to step down have been made since rioting over increased food prices in July left at least 26 people dead. Opponents accuse Kaunda of corruption, mismanagement, authoritarianism and nepotism.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Police are hoping a light blue silk scarf once owned by the singer Madonna will come into vogue when it's put on the auction block. The scarf went with a $20,000 blue-sequined dress owned by the Michigan native. The ensemble was stolen two years ago from an MTV display at Twelve Oaks Mall in this hamlet about 15 miles northwest of Detroit. The dress was found three days later and returned, but police forgot until recently to return the scarf. And now MTV doesn't seem to want it. ``All attempts to return it have fallen on deaf ears,'' said Novi police officer Robert Gatt, who handled the purloined-clothing case. Thus, the scarf became property of the department, which is auctioning it off to raise money for its Drug Abuse Resistance Education program. The scarf will fetch at least $500, which is the minimum the department will accept in its sealed-bid auction to be held Nov. 1. As for the clothing caper culprit, an overzealous fan was convicted of larceny and sentenced to probation. --- CORAOPOLIS, Pa. (AP) - Actor Michael Keaton has given the Roman Catholic school he once attended mounds of memorabilia from his hit movie ``Batman.'' Keaton, who played the caped crusader in the 1989 film, sent toys, dolls, videocassettes and other items to the St. Malachy Roman Catholic School and church for its annual Nationalities Festival. Keaton attended grade school at St. Malachy and his mother is a parishioner at the church, according to a church secretary. The festival, which began Thursday and concludes Sunday, raises money to fund parish activities, according to the secretary, who declined to give her name. Keaton, who stars in the recently released thriller, ``Pacific Heights,'' appeared in one movie made in Pittsburgh, ``Gung Ho,'' which told the story of Japanese auto makers who took over an abandoned American factory. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moved on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Dee Brown, a National Basketball Association hopeful, is moving to this affluent Boston suburb despite an incident in which the town's police forced him to the ground at gunpoint. Brown, who's black, was confronted by Wellesley police who had mistaken him for a bank robber Sept. 21. ``I'm going to make my home in Wellesley,'' Brown told WBZ-TV in Boston in interview broadcast Friday. ``It makes me feel confident that me and my fiancee will be safe there.'' But Brown, the Boston Celtics No. 1 draft choice, also authorized his lawyer to consider suing the town after private negotiations failed to work out a settlement over his detention by police. ``The town has chosen the position that racism was not a factor and that all of the police procedures were proper and correct,'' said Brown's lawyer, Alan Margolies. ``We disagree.'' Margolies said he had offered the town a deal but was rebuffed. He did not return telephone calls seeking details of his proposed settlement, nor would Wellesley officials disclose it. Brown, a 6-foot-1 point guard who participated in the first day of training camp Friday, said he had received letters and petitions from Wellesley residents asking him to move there. Blacks make up less than 2 percent of the town's population. ``You don't want a rap like that on your town, that every time a black person (or) a suspicious person or everybody that doesn't look like a Wellesley citizen, you have to check them or ID them,'' Brown said. --- NEW YORK (AP) - William F. Buckley Jr., the founder of National Review, says he will soon leave the position he has held as ranking editor for 35 years at the conservative biweekly magazine. The 64-year-old author, TV commentator and editor said he would become an editor at large. He spoke late Friday at a banquet for the magazine. The 35th anniversary issue, which is to be published in two weeks, will be his last as the top editor. Buckley told about 800 guests, ``We did as much as anybody, with the exception of himself, to shepherd into the White House Ronald Reagan.'' Buckley, who also will step down as chief executive officer of the magazine, will be replaced by Wick Allison, the current publisher. The ranking editor will be John O'Sullivan, who will continue in his title as editor.

DOC.HEAD: American Weds In Lockerbie, Where Her Daughter Died
DOC.TEXT: An American widow whose daughter and son-in-law were killed in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 was married Saturday in this small town where the local people had been kind to her. Marion Alderman, 63, of Camden, N.Y., married Edward Jablonski, 68, of Rome, N.Y., at All Saints Church in a ceremony attended by 20 Lockerbie villagers. ``It is a great joy to be here today for this happy ceremony after all the grief that Lockerbie has seen,'' said the Rev. Alan Neal, rector of All Saints. Town councilor Hugh Young gave the bride away. He and his wife, Linda, were witnesses. ``We're so happy,'' said the new Mrs. Jablonski. ``It was a beautiful ceremony and everyone has been wonderful.'' Her daughter, Paula, 29, and Paula's British husband Glenn Bouckley were killed while flying home to Syracuse, N.Y. after attending the wedding of Glenn's brother. They were among 259 passengers who died when the Boeing 747 was blown apart by a terrorist bomb on Dec. 21, 1988. Eleven Lockerbie residents were also killed on the ground. ``I first visited the town six months after the disaster and put a wooden cross in the golf course where my daughter's body landed,'' the bride said Friday. ``The locals were very kind and considerate.'' She was among the relatives visiting Lockerbie this week for a public inquiry into the bombing. Jablonski, an electronics engineer, said Saturday: ``We couldn't have found a nicer place to get married. We originally intended to wait until next year, but Marion had already planned her trip to Lockerbie and we thought it would be a good idea to have the ceremony here. ``It's our way of paying tribute to the local people. Marion has told me how well they treated her and other bereaved relatives after the disaster.''

DOC.HEAD: Biggest Human Airlift Aids Gulf Refugees
With AM-Gulf-US Buildup, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The biggest human airlift in aviation history is ferrying hundreds of penniless Asian refugees from the Persian Gulf to their homelands daily, but a shortage of relief aid could clip its wings. Relief officials also fear that many of the estimated 2 million foreigners still in Iraq and Kuwait may soon flee as well, putting enormous strain on the operation and on Jordan, the main escape route. Some 422,400 refugees, mainly Egyptian and Asians, have been flown out of Jordan in more than 1,798 flights by military and civilian aircraft since Aug. 5, Jordanian civil aviation officials said. Another 60,000 have been flown home from Turkey and hundreds of thousands, mainly Egyptians, have been taken home by sea. ``This is the biggest airlift operation ever undertaken in civil aviation,'' said J.N. Mahajan, the Indian consul-general in Dubai, who has overseen the repatriation of nearly 17,000 of his countrymen through the southern gulf state. On Saturday, the United Nations announced a contingency plan to help refugees if the gulf crisis escalates or extends into the winter. U..N. Undersecretary-general Mohammed Essaafi said the world body's disaster relief agency and Jordanian officials are preparing food stockpiles to feed up to 120,000 more refugees. They also are buying winter tents to replace the summer tents in Jordanian refugee camps. Half the 335,000 Egyptians who fled Kuwait and Iraq after Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of the gulf emirate have been airlifted home by the Cairo government. Most of the estimated 70,000 Indians repatriated have been flown home. All told, some 900,000 people have fled into Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Syria and Iran in the last two months, 720,000 of them through Jordan alone. The State Department fears that as conditions deteriorate because of U.N.-imposed economic sanctions, many of the 2 million foreigners still in Iraq and Kuwait will try to flee. U.N. relief officials have warned that there could be a new surge in the exodus soon because the Iraqis have said they will cut food rations to foreigners trapped in the two countries. Jordanian authorities expect 80,000 new refugees in the next week. All this will intensify the pressure on relief workers, who are now seeking to help the refugees through the approaching winter, and will cost tens of millions of dollars. Many of the relief flights are organized by the Geneva-based International Organization for Migration. One of its senior officials, David Whittlesey, said in a telephone interview that more money is needed urgently to pay for the airlift. Whittlesey said the relief effort ``in its scale and nature, is a unique situation.'' ``It's extremely difficult to predict the rate of flow from Iraq and Kuwait, which nationalities these refugees will be, where they will want to go, what condition they'll be in. It's a logistical nightmare.'' The Indian government has paid more than $14 million to Air India to ferry more than 13,000 citizens out by Oct. 3. Iraq last month allowed the Indian air force to send in four flights a day to the southern port of Basra to evacuate about 1,000 Indian nationals daily. Pakistan has evacuated some 45,000 of the 190,000 nationals it had in Iraq and Kuwait, mainly through Jordan. Thailand's national carrier has flown more than 40 flights carrying more than 7,500 Thai refugees from Jordan and Saudi Arabia to Bangkok. The U.S. government last month flew some 1,900 of its citizens out of Baghdad in chartered jetliners after Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein allowed them to leave. Another group is expected to fly out on Wednesday, officials said. The Soviet Union has flown more than 2,500 of its people out of Iraq in Aeroflot jetliners. And Brazil chartered an Iraqi Airways jumbo jet last week to fly out 173 of its citizens after weeks of tough negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Two Sisters, Brother Hold Reunion in Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf-US Buildup, Bjt
LaserPhoto DHA5
DOC.TEXT: Navy Yeoman 1st Class Patrice Davis says a military career might not be for everybody. But her family is the sort recruiters dream about. Of the eight children in the Elmore family of Charleston, S.C., six are in U.S. military service, and three are assigned to Saudi Arabia. On Saturday, Patrice, the oldest at 28, held an emotional reunion with her sister, Army Sgt. 1st Class Darnetha Elmore, 25, a member of an intelligence unit, and her brother, Army Spec. Loris Elmore, 21, a paratrooper. It was their first meeting since all three became part of the 170,000 Americans deployed under Operation Desert Shield following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. There were grins and hugs as the trio met at a hotel in Dhahran where Patrice, known to friends as ``Mo,'' works in the Joint Information Bureau operated by the Saudi Information Ministry and the U.S. military command. Then they went off to Patrice's room to talk family and call their mother, Sandra, back in Charleston. Patrice, normally based in Alexandri,, Va., said she volunteered for duty in Saudi Arabia because ``aside from the ones on ships,'' many Navy people don't get the chance to travel. She said she checked with her husband and two days later was on her way. Loris, a member of the 82nd Airborne Division, said that when members of his unit learned he had two sisters in Saudi Arabia, ``they said, `Well, you don't get much mail, so they're mailing your family over here'.'' The three agreed that being together in the potential war zone was worrisome. ``I think about it but I don't dwell on it,'' said Patrice. Darnetha, describing herself as ``a sort of upbeat person,'' said of her brothers and sisters that she didn't mind being in Saudi Arabia ``as long as I can see them and know they're OK. I try not to think about the bad stuff.'' Loris said it helps to know his sisters ``can handle it if they ever get into a situation. ``I still worry a lot, but I know they're going to be coming home on their own two feet,'' he said. Patrice said she enlisted in the Navy while still in high school and left for the service 13 days after graduation. ``I was being a rebel,'' she recalled. ``My father wanted me to go to college. I just wanted to do my own thing.'' Her example led the others to follow suit, although only one brother, Lee Anthony, 27, opted for the Navy. He is assigned to a ship based at Charleston. Also in the military are brothers Tracy, 22, an Army specialist based at Flint Hills Farm, Va., and Donnie, 20, a specialist serving with an Army Signal Corps unit in South Korea. Two other sisters in Charleston are Michelle, 24, a patient care assistant, and Sherita, 14, who lives with their mother. Saturday's phone call to the Elmore home lasted 25 minutes, Patrice said, and included ``nothing about over here.'' She said her mother ``wanted to know how we are and whether we're eating all right, if we got all her letters. And we just got caught up on gossip.''

DOC.HEAD: Fed Up With Politics As Usual, Public Seeks To Limit Terms, Spending
DOC.TEXT: The public, as usual, is fed up with politics as usual. But disgruntled voters in three states and one city are considering turning their grumbling into action on Nov. 6. Ballot proposals in Colorado, California and Missouri would limit how long elected officials can serve. Proposals creating state ethics panels also are on ballots in Missouri and California. Missouri's proposed amendment would also reduce the size of the House from 163 to 103 members by 2003, and shorten legislative sessions. Bolstering support for the amendment were the convictions of two Missouri House members in U.S. District Court last month: one on felony drug charges, the other for conspiring to steal union property and sell it to repay a federal grant. Colorado's proposal would not only limit state legislators, the governor and other state officeholders to eight years in office, but also impose a cap of 12 years for U.S. House and Senate members. Critics question whether such a cap would be permissable under the federal constitution. Kansas City, Mo., residents will decide on Election Day whether to limit City Council members to two four-year terms. That proposal could force nine of 13 members out of office next April. Oklahoma voters recently approved an amendment limiting state lawmakers to 12 years in office, effective Jan. 1, and also established an ethics comission. Arizonans, meanwhile, are considering a pay increase for state legislators to $24,000 from $15,000. The last such raise, which must be approved by voters under state law, was in 1981. They defeated a similar recommendation in 1988. Skepticism about public officials has, of course, a long history. A half century ago, H.L. Mencken wrote: ``At each election we vote in a new set of politicians, insanely assuming that they are better than the set turned out. And at each election we are, as they say ... done in.'' But ballot issues limiting legislators' terms are unprecedented, said Karl Kurtz, director of state services for National Conference of State Legislatures. Some states have limited governors' terms before, though, he said. ``I think this is occurring because of disillusionment over government ... and it is showing in election returns,'' Kurtz said. ``I don't think any one thing has forced this. It's just a general sense of unhappiness with governmental institutions and the image of politicians.'' Kurtz called the propositions ``anti-democratic in spirit.'' The Colorado proposal is spearheaded by state Sen. Terry Considine, a Republican from wealthy Cherry Hills Village who believes the state Legislature, like Congress, is gridlocked. ``It's not that we do the wrong things; it's that we don't tackle the real problems,'' Considine said. ``We work very hard at incremental improvements, but we are much less successful at accomplishing real change.'' Two years ago, Colorado voters limited annual legislative sessions to 120 days. Term limitations are addressed in two proposals on California's November ballot - Proposition 131 and Proposition 140. Politicians, including Assembly Speaker Willie Brown, are mobilizing to kill both. One proposition is a clean government amendment with ethics and campaign finance provisions, including term limitations allowing legislators to serve 12 years in each house of the California State Assembly, or 24 years total. The other, more stringent proposal would bar legislators from serving more than eight years in the State Senate and six in the House. It would have the effect of cutting the Legislature's next fiscal year budget by as much as half.

DOC.HEAD: Streaming Along in 20-Foot-Long Sun-Powered Tadpole
LaserPhoto DT2 of Oct. 3
DOC.TEXT: Today's state-of-the-art solar car looks like a waist-high, 20-foot-long, bright yellow plastic tadpole. Getting in without breaking it is an adventure, and only one person will fit. And taking one home from the showroom isn't likely soon - the price tag comes to about $650,000, plus $350,000 for computers and other ancillary equipment. But the squat, yellow University of Michigan Sunrunner has one thing going for it: It's a national champion in solar speed, and it's headed for an international challenge on the roadways of Australia next month. In July, the Sunrunner and 31 other solar-powered cars built by college teams raced from Florida's Disney World to General Motors Corp.'s Technical Center in the Detroit suburb of Warren. The Sunrunner, traveling by day and resting overnight, won the 1,641-mile race with a time of 72 hours, 50 minutes and 47 seconds, averaging 22.5 mph. GM is sending the Sunrunner and other top finishers to the World Solar Challenge 1990 race. In all, 43 cars from 10 countries are entered in the race, which begins Nov. 11 and will stretch 1,863 miles from Darwin on Australia's northern coast to Adelaide on the south coast. For the race, the Sunrunner team hopes to reach an average speed of 32 mph. To take the car out for a recent test drive at the Michigan International Speedway, industrial engineer Paula Finnegan had to buckle on a safety harness, then have a colleague boost her up into the open top of the car. Inside, she balanced on the aluminum-tubing skeleton and the hammocklike seat slung down in the frame. She then threaded her legs through the jungle-gym-like tubing to the accelerator and brake, reclined in the seat, buckled on harness straps and put on a headset with earpiece and microphone. The Sunrunner still wasn't ready. Three people gingerly lifted its floppy plastic canopy from the ground, lowered it over Finnegan and sealed it in place with bright yellow tape. During test laps, it reached 23 mph on a mostly sunny day with thin, high clouds. For faster speeds or hills, the Sunrunner's circuitry draws on battery help. At slower speeds, or going downhill, it puts excess power from the solar cells back into the batteries. In bright sun, the solar cells produce about 1,200 watts, enough to power a toaster oven, hair dryer, or the 500-pound Sunrunner. Cloudy weather can cut the power to 300 to 400 watts, enough for a bright light bulb. A 1.5 horsepower electric motor the size of a coffee can powers the car via chain drive on one of the 26-inch mountain-bike wheels. There's a viewing slot to view the road ahead, and a rearward facing fiber-optic viewer that allows the driver to get an idea of what's behind. Two ports in the front of the cockpit bring in fresh air. ``The drivers said it wasn't too bad as long as they kept moving,'' said Mike McAlear, strategist for the team. For now, electric cars will have to rely on batteries. Solar cells and motors must become more efficient before energy straight from the sun can propel a car faster than 30 mph. Solar cars therefore aren't on the verge of practical commuting, Finnegan said. ``Not any time in the near future, but with improved technology it can happen.''

DOC.HEAD: Opponents Demand Roh's Apology for Alleged Surveillance
DOC.TEXT: Opposition legislators demanded Saturday that President Roh Tae-woo apologize for alleged political surveillance by military intelligence agents. The nation's main opposition group, the Party for Peace and Democracy, urged Roh to overhaul the Defense Security Command - the military surveillance unit - and end military interference in politics. The party also demanded a full explanation from Roh of the alleged activities. The outcry followed the disclosure Friday of alleged evidence of undercover operations by the command against 1,300 dissidents, journalists, intellectuals and lawmakers from both the opposition and government. The alleged evidence was revealed by Yoon Suk-yang, a 24-year-old army private who deserted from the security command taking with him classified papers, computer discs and other data. The data included the names and personal records of ruling party chairman Kim Young-sam, opposition leader Kim Dae-jung and 89 other lawmakers. The data characterized Kim Dae-jung as ``dangerous, untrustworthy'' and showed that Kim Young-sam and his followers were under surveillance even after his party joined the ruling group in January. The Defense Ministry said the data and other materials were stolen from the security command, but said such data was kept not for political surveillance but to ``protect those listed from enemies or impure elements.'' The ministry did not elaborate. The government has two powerful intelligence organizations - the Defense Security Command and the Agency for National Security Planning. Disgraced former president Chun Doo-hwan, who is in rural exile, headed the command in 1980 when he seized power with other military officers. Roh played a role as an army division commander. Roh has promised to maintain the military's political neutrality since he took office in early 1988, but Friday's revelations forced some to question that pledge. Both ruling and opposition party leaders demanded that Roh fully account for the military's surveillance activity. Kim Dae-jung's party called for a public investigation saying the command was used to bolster authoritarian rules. Roh captured two-thirds of the legislative seats in January by merging his party with two conservative opposition groups. Opponents claim the merger was an attempt to prolong his rule and gain enough votes to seek political changes. Political tension has heightened since all 78 opposition members of the 299-member National Assembly resigned in August, charging Roh with railroading bills through the legislature and ignoring calls for reform. The opposition has refused to return to the assembly and demands elections for a new legislature.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Former Head of Egyptian Antiquities Dies in US
DOC.TEXT: Ahmed Kadry, who headed the Egyptian Antiquities Organization through a turbulent six years that began and ended with rocks falling from the Sphinx, has died in the United States, friends said Saturday. He was 59. Kadry's friends said he died Thursday in Pittsburgh, where he was awaiting a liver transplant. Suffering from liver cancer, he fell into a coma before the operation could be performed. ``He was honest, active, brave, frank,'' said Gamal Mukhtar, another former chairman of the antiquities organization. Kadry's career was long and turbulent. He was among the young officers who joined Lt. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser in the 1952 coup that ended the monarchy and eventually led to republican Egypt. Kadry later was to spend time in Nasser's jails during one of the former dictator's crackdowns on dissent. After his military career, Kadry spent 26 years with the Egyptian Antiquities Organization. He became chairman in 1982 after a stone fell from the decaying Sphinx and cost his predecessor the job. Six years later, Kadry was fired in a similar controversy when a rock fell from the right shoulder of the giant statue in February 1988. Soon after, Culture Minister Farouk Hosni and Kadry engaged in a heated public argument. Hosni, Kadry's boss, charged that a restoration project in progress since Kadry became chairman had endangered the monument. Kadry retaliated with allegations that the minister's agents hammered the stone out to embarrass him. Hosni fired Kadry. A bitter Kadry left Egypt to join the faculty of Tokyo's Waseda University. Criticism of Kadry's Sphinx restoration continues. But in recent months some critics have praised his other achievements as chairman. A television commentator referred to his tenure as ``the golden age of Egyptian antiquities.'' Kadry is best remembered for restoration work on ancient mosques and other Islamic monuments, including Saladin's fortress overlooking Cairo and his small fort in the Gulf of Aqaba. The strong-willed Kadry became chairman of antiquities as the outside world was starting to realize that Egypt's vast historic legacy wouldn't last forever. Pollution, underground salt, a burgeoning population, neglect and mass tourism were destroying the monuments. Looking for ways to stop the decay, or at least slow it down, Kadry shifted his organization's emphasis from excavation to preservation. He turned to foreign help and imported technology to fight the battle. For this, commentators assailed him vigorously, accusing him of letting foreigners pillage Egypt's past as they had done during colonial times.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Apologizes For Bad Speech
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate Mary Mead is sorry for a speech she made - but not because of anything she said. ``I got reports saying it was boring and that I hadn't really said anything,'' she said. A week after the Sept. 19 speech, she wrote a letter to apologize for the speech ``not necessarily to change anybody's mind about me, but just to let them know that it mattered to me.'' Mead addressed the Wyoming Association of County Officials and lightly touched on court reform, recycling, and legalized gambling, among other topics. In her letter, she said she heard people say that she ``didn't address the issues'' and ``wasted an opportunity to make a favorable impression on some important Wyoming voters.'' ``And, regrettably, I agree,'' Mead wrote. ``Even before I left your meeting I knew that my remarks had not served me well. Some days are great and some aren't - and I wish I could redo that one.'' Mead is hoping to unseat incumbent Gov. Mike Sullivan, who's seeking his second term in the state's executive office.

DOC.HEAD: Government Shutdown Turns Back Tourists From Nation's Parks, Museums
DOC.TEXT: Nine-year-old Michael Woodward went looking for pandas and koala bears at the National Zoo on Saturday, but instead found locked and shuttered buildings because of a budget fight between the White House and Congress. ``I'm really disappointed. I've been saving for a long time for this trip. I guess I'll have to come back to see the pandas,'' said the boy, who journeyed from Harrisburg, Pa., with his parents and a church group to see the zoo. The zoo's grounds were open but huts housing reptiles, apes, birds and aquatic life were closed. The scene was duplicated at some of the nation's most famous tourist spots - from the Statue of Liberty in New York to the St. Louis Arch - as President Bush's decision to shut down non-essential services took effect early Saturday in the absence of a budget agreement. ``I think it's a cheap shot - closing the (Smithsonian Institution) museums like this. You can bet they didn't cut their salaries,'' Maria Raices, a New Hampshire resident, complained about Congress' and the White House's inability to settle the budget dispute that allowed the government to run out of money. If tourists were inconvenienced, most federal workers had not yet felt the impact of possible furloughs. A three-day Columbus Day weekend meant most cuts would not be felt until Tuesday at the earliest. And the Bush administration said it had authority to maintain essential services - such as the military, prisons and the air traffic control system - well beyond then. The National Hurricane Center announced plans to remain in business, and was continuing to keep tabs on Tropical Storm Klaus. That was little comfort to those who flocked on Saturday to the nation's capital in hopes of visiting its famed attractions - the White House tours, the Washington Monument, the Smithsonian's 13 museums and art galleries. ``Their first comment, in harmony, was `It stinks,''' Boy Scout leader Bill Johnson said of his scouts' reaction to finding the National Air and Space Museum closed. The troop had traveled from Roanoke Rapids, N.C., to spend the day sightseeing. The 15 scouts marched down the Mall, past the closed museums toward the Capitol, hoping they could get in to see Congress. ``Maybe this won't be a lost weekend, after all. The boys won't forget this and I expect they'll go home and tell their parents about what happened to them,'' Johnson said. At the air and space museum, tourists packing cameras and video equipment pressed their noses against the glass front, straining to glimpse the NASA rockets, boosters and airplanes suspended from the ceiling inside. ``This one's closed, too, Dad. The people are just peeking inside,'' one youngster glumly called out. Evelyn Abes of New York City, who was wrapping up a five-day visit to Washington with her 9-year-old grandson, had been saving the air and space tour for last. ``This was going to be the highlight of our trip,'' she said, waving toward the museum. ``I guess we'll have to do the car stuff now. ... ``The government's shutdown is not making you stop eating or causing a loss of blood or anything, but this is a quality of life issue, enlightening children and helping them learn about the world,'' Mrs. Abes said. Many out-of-town sightseers were flustered by the locked museums, wondering out loud at signs that said, ``All Smithsonian museums are closed today. We regret the inconvenience.'' Friendly, informed tourists told them why, `Congress couldn't pass its bill,'' they said, or ``The government's run out of money.'' Sightseers from around the globe felt the impact in New York, when they trekked to lower Manhattan to catch ferries to Liberty and Ellis Islands to see the Statue of Liberty, only to find the boats weren't running. Helen Bealka, 62, traveled from St. Paul, Minn., to see Ellis Island, where her father first set foot in America. ``This is horrible. I don't know if I'll live long enough to come back,'' she said. The nation's parks were affected, too, as rangers nationwide began locking gates and closing down camp grounds when word was dispatched from Washington that the federal government was out of money. A bus load of tourists from Indiana drove six hours to reach the Great Smoky Mountains National Park in Tennessee, only to be turned away by rangers. ``It's really unfair to rub this in the people's face. This is really not helping relations with the public. ... I just feel like it's a political ploy,'' said Bob Davenport, leading the group from Muncie, Ind. At the White House, the staff that serves the president's living quarters - ushers, butlers, chefs, maids - has already been cut from 70 to 10. ``We won't be having any big dinners around here,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. John Sturdivant, president of the 700,000-member American Federation of Government Employees, complained about Bush's choice of words for explaining his veto of stopgap budget legislation that would have ended the shutdown. The president apologized for any ``inconvenience'' that might have been caused. ``He should have said `I'm sorry for the disaster I've caused,''' Sturdivant said. ``It's more than an inconvenience for employees to be without a paycheck or go through two months of anxiety about what's going to happen to them.''

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Launched Smoothly, Ulysses Probe Sent En Route To Sun
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with successful firing of rockets, sending solar probe out of Earth orbit. Picks up 6th graf pvs: ``In 1994 ...'' ^LaserPhotos CSB1, CSB3, CSB7; LaserColor CSB2, CSB4
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Discovery rocketed into orbit Saturday, carrying Americans into space for the first time in nearly six months and starting the robot craft Ulysses on a five-year voyage of solar exploration. The five-man Discovery crew smoothly accomplished its primary goal, casting off Ulysses exactly as planned. The probe then rocketed itself out of Earth orbit. ``Good deploy, Houston,'' said mission commander Richard N. Richards after the solar probe was freed from the shuttle. ``Ulysses is on its way.'' ``That's a great job,'' Mission Control replied. Three rocket stages then fired automatically on Ulysses, and the craft was accelerated out of Earth orbit at 34,130 mph, the fastest speed ever for a manmade object. Mission Control told the astronauts that ground monitors in Guam and Australia determined Ulysses was exactly where it should be, indicating that the rocket stages fired as planned. ``Fantastic!'' exclaimed an astronaut from space. The atomic-powered solar explorer started its independent voyage six hours after the shuttle was launched by dawn's early light. Discovery roared from its seaside launch pad and climbed flawlessly to a 184-mile-high orbit. Ulysses will follow a roundabout path, first cruising away from the sun toward Jupiter. The powerful gravity pull of that giant planet will act like a slingshot, accelerating the probe to an even higher speed and sending it streaking back toward the sun. In 1994, Ulysses will pass over the sun's south pole, then curve over the north solar pole. The sun's poles cannot be seen from Earth and have never been explored. Because Ulysses is powered by a generator energized by more than 20 pounds of plutonium, anti-nuclear activists filed a lawsuit to block the launch of the radioactive material. But a federal judge ruled against their petition Friday. That same day, two of 20 anti-nuclear demonstrators were arrested at the Kennedy Space Center. NASA staffers cheered as Discovery soared into space only 12 minutes later than the planned 7:35 a.m. launch time. The delay was caused by a minor weather problem and a last-minute technical glitch. Discovery's mission is scheduled to last four days with a landing Wednesday in California. The launch wasn't affected by the shutdown of many federal agencies because funds for the mission already had been set aside, officials said. After the craft settled into orbit, Mission Control in Houston told the astronauts: ``There are a lot of smiling faces down here on the ground.'' ``There's a lot of smiling faces up here, too,'' replied Richards. ``You all did a great job getting us off the pad this morning. We couldn't ask for anything better.'' The launch came after months of frustation for NASA. A mysterious hydrogen fuel leak, still unsolved, forced a series of launch cancellations for space shuttles Columbia and Atlantis. NASA's last previous launch was April 24, when Discovery took off. Another embarrassment came over the summer when NASA engineers learned that the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope had been manufactured with an error that gives it a blurred view of the universe. The error was not found until after it had been deployed in space by Discovery last April. And last week, NASA was embarrassed again when workers left a 70-pound metal beam inside the engine compartment of Atlantis and the beam caused some minor damage when it clanked around inside as the spacecraft was lifted and rotated by a crane. The smooth launch on Saturday was a boost for NASA's morale, said launch director Bob Sieck. ``We're obviously pleased,'' he said. The mood among space workers, he said, ``is one of euphoria or relief. It's certainly good to be back ... on orbit. The team worked real hard for this. They got their reward - finally.'' Sieck said Discovery had only a few minor problems in its countdown toward launch. He said the craft is ``the fleet leader right now because it got us back to flight again.'' Besides Richards, the crew members are pilot Robert D. Cabana and mission specialists William M. Shepherd, Bruce Melnick and Thomas D. Akers.

DOC.HEAD: Government Shutdown Also Dims Lights at White House
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new penultimate graf with Bush motorcading to wedding
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, who rarely stays in town on weekends, presided Saturday over an executive mansion darkened and empty of tourists and where even finding someone to type up a veto proved problematic. The president canceled a holiday weekend visit to his oceanside home in Kennebunkport, Maine, and remained in Washington to keep tabs on the federal budget stalemate. When Congress failed to produce a new budget agreement on Friday, the government officially ran out of money and all non-essential government services were shut down effective Saturday at 12:01 a.m. EDT. Much of the White House also was shut down. Tours were canceled Saturday and only a skeleton staff of aides and attendants were allowed to come to work. But the president declared a defiant ``watch and learn'' when asked how longhe was prepared to allow the government to remain closed down to make his point with Congress. And he raised the stakes by vetoing a bill Congress had passed the night before to avert a government shutdown. But since the bulk of Bush's clerical and press staff had been deemed ``non-essential'' and told not to report to work, getting the word out about the veto wasn't all that easy. Well, Bush conceded to reporters, ``it hasn't been vetoed yet. Need a typewriter in there to get it done.'' ``By the time we finish this press conference that has gone longer than I thought, it'll probably be all typed up,'' he added. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, explained later: ``We don't have any secretaries around here'' - although he also said that he thought the veto message had been typed the night before. Even Bush's news conference to announce the veto was unusual. The press briefing room, where he usually speaks with reporters, was dark and empty. But the president had no problem finding cameras and reporters. He walked outside the White House and stepped up to the battery of microphones in the driveway from which congressional leaders had just departed - including Democrats who blasted Bush for his veto decision. It was the first time in recent memory that a president has held a news conference in the driveway. Dozens of tourists, barred entry to the White House because of the shutdown, pressed against the fence along Pennsylvania Avenue to peer at the president and the large crowd of reporters surrounding him. The rule that only essential government workers could remain on the job apparently did not apply to presidential motorcades. Bush took an 11-car procession to a church in the Georgetown section of the city to attend the wedding the wedding of White House personnel chief Chase Untermeyer. Since taking office in January 1989, Bush has only spent a handful of weekends in the White House. Usually he spends Saturdays and Sundays at the presidential retreat in Camp David, Md., or at his vacation home in Maine.

The budget crisis that has pitted the executive branch against the legislative branch, the president against Congress and Democrats against Republicans is grounded in years of government infighting over how best to cope with steadily rising federal deficits. Here are answers to some of questions most frequently asked about the impact of budget stalemate on the American people and their lives:

Q: Why has the federal government been forced to start shutting down? A: Because the budget dispute prevented enactment of any of the 13 regular appropriations bills for fiscal 1991, the federal budget year that began Oct. 1. The Constitution states that ``No money shall be drawn from the Treasury but in consequence of appropriations made by law.'' While some appropriations are in permanent law, most day-to-day government operations are renewed annually in one or another of the 13 appropriations bills. What that means is that government agencies are not allowed to spend money, including salaries, purchases and so forth, unless there is a law authorizing them to spend money. Since there wasn't even a stopgap law in place Saturday, the agencies were legally required to send people home and close down.

Q: Has this ever happened before? A: Yes. The government was forced to shut down temporarily three times in the past decade due to squabbles between the administration and Congress over the budget. The government closed briefly in November 1981 when an estimated 400,000 employees were dismissed at midday after President Reagan vetoed an emergency money bill. On October 4, 1984, about 500,000 government workers were sent home by Congress' failure to approve an appropriations bill. On October 16, 1986, the government sent 500,000 non-essential employees home at midday, but Congress later in the day passed an appropriations bill acceptable to Reagan and workers were ordered to report on their next shift. Congress, as it had done in 1981 and 1984, passed a resolution ordering that employees furloughed get their regular salaries anyway.

Q: What is this ``Gramm-Rudman Act'' I keep hearing so much about and why was it passed? A: Congress enacted the law, named for Sens. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, and Warren Rudman, R-N.H., in 1985 and revised it in 1987. Some refer to it as ``Gramm-Rudman-Hollings,'' to reflect that Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., played a role in its creation. Passage of the law, in effect, was a legislative admission of failure - a recognition by members of the House and Senate that they could not make the tough choices necessary to staunch the flow of government red ink without a threat hanging over them. The law requires Congress and the president to reduce the deficit to predetermined annual targets, leading eventually to a balanced budget. Gramm-Rudman requires across-the-board spending cuts to make up the difference if those targets are missed. The target for fiscal 1991 is $64 billion but the president's estimates are so far above that number that Bush and Congress agree it is impossible to reach. They will change it to a much higher number - if they agree on an overall budget package. The result will be to delay the goal of a balanced budget probably until 1996 or beyond.

Q: What events prompted the current shutdown? A: On Sept. 30, the last day of fiscal 1990, Bush and the bipartisan congressional leadership announced agreement on a five-year, $500 billion deficit-reduction package that included approximately $134 billion in new taxes. Congress passed and Bush signed a one week temporary appropriations bill to keep the government operating while Congress passed the plan. Bush went on national television Tuesday night to appeal for congressional support of the package, but it was voted down Thursday night. Members of the House and Senate approved another stopgap spending measure, known as a ``continuing resolution'' on Friday. That would have kept the government running until next Friday, Oct. 12, and would have given lawmakers another week's time to arrive at a budget consensus. But Bush vetoed that bill Saturday.

Q: How will the shutdown affect my life. Can I still catch my flight, for example? A: The government began closing so-called ``non-essential'' facilities Saturday, but air traffic controllers are among those considered essential. Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Bob Buckhorn says those ``essential services remain in place'' at air control towers. However, if the deadlock persisted, there would be a reduction in the number of controllers allowed to work.

Q: What is meant by ``essential'' and ``non-essential?'' A: Each agency decides what is an essential service. But, generally, staying on the job will be workers dealing with national security, health, emergency and similar things. The military, air traffic controllers, border guards, medical institution personnel and prison guards will be unaffected. Federal meat and poultry inspection will continue during a general shutdown.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Issues New Travel Warnings on Middle East
DOC.TEXT: The State Department advised U.S. citizens on Saturday to avoid traveling to the Israeli-occupied territories because of ``recurrent disturbances and increased tensions'' in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The department also warned travelers to the Middle East, South Asia and North Africa of possible anti-American demonstrations arising from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``Travelers and residents throughout the region should exercise caution and contact the nearest U.S. embassy or consulate to register their presence and receive information on the local situation,'' the warning said. The pair of warnings marked the second time in a week - and the third time since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 - that the State Department has warned Americans against traveling in regions because of Persian Gulf tensions. The separate travel warning on the Israeli territories said Middle East events ``have sparked anti-American sentiments and threats in the territories.'' The department said there have been disturbances in East Jerusalem and warned Americans planning to travel there to check with the American Consulate for an update on conditions. Security has been tightened in the territories and the State Department warned that tourists may be subject to strict and lengthy searches. The department also noted Israel, which has feared Iraq's chemical warfare capabilities, is distributing gas masks to citizens starting Oct. 14. ``Americans should take this into account in planning to visit Israel,'' the travel warning said.

DOC.HEAD: Contacts Under Way for Resuming Relief Flights in Sudan
DOC.TEXT: U.N. officials have resumed contacts with the military government aimed at resuming relief flights to rebel-held areas in southern Sudan, a U.N. relief official said Saturday. Trover Page, director of the World Food Program and representative of the U.N. secretary-general, called this week's government decision to lift the ban on the food shipments ``extremely good news.'' Figures released recently by the United Nation in New York indicate famine threatens up to one-fifth of Sudan's 25 million people. ``Much of the Sudan is affected,'' Page said. ``It is much more than that . . . Much of Sudan faces food scarcity at the time.'' Page said he would not call it famine but ``serious food shortage.'' Sudan's military leader, Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan El-Bashir, last weekend banned Red Cross and U.N. relief flights to south Sudan, where the Sudan People's Liberation Army holds most the three provinces except for some garrison towns. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar confronted el-Bashir about the ban during meetings in New York this week. El-Bashir's foreign minister, Ali Sahloul, later said mercy flights would resume. The rebels took up arms in 1983 to demand greater autonomy and economic and administrative reforms.
