DOC.HEAD: Veterans Cry Shame on Proposed Home Closing
DOC.TEXT: At 100 years old, Ethel Pierce hasn't forgotten nursing ``the boys'' of World War I, sometimes filling out night reports with her feet propped up on a water pail to stop the rats from running up her legs. Now it's time for her government to remember, says Pierce, who like most residents of the Holyoke Soldiers Home doesn't know where she'll go after April 1, the date the facility is scheduled to close because of state budget cuts. ``It's a shame,'' she said. ``We went (to war) and we didn't know whether we'd get back or not.'' Leaving the Holyoke home, perched on a hilltop that overlooks the wooded Connecticut Valley, would mean losing contact with family and friends, veterans said. ``This is a lovely place,'' said Pierce, who from her fourth-floor room looks out on a view many hotels would envy, a sea of dark-green pines flecked with the russets of maple as fall foliage season approached. The cuts, part of a $310 million reduction announced by Gov. Michael Dukakis on Sept. 25, set closing dates for the Holyoke home, another Soldiers Home in Chelsea and several Boston shelters, including a place for homeless veterans recognized by President Bush's ``thousand points of light'' program. Since that announcement, state officials said they will keep the homes and shelters open if the Legislature approves alternative cuts. The uncertainty hasn't been good for veterans' peace of mind, said Holyoke Soldiers Home Superintendent Rudolph Chmura. ``You're up high one minute and you're down low. These people are on medical treatment, they don't need that,'' he said. Veterans said they're not asking for a handout. ``I wonder what the thoughts are of a recruiter today ... if he were to tell that (recruit), `I am sorry, but by the time you're 65 you'll have to find your own way, so be careful,''' said 75-year-old John Landers, who lost both legs as a result of injuries he suffered when a tank caught fire. David Joyce, 80, and a member of the Holyoke home's Board of Trustees who is staying temporarily at the facility for medical treatment, called the closing an ``absolute disgrace'' and said he doubts putting residents in a nursing home will save the state any money. The state has always owned and operated the Holyoke home. Many of its 245 residents would end up in nursing homes, where the state would still be responsible for half of the cost of their care through the Medicaid program. ``My wife's in a nursing home that costs $110 a day. I figure at the end of a year our resources and whatever else we had will be gone, maybe,'' he said. Chelsea veterans were equally dismayed to hear of the closing date, which would displace 450 people, said Paul McNamara, assistant superintendent. Dukakis has said he had no choice but to make the cuts because he has the power to withhold money only from executive agencies. He said he will ask the Legislature, the courts and the constitutional officers to make further cuts in their budgets, which would free $13 million for human service programs, including the $5 million needed to keep the soldiers homes open. State officials denied that veterans are pawns in a political power play. ``It's unfortunately the nature of reality,'' said Dukakis spokesman Steve Crawford. ``Over the last 14 months we've cut $100 million a month from the state budget.'' Meanwhile, the veterans wait. Pierce, her face furrowed by the lines of a century, set her chin resolutely at the thought of leaving the Holyoke home where she has lived for 14 years. Her eyes, magnified by thick glasses, flickered with mischief as she recalled the days of 1917 when she dodged the wrath of a supervisor - ``Lord knows what war she was in before'' - and joked with the British soldiers sent to her field hospital in France. ``I said I'd go wherever necessary with `the boys,''' she said. ``We didn't know whether we'd be bombed or not, but we went just the same.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Officials Say Saddam Replaces Kuwaiti Population
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, ```This phenomenon...' to CORRECT Olmert's title to head of press office sted spokesman; SUBS 10th graf, `He said...' to CLARIFY that Olmert sted Sharon made statement...
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein is moving so many Iraqi citizens into Kuwait that its population might choose to remain under Baghdad's rule even after Saddam removed his troops, Israeli official said Saturday. Iraq has been transferring its citizens into Kuwait steadily since the invasion, the officials said. An Israeli military official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 50 percent of the emirate's population at the moment ``are not Kuwaitis.'' He gave no further details. ``This phenomena certainly exists, and the longer it goes on, the more irreversible the annexation becomes,'' said Yossi Olmert, head of the Government Press Office. The replacement of Kuwaitis by Iraqi citizens has been easy for Iraq because many Kuwaiti citizens were abroad on summer vacations during Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and have not returned to the occupied country, Olmert said. Following the population transfer, Saddam ``may offer, at a certain stage, an arrangement involving elections on the basis of the population existing in Kuwait,'' Olmert said. A similar assessment was made by Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, who as defense minister led Israel in the 1982 invasion of Lebanon. In a recent television interview, Sharon said one-third of Kuwaiti residents have been replaced with ``Iraqis and Palestinians, or Jordanians of Palestinian origin.'' ``So a day can come and Saddam can offer a political solution: I withdraw from Kuwait, you withdraw from the Gulf and Saudi Arabia, and there will be a plebiscite in Kuwait. And we know what this plebiscite would show,'' Sharon said. Olmert said he could not estimate how many Iraqis had been moved in, whether it ``concerned 40, 50 or 60 percent'' of Kuwait's population. There was no independent confirmation of the Israeli claims. Even before the invasion less than half the residents of Kuwait were Kuwaitis. Kuwait's population was estimated at 1.7 to 1.8 million at the time of the Iraqi invasion, including about one million expatriate workers. Of the 800,000 Kuwaitis, about 300,000 are believed still inside the occupied country. The others fled after the invasion, most to Saudi Arabia where the ousted emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, has set up a government-in-exile. The English-language daily Jerusalem Post newspaper, in a Sept. 27 editorial titled ``Palestinizing Kuwait,'' also discussed the issue. ``The Palestinians have expropriated the registration records of the (Kuwaiti) interior ministry and handed them over to the Iraqis,'' it said. Olmert said Kuwait's Interior Ministry, and all its documents, was under Iraqi control. ``Thousands of Palestinians with their families and belongings are being resettled in abandoned homes, and whole neighborhoods are now inhabited exclusively by Iraqis and Palestinians, who carry Kuwaiti identity papers produced with confiscated Kuwaiti equipment,'' the Post said. ``It will not be long before the only genuine Kuwaitis with allegiance to the exiled emir will themselves be living in exile too, if they are living at all.''

DOC.HEAD: Burma Military Rebuffs Calls for Democracy
DOC.TEXT: The ruling military council has rebuffed foreign criticism and announced it will continue martial law in Burma as long as it sees fit. ``It is unacceptable for foreign countries at this delicate and sensitive stage and time of transition to exert unwarranted and unjust pressure on the nation,'' said a government statement, distributed to diplomatic missions Friday and broadcast on state radio. Most Western governments suspended aid to Burma after the military brutally seized power in September 1988. The military has refused to transfer power to a democratic coalition that won elections held in May. Government troops raided the West German, British and U.S. embassies late last month and detained Burmese employees of Western missions. The government on Thursday rejected Frederick Vreeland as the new U.S. ambassador after he criticized Burmese human rights conditions and other policies at his confirmation hearings in Washington. ``Whatever external pressure is exerted, the (ruling council) will continue to shoulder the task that has been set out,'' the government statement said.``Such pressure by a minority of countries can only be detrimental to the interests of these countries.'' ``Should it be deemed necessary, the (ruling council) will continue to exercise martial law until such time that a firm, constitutionally established government has come into being,'' the statement said. The military has said it will make unspecified constitutional changes before stepping down or allowing democratic rule.

DOC.HEAD: Gregarious Goose Likes Life with Humans
DOC.TEXT: Gus, a 4-month-old Canada goose, helps cut the grass, visits the neighbors and sometimes flies after the school bus. ``He's the original party animal,'' says Bill Carson, who adopted Gus from friends who hatched the goose on their water heater. Gus will accompany anyone on a walk to get the newspaper. He helps mow the grass by eating clippings sprayed from the mower and sometimes chases the school bus when his friend Ryan Thigpen, 11, leaves in the morning. Gus flies beside the bus, looking in the window. Carson - fearful the goose will be hit by a car - is trying to break Gus of that habit. Content to live with humans, Gus ignores a large flock of Canada geese living in a small lake in Carson's back yard. He also ignores Dudley, a domestic gray goose who passes the day staring at his reflection in the shiny chrome bumper of Carson's truck. About five months ago, a Doberman pinscher found an egg near the Harpeth River in Franklin, about 20 miles south of Nashville, said Diane Frazier. ``My uncle's dog, Duchess, was playing with the egg in the yard for some time,'' Frazier said. ``My uncle thought it was a baseball.'' Her husband, Mike Frazier, rescued the egg, put it in a paper bag and placed it on the water heater, turning it once a day until Gus hatched. The Fraziers, who live in downtown Franklin, soon decided Gus would be happier in the country and gave him to their friend Carson, who lives in this small town about 10 miles east of Franklin.

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Find Capitol Hill About the Only Game in Town
With AM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: On a day when the doors were closed at the Smithsonian museums and the White House gates were locked, the best show in town on a sunny Saturday was at the Capitol - and it didn't cost a dime. Tourists who normally would have streamed into the National Air and Space Museum to see Charles Lindbergh's Spirit of St. Louis or stood in long lines to ogle the lower reaches of the White House instead found all the action was in Congress, where an unusually bitter budget fight was being waged with President Bush. They piled into elevators and rode to the third floor House and Senate visitor galleries. And then they waited for their chance to be admitted to hear the verbal jousting over the budget crisis that had begun to shut down some segments of the government. The show was worth it. Mouths hung agape in the Senate as Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., exclaimed: ``I'm surprised we have electricity in this room and anybody attending to this chamber so we can stand here and argue about this.'' Sen. Terry Sanford, D-N.C., thought President Bush had gone too far in vetoing a stopgap spending bill that would have postponed the government shutdown for a week. ``It was a childish act, a temper tantrum,'' Sanford declared. People bent forward, craning their necks, as Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky., observed: ``I think everything is closed except this place, and the admission here is free.'' ``They're all here because the other zoo is closed,'' said Rep. Charles Wilson, D-Texas, motioning toward the public galleries in the House. In both the House and Senate, member after member got up to 1) excoriate the president; 2) assail a colleague; and 3) engage in public self-flagellation about governmental ineptitude. ``Vote! Vote! Vote!'' a large number of lawmakers chanted as patience wore thin. It was something akin to the British House of Commons, where roars of approval or disapproval are accepted as common practice. Through the hallways, in the elevators and behind the counters in the snack shops, congressional aides groused about working on Saturday. In the Senate carry-out, visitors opted mostly for coffee and Cokes, eschewing the day's special - New Orleans-style fish and pasta. Outside, tourists leaving the show backtracked along the East Front parking lot to get a fuller view of the majestic Capitol Dome, looming high above the building, magnificently oblivious to the uproar below.

DOC.HEAD: Romania To Fire Industry Managers, End Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: Economics Minister Eugen Dijmarescu said Saturday that the government has decided to fire thousands of managers of Romania's huge, largely failing state-owned industries. He also said most subsidies for consumer goods will be abolished soon to bring their prices in line with real market values. Officials hope that will restore the stocks of state-owned stores, which have been depleted by speculators reselling the goods on the black market at higher prices. Dijmarescu said the government will try to cushion inflationary pressures with measures aimed at increasing productivity, which officials estimate dropped by about 20 percent over the past year. Among the measures will be reorganizing and privatizing most industries on the basis of ``competence and competitiveness,'' he said. That will include firing thousands of managers elected by workers' committees following the December revolution that toppled the Communist dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu. The minister said most of these managers ``act like union representatives'' and do not understand that the government no longer sees itself responsible for providing industry with raw materials and financing their losses. ``Probably 60 to 70 percent of the existing managers will be replaced . . . by a new leadership named on the basis of competence . . . people who will make sure the factories produce more, and enough to pay salaries,'' he said in an interview. Dijmarescu said pending laws would link salaries to output. Once the Romanian currency, the leu, is convertible, ``production will also be stimulated by the competition from foreign firms,'' he said. The government plans to devalue the leu to achieve convertibility, he said. The official exchange rate is 20 leu to the dollar, but the black market rate exceeds 100. In Munich, Germany, the leu is bought at 216 to the dollar. Dijmarescu said while the governing National Salvation Front won the May elections on a platform proposing ``transition through small steps . . . the government is proposing a program of shock therapy, and has been approved by Parliament.'' The government decided last week to halt credit lines to failing industries and to impose special taxes on industrial use of electric energy. It will eliminate energy subsidies to most industries. The measures were designed to assure the more than 23 million Romanians sufficent heating and lighting in the coming winter. Ceausescu, who was executed Dec. 25, allowed factories to keep operating even when power was cut off to homes. The country's economic problems have been aggravated by a reduction in energy imports from the Soviet Union and by Iraq's cutoff of $1.7 billion in debt repayments, which were to be made partially in the form of cheap gasoline. Iraq announced it would not pay the debt after Romania supported U.N. economic sanctions over the invasion of Kuwait. On Saturday, about 400 demonstrators marched through the capital shouting slogans against President Ion Iliescu and demanding the release of what they said were political prisoners. The demonstration was organized by four small opposition parties - the Free Republican Party, the Christian-Democratic Union, the Christian National Democratic Party, and the Independent Peasants Party of Craiova. Nica Leon, a leader of the Free Republicans, said, ``We are expressing our opposition to the abusive arrests and the inhuman conditions suffered in prison by those who opposed Iliescu.'' Iliescu and his National Salvation Front came to power after the revolution and were confirmed in the May elections. The government has used force to break up some demonstrations since then.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed In Hot-Air Ballon Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with cause of accident. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A hot-air balloon with seven people aboard crashed on Saturday after the burner failed, killing four people and seriously injuring three, the Civil Aviation Bureau said. The accident occurred in clear weather in a wooded area near Bad Pirawarth, about 30 miles northeast of Vienna. Officials said the balloon lost altitude as a result of the burner failure, whose cause wasn't known. The gondola grazed treetops and then flipped over and fell onto a road. It was Austria's worst ballooning accident. In July 1968, three people died when a balloon hit Vienna's Danube Tower and was slit open.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Navy To Temporarily Stop Killing Squirrels
DOC.TEXT: An animal rights group has won a court order against a Navy program to kill squirrels at a weapons station. The group claims the chemical bait used also threatens endangered species. U.S. District Judge Thelton Henderson on Friday granted a temporary restraining order to the Contra Costa County chapter of In Defense of Animals. The group sued the Navy in federal court, contending a squirrel control program was started at the Concord Naval Weapons Station without an environmental impact report. Contra Costa County paid for half the poisoned grain but was not named in the lawsuit. The county has sponsored an eradication program for years that has not been challenged in court. The Navy began the eradication program Monday because neighbors of the base complained squirrels were damaging property and buildings and because the animals burrowed into ammunition bunkers, said Assistant U.S. Attorney James Coda, respresenting the Navy. About five tons of oats containing the anticoagulant chlorophacinone were spread over 800 acres of the Navy's 12,900-acre station north of Concord before the ban was imposed. The animal rights group claims the poison threatens endangered species that live in in the area east of San Francisco Bay, such as the San Joaquin kit fox and salt harvest mouse. Predatory birds such as owls and golden eagles also could die after eating the poisoned squirrels, said Maryanne Britten, an attorney for the group. The temporary ban lasts until Oct. 22, when Henderson will hold another hearing to decide whether to extend it. In Defense of Animals also contend the program is cruel because the poison causes the California ground squirrels to bleed internally and die slowly, said spokeswoman Jean Bonadio. Henderson ordered the group to raise a $10,000 bond by early next week as a condition of granting the temporary stay. The bond would cover the Navy's losses if the animals rights group fails to win its case. The Navy paid Contra Costa County $10,000 for the poisoned grain. Since last May, the county has sold the bait to landowners at a 50 percent price discount. Before that, it provided the poisoned grain for free, but began sharing the cost because of increased requests. John Defremery, the county's agricultural commissioner, said about 35 tons of poisoned oats have been used on about 35,000 acres of county rangeland this year.

DOC.HEAD: Package Bomb Kills Woman in Turkey
DOC.TEXT: A retired professor of religious affairs known for her secular views was killed Saturday by a mail bomb at her home, state television reported. Police said the package exploded when Bahriye Ucok, 71, opened it. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the bombing. Turkey is a predominantly Moslem country with secular laws, but a Moslem fundamentalist movement has been growing lately.

DOC.HEAD: Ulysses Controllers Thrilled by Launch of Solar Satellite
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: European and NASA officials exuded joy Saturday after the shuttle Discovery launched the Ulysses probe they control from California on ``a great adventure'' to explore the sun's poles. ``I've never enjoyed an experience like I've enjoyed this one. ... Never have I known you could feel so good for so long,'' said Willis Meeks, Ulysses project manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Derek Eaton, Ulysses project manager for the European Space Agency, declared: ``Welcome to sunny California. It's a sunny day for me today.'' Discovery lifted off from Cape Canaveral, Fla., Saturday morning. Six hours later, Ulysses was deployed from the shuttle's cargo bay. In the next 83 minutes, three rocket stages boosted Ulysses out of Earth orbit, starting it on a roundabout, five-year mission to explore the sun's polar regions at a cost of $750 million. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Deep Space Network tracking station in Canberra, Australia, picked up Ulysses' signal at 12:18 p.m. PDT. The spacecraft seemed to be ``in perfect working order,'' Eaton said. Ulysses is a joint project of NASA and ESA. The Europeans will control Ulysses from the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, while NASA officials will provide tracking and other ground support. Ulysses' voyage will take it past Jupiter in February 1992, when it will use that planet as a ``gravity slingshot'' to become the first spacecraft to fly a path perpendicular to the plane in which the planets orbit the sun. That will allow Ulysses to pass over the sun's south polar regions during May-September 1994 and over the north polar latitudes during May-September 1995. ``This is a great adventure in virgin territory,'' said Edgar Page, ESA's Ulysses science coordinator. Yet Ulysses will never get closer to the sun than when it was launched from the shuttle. At its closest approach, Ulysses will be 120 million miles from the sun. Earth is 93 million miles from the sun. Page said there is no need for Ulysses to get any closer to achieve its goal of studying the sun's high latitudes. To send the spacecraft closer would have raised difficult design problems since Ulysses would have to withstand intense solar heat but also survive deep cold near Jupiter. Because no spacecraft ever has studied the sun's high latitudes, ``our present understanding of the sun could be compared to trying to make a map of the Earth by flying an airplane around the equator,'' ESA said in a news release. Ulysses carries nine scientific instruments, and its radio will conduct two other studies. The experiments will study solar wind, cosmic rays and dust, gamma rays, X-rays, solar magnetic fields and a vast array of energetic particles spewed by the sun. ESA said: ``There is no body in heaven as important to us as the sun. Even a tiny change in its health could cause an ice age or could melt the ice caps, flooding the coasts of the world. ... Variations in solar cycles have had an impact on the radical climate changes seen in the past.'' Willy Brado, ESA's assistant director for operations, said Saturday's launch will help restore the confidence of European governments in manned space flights for deploying scientific spacecraft. ``If this had failed, it would have had repercussions at ESA,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Mission Ambushed in Somalia; One Killed, Three Missing
DOC.TEXT: Armed men ambushed four Red Cross workers on a relief mission in northern Somalia on Saturday, the International Committee of the Red Cross said. It said one worker was killed and the three others are missing. The all-Swiss ICRC said Swiss Red Cross delegate Peter Altwegg was taken to the town of Hargeisa, mortally wounded, and died there. It said it had no word on what happened to another Swiss citizen, Antonella Notari, or to two members of the Somalian Red Cross, Sahra Ahmed Jama, president of the Hargeisa branch, and Hassan Arab. There was no word on who attacked the group. The rebel Somalia National Movement has been fighting in the area since 1988 against the government of Somaila. Plain banditry is also a problem in the Horn of Africa country. The ICRC said both government and rebel representatives had been told of the relief mission and agreed to it. The relief workers were ambushed about 18 miles from Hargeisa, it said.

DOC.HEAD: University Of District Of Columbia Students End Protest
DOC.TEXT: Students at the University of the District of Columbia Saturday relinquished control of an administrative building and ended a 10-day protest after school officials agreed to most of their demands. Following several all-day negotiation sessions, the board agreed to 35 of 44 demands, including amnesty for the activists, student leader Mark Thompson said. The students took over a campus services building on Sept. 26 to press their demands for improvements in academic and athletic programs and the resignation of the 11 members of the 15-member board of trustees appointed by Washington Mayor Marion Barry. As many as 500 students occupied the building during the protest, which forced cancellation of classes for several days on the northwest Washington campus. Thompson said students compromised on the final demand that the 11 trustees resign. The trustees had said their resignation would create confusion at the campus of 12,000 and do more harm than good. A city council committee is expected to consider a bill that would increase board membership to 21 including two students. Barry, who earlier abandoned negotiations with the students because of the lack of progress, told a gathering of students and school and city officials Saturday that all sides would benefit from the strike. ``This is a historic and proud moment in the history of UDC. UDC is and will become an even a greater university because of what our students did and what they did and stood for,'' said the mayor. Both trustees and students pledged they would continue to try to improve student services and provide a better education at the city-subsidized institution. The pact does not include any immediate changes. Committees of students and administrators are to be set up to examine such issues as constructing a student union and creating a computerized music library.

DOC.HEAD: `20-20' Admits `Buckwheat' Was an Impostor
DOC.TEXT: The executive producer of ABC's ``20-20'' acknowledged Saturday that the television show was duped by an impostor claiming to be Buckwheat from the classic ``Our Gang'' comedies. William ``Billy'' Thomas, the actor who played Buckwheat, died nearly a decade ago. On ``20-20'' Friday night, Hugh Downs narrated a segment in which the series claimed to have found Buckwheat working as a grocery bagger in Tempe, Ariz. The impostor, Bill English, said he had changed his last name from Thomas and refused to sign autographs because it would interfere with his work. ``20-20'' spokeswoman Maurie Perl said Saturday that Thomas' obituaries proved English was a fake and the show would apologize during its next broadcast Friday. ``(Executive producer Victor Neufeld) feels indeed there was a lapse in the research done by the production team and we may very well have made a mistake,'' Ms. Perl said. ``Obviously we are upset and dismayed with the mistake.'' Thomas' friends and family said they were angry the impostor received a national television audience. Thomas died Oct. 10, 1980, of a heart attack at age 49, said his son, William Thomas Jr. of Covina, Calif. The elder Thomas appeared in 89 ``Our Gang'' films, starting in 1934 - when he was 3 years old - until the series ended in 1944. ``I just can't believe `20-20' didn't investigate this better. I'm somewhat dumbfounded by the whole thing,'' Bill Thomas said Saturday. ``We did not mean to cause any pain or unpleasantness for any of Buckwheat's family or friends,'' Ms. Perl said. ``With regard to the production team, obviously they will be reprimanded and that will be handled internally.'' Thomas, who runs Buckwheat Enterprises and makes a living licensing the character, said impostors threaten his business. He has filed several lawsuits to protect the name. George McFarland, 62, the child star who played Buckwheat's sidekick Spanky, said he spoke Saturday with Neufeld and the producer ``was terribly concerned about what had happened.'' McFarland, who lives in Fort Worth, said he too has been dogged by impostors. Richard W. Bann, who co-wrote the 1976 book ``Our Gang, the Life and Times of the Little Rascals,'' with Leonard Maltin, said the error hurt the ABC news magazine show's credibility. ``What kind of research is this? You would think that at this level of investigative reporting, you would catch something like this,'' he said from his Los Angeles home. ``It sort of undermines anything you'll ever see on that show again. And next week, they'll find Elvis.'' A Tempe viewer suggested the profile, said Ms. Perl. ``I don't believe in the 12 years of the broadcast we have ever had such a problem and we will without question tighten all research and review processes,'' she said. The ``Our Gang'' series, which included 221 short films and one of feature length, began in 1922 with the dual billing: ``Hal Roach presents his Rascals in their latest Our Gang comedy titled ...'' The term ``Little'' was added to ``Rascals'' when the films were broadcast on television beginning in 1955. The series starred several child actors, including Robert Blake and Jackie Cooper. The kids had a pit bull named ``Pete the Pup'' with a circle painted around one eye. A year to the day after Thomas died, Eddie Murphy began his parody of an adult Buckwheat on NBC's ``Saturday Night.''

DOC.HEAD: First Snow in Rockies; Northeast Basks in Summery Weather
DOC.TEXT: The first snow of the season fell in the Rockies Saturday, while a cold front moving across the Plains into the northern Midwest brought summerlike conditions to the Northeast. As much as 7 inches of snow had accumulated Saturday morning in the northern and western mountains of Wyoming, and snow was scattered over the mountains of western Montana and northern Idaho. In the northern Black Hills in South Dakota, 3 to 6 inches of snow was expected to accumulate overnight. Snow over the Black Hills on Saturday morning changed to scattered showers. Advisories were posted for freezing temperatures Saturday night over North Dakota, western and northern South Dakota, Minnesota and Upper Michigan. Freezing temperatures also were expected Sunday morning in western Idaho. Temperatures dipped into the low 20s in parts of Colorado, Idaho, Wyoming and Montana. Winds up to 35 mph buffeted parts of the California deserts, and winds gusted to 45 mph in the southeast highlands of Idaho. Rain and occasional thunderstorms ranged along the Gulf Coast from Texas to Florida. The cold front moving into the northern Midwest created high pressure in the Mid-Atlantic region, and the Northeast basked in temperatures reaching into the mid-80s. Hartford, Conn., recorded 86 degrees in the early afternoon, tying its high for the date set in 1959. Boston reached 86 degrees, tying a record high for the date set in 1946. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 22 degrees at Gunnison, Colo., and Kalispell, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 31 degrees at both Gillette, Wyo., and Livingston, Mont., to 98 degrees at Harlingen, Texas. Hurricane Klaus weakened to a tropical storm on Saturday and drifted into the open waters of the Atlantic. The Caribbean island of Martinique was by far the hardest hit by the storm. Heavy rain since Tuesday spawned landslides and serious flooding that left at least six people dead and 1,500 homeless.

DOC.HEAD: Church President Still Listed in Serious Condition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to CORRECT condition to serious sted critical.
DOC.TEXT: Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson remained in serious but stable condition Saturday as the church's faithful met for their 160th semi-annual General Conference. An LDS Hospital nursing supervisor said the condition of the leader of the 7.5 million-member Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints was unchanged. Benson underwent surgery last month to remove blood clots from his brain and from gastrointestinal bleeding discovered last week. He was hospitalized Sept. 18 after complaining of severe headaches and difficulty swallowing. The 91-year-old Benson's condition had been upgraded to fair and he was moved out of the intensive care unit and into a hospital room Sept. 28, but he was moved back into intensive care two days later when doctors discovered gastrointestinal bleeding. This weekend, thousands of church members from throughout the world met in the Tabernacle on Salt Lake City's historic Temple Square for the two-day conference.

DOC.HEAD: Briton Sees No Coordination Problems Between British Troops, U.S. Marines
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A senior British official said Saturday he foresaw no problems of coordination between U.S. Marines and a British armored unit soon to be placed under the Marines' operational control. ``We wouldn't anticipate any great trouble there,'' Armed Forces Minister Archibald Hamilton told a news conference. Compatible equipment, including communications gear, is ``one advantage of working with our NATO allies,'' he said. Britain's 7th Armored Brigade, with about 7,000 troops and 120 advanced Challenger tanks, is being shifted from its base in Germany in the biggest movement of British armored forces since World War II. The unit is named the Desert Rats for its legacy of battle in North Africa. Hamilton, the second-ranking official in the British Defense Ministry, said he expected the brigade to be in place by early November, alongside U.S. Marine units that have been in the country for six weeks. U.S. officials here have refused to comment on the arrangement. Hamilton said the combining of the two forces has been proposed by American commanders, who were ``very glad when they heard the 7th Armored Brigade was coming.'' ``In fact, they said they would like to see 7th Brigade enhancing the capability of the Marines, and that's where we seem to fit in most neatly.'' The Challenger tanks, equipped with 120mm guns and what British experts claim is the world's best armor, are more modern than the Marines' M-60 tanks. ``It is certainly up to anything that the Iraqis can field. It is superior to anything the Iraqis have,'' Hamilton said. He acknowledged the Challenger had been plagued with difficulties but said there was no basis for reports that they would be used only as ``static artillery'' to support Marine operations. The current British deployment, which includes aircraft, warships and 5,000 personnel, is costing a million pounds ($1.91 million) a day and that will double when the armored brigade arrives, Hamilton said. He said there was ``an argument'' between the Defense Ministry and the British Treasury on how the costs are to be covered, but discussions were under way toward getting the Saudi government to underwrite some of the cost, as it has done with the U.S. forces.

DOC.HEAD: Panic Ends As Gasoline Regulation Starts
DOC.TEXT: Authorities began a form of gasoline rationing on Saturday to deal with dwindling supplies of Soviet oil as winter approaches. The new regulations, which took effect at midnight Friday, limit drivers to 25 liters, or about six gallons, of gasoline in October at the official price of about $3 a gallon. Any amount above the limit carries about a $1 surcharge per gallon. New limits for November were to be announced later. For three days before the rationing went into effect, drivers overwhelmed filling stations, trying to buy as much gasoline as possible. Some slept in their cars overnight waiting for the stations to open. Panic buying started Wednesday night after announcements that Czechoslovak leaders were seeking urgent talks with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov about Soviet oil supplies. The price of gasoline already increased by 50 percent in July because of dwindling supplies from the Soviet Union. The Soviet Union, for years the main supplier of subsidized oil to Czechoslovakia and its East European neighbors, has been unable to fulfill quotas. It will begin demanding convertible currency for the oil starting next year. Many of the countries in Eastern Europe also have lost supplies of Iraqi oil beccause of their support for the U.N. sanctions against Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Their fragile economies are facing much higher prices on the world market. Economics Minister Vladimir Dlouhy estimated last week that Czechoslovakia would lose about $1.4 billion in extra fuel costs as a result of the gulf crisis. Soviet authorities said earlier they would reduce oil allotments for Czechoslovakia, originally set at 16.6 million tons for 1990, by an estimated 2.6 million. But Czechoslovak authorities say the cuts are even greater.

DOC.HEAD: Researcher: Many Lockerbie Victims May Have Lived Until Impact
DOC.TEXT: The pilot and at least 147 other victims of the Lockerbie disaster may have survived the bomb blast that ripped the plane apart at 31,000 feet and died when they hit the ground, a forensic pathologist said. ``And there's a good possibility they were conscious,'' said Dr. William G. Eckert, director of the Milton Helpern International Center of Forensic Sciences at Wichita State University. Eckert has performed thousands of autopsies and consulted on hundreds of cases involving medical-legal issues. Pan Am Flight 103 was ripped apart by a bomb on Dec. 21, 1988, over southern Scotland. Whether any of the 259 victims survived the fall to the ground could be a crucial point in lawsuits seeking payment for the victims' pain and suffering. Eckert said the 148 Lockerbie victims who landed on or near Tundergoth Hill may have lost consciousness because of lack of oxygen when the Boeing 747 exploded but would have revived at about 15,000 to 10,000 feet. He said the victims would have been aware of what was happening for the final third of their 36-second fall. Eckert said testimony Thursday at a public inquiry in Dumfries, Scotland, supported his opinions. A rescuer said she found a young woman who had a weak but regular pulse shortly after the bodies rained from the sky. In a memo to Scottish police investigator John Orr, Eckert said several of the passengers apparently had prepared for their deaths. Some clutched crosses or crucifixes and one woman held her baby tight. A woman aboard a Yugoslavian airliner that collided with a British jetliner in 1976 survived a 38,000-foot fall, Eckert said. German plots during World War II who crashed and died at the controls of their planes suffered injuries similar to those inflicted on the flight's pilot, he said. ``There was a mark on the thumb of the right hand of the pilot that suggests the pilot was holding the yoke of the plane on impact and was alive and holding on for dear life,'' Eckert said. Eckert's comments came in a Friday interview, the memo he wrote to Orr and an article he wrote for the American Journal of Forensic Medicine and Pathology, the professional journal of the National Association of Medical Examiners. The report was published in the quarterly's fall issue. Eckert toured the crash site and investigation centers about five months after the crash. He wrote the confidential memo to Orr shortly after the visit and gave a copy Friday to The Associated Press. Eckert viewed the five main areas where bodies and debris fell, saw some bodies and talked to pathologists. Autopsy records and remains could help determine who survived the blast, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Red Army Troops Sell Their Weapons In East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Red Army soldiers stationed in what was East Germany before last week are pilfering their arsenals and selling everything from assault rifles to small rockets, a newspaper reported Sunday. German officials are worried the weapons might end up in the hands of terrorists, Welt am Sonntag reported. Federal officials report that Soviet soldiers are selling AK-47 assault rifles, ground-to-air rockets, mines, hand-held weapons and anti-tank weapons. The AK-47s are said to be selling for the equivalent of $227, the newspaper reported. Bernd Wilz, a lawmaker with Chancellor Helmut Kohl's governing coalition, urged that a group be set up to investigate the sales. ``The Soviet Union cannot have an interest in seeing its weapons flooding the black market in Germany,'' Wilz was quoted as saying. The 370,000 soldiers based in what was East Germany are to be returned home over the next four years under a Soviet-German agreement. Many of the soldiers, who have lived relatively well in East Germany, are said to be worried they will not have jobs or housing when they return home.

Elections Provoke Power Struggle In Iran

DOC.TEXT: Elections for the body that picks Iran's spirital leader are threatening to aggravate a simmering feud between President Hashemi Rafsanjani's government and his radical rivals. The hard-liners accuse the current spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, of backing Rafsanjani and rigging the elections to exclude radical candidates from the 83-member Assembly of Experts. They say Monday's popular vote must be postponed. The anti-Western radicals have been on the defensive since the death of their revolutionary patriarch, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, in June 1989. They fear a purge by Rafsanjani, who has tried to mend bridges with the West after more than a decade of hostility. They suffered a further blow last week when Tehran resumed relations with Britain after an 18-month break. Radical leaders believe such ties will dilute Khomeini's zealous 1979 revolution, which overthrew the pro-Western Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi and replaced him with the Islamic Republic. The tug-of-war between the two factions, though officially denied, has never been far from the public eye. But it also has never been as public as it has recently. Fistfights erupted in the radical-dominated Parliament, or Majlis, during a debate on the issue last week, sources in Tehran said on condition of anonymity. The government radio, broadcasting the heated debate live, abruptly went off the air when the fighting started, the sources said. The radicals reportedly threatened to stage protest rallies in Tehran on Monday. Diplomatic sources in Tehran said Saturday the situation was ``tense.'' Jolted by a warning from Khamenei against allowing the feud to boil over, Tehran radio said ``hundreds'' of radical organizations and personalities had pledged their support for the government. The Revolutionary Guards, Iran's main fighting force which is believed dominated by radical sympathizers, warned hard-liners not to widen the divisions inside the Tehran hierarchy. But the Mujahedeen Khalq, an opposition group based in Iraq, said in a statement Saturday that many of the Revolutionary Guards, who maintain law and order, are themselves against the elections because their ideological allies have been dumped. The radicals, angered by Khamenei's support for Rafsanjani in his campaign to ease the government's hold on the economy and move closer to the West, have aimed their criticism at him. Led by former interior minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, the hard-liners have accused Khamenei of lacking the qualifications for leadership. Khamenei, 51, a middle-ranking cleric, was overwelmingly chosen by the Assembly of Experts to replace Khomeini. Overnight, he was promoted to Ayatollah, the highest clerical rank in the Shiite Moslem hierarchy. But sources in Tehran said on condition of anonymity that the hard-liners were seeking to win enough seats in the Assembly of Experts to depose Khamenei and replace him with a radical-controlled leadership council. To pre-empt that, Khamenei several weeks ago ordered his allies on the Council of Guardians to pass a new law requiring candidates to sit for an examination before they can run for the assembly. The Council screens parliamentary legislation to ensure it conforms with Islamic principles. Out of 169 candidates who took the exam, 60 failed. Sources said most were radicals, including Parliament Speaker Mehdi Karrubi. Some radicals refused to sit for the examinations. Three hard-liners who did pass later withdrew their names in protest. In a Cabinet meeting Wednesday, Rafsanjani denied any move to sideline his radical opposition, Tehran radio reported. ``There is no such thought either in the mind of the leader, or the Guardian council, nor do others think like this,'' he said. The Mujahedeen statement said that in Wednesday's Parliament session, Sadegh Khalkhali, a vehement radical, attacked the Guardian Council and said, ``If it has been decided that we are to be cast aside, tell us officially.'' He warned: ``We will stand by our words until the very last drop of our blood.''

DOC.HEAD: EC Monetary Officials Approve Britain's Decision on Pound
DOC.TEXT: European finance chiefs on Saturday approved Britain's long-awaited decision to enter the pound into their exchange rate linkage, giving a fresh push to efforts to unite their nations' economies. The finance officials said Britain's surprise move marked ``a significant advance'' in forging closer economic and monetary links among the 12 nations of the European Community trading bloc. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher sharply reversed long-standing economic policy to let the pound join the system, which is heavily influenced by the strong German mark. She so far has resisted radical plans that would quickly lead to a common currency and a central bank for the community nations. The economic project would give an added dimension to the trading bloc's campaign to tear down by the end of 1992 the many trade barriers preventing the free flow of people, money, goods and services among the nations. It will create a vast consumer market of more than 330 million people. The move to add the pound to the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System was unlikely have an impact on the U.S. dollar, which is not part of the arrangement. The exchange rate mechanism seeks to prevent wide shifts in exchange rates of the member nations and keep inflation and interest rates under control. Central banks are required to prevent their currencies from falling outside certain ranges by intervening - buying and selling currencies - in the exchange markets. In a statement, the finance chiefs announced acceptance of Britain's proposal to tie the pound to the mechanism on Monday with a central rate of 2.95 German marks. It will be allowed to swing 6 percent above or below that figure for an unspecified ``transitional period,'' said the statement. The Spanish peseta, the last currency to join the system in June 1989, also swings in a 6 percent range. All the other currencies move in a narrower band of 2.25 percent. Last January, the Italian government narrowed the range for the lira from 6 percent to 2.25 percent. With the pound's addition, the currencies of 10 community nations - Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Spain - will be linked in the exchange rate mechanism. Only the currencies of Portugal and Greece remain outside the link. Carlos Tavares, secretary of state at the Portuguese Treasury, predicted his country's escudo would be the next to join, sometime before 1993. In their statement, the finance ministers and central bank governors said they considered the British move ``a strengthened commitment by the British authorities to pursue a firm anti-inflationary policy.'' Mrs. Thatcher had said she would not allow the pound to join the linkage until Britain's inflation rate dropped closer to the European average of about 5 percent. After Friday's announcement, she said she made her decision because the country's double-digit inflation rate was on the verge of falling. Being part of the arrangement, she said, ``would underpin our anti-inflationary stance.'' The currency linkage is the first stage of a three-part plan for creating an economic and monetary union. In later stages a single currency and a European-wide central bank would be created, modeled after the U.S. Federal Reserve. Britain recently has gained support for its go-slow approach to monetary union because of worries about the economic impact of the Persian Gulf crisis. The surge in oil prices and inflation could make it harder to merge the different economies. Even so, the community will open a special conference in mid-December to make changes in its founding treaty so new economic agencies can be set up.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Shutdown Disappoints Yosemite Campers
With AM-Government Shutdown, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: There aren't many happy campers in Yosemite National Park this weekend. On a beautiful, Indian summer afternoon Saturday, with the leaves turning color and the meadows filled with vacationers, the news that all campsites would be shut down triggered anger and disappointment. Some blamed Congress, some President Bush. But none of the 7,000 campers liked it when National Park Service officials told them they had to clear out by 1 p.m. Sunday because of the budget crisis in Washington. Bush has ordered non-essential federal government agencies across the nation closed in the absence of a budget agreement. ``I think it's horrible,'' said Becky Vaccarezza of Stockton, who months ago made reservations for a weeklong vacation with five other adults and six children. ``When you're at home you deal with the bills and everything. But when you come up here, this is everybody's escape. This is how you're supposed to get away from budgets,'' she said. ``It's a major disappointment. We had so many plans for the kids.'' This was to be the last big weekend of the year at Yosemite - the final days of its centennial celebration - before rangers start preparing the campgrounds for winter. Instead of relaxing and enjoying the magnificent views of Half Dome and El Capitan, many visitors worried about packing up Sunday morning and finding somewhere to stay. The Ahwahnee Hotel, Yosemite Lodge and other facilities operated by the Curry Co. will remain open, as will the visitors center with a reduced staff. But the park service canceled nature walks Saturday, sent interpretive rangers home and closed the centennial exhibit and Indian cultural museum in this park east of San Francisco near the Nevada state line. Yosemite superintendent Michael Finley said Interior Department officials in Washington told him to curtail all operations except emergency services. ``There's no authority for me to spend money,'' Finley said. ``The irony of it is that the shutdown is very expensive.'' Seasonal workers let go would have helped the National Park Service rangers prepare Yosemite for winter, he said, adding that it would cost more money in the long run to have rangers do that work alone. Yosemite evacuated 15,000 visitors this summer because of fires, but this was the first time people have been told to go home because the U.S. government had run out of money. ``This is a real letdown,'' said Tom Figlio, on vacation from his home in New Jersey. ``I always wanted to see Yosemite. It's very discouraging.''
