DOC.TEXT: The United Nations, fearing the Persian Gulf crisis might last through the winter, announced Saturday it will stockpile food for another 120,000 refugees from Iraq and Kuwait and buy winter tents for those stranded in camps. Saudi Arabia recalled its ambassador to Jordan, diplomatic sources said, in another reflection of souring relations between the Arab neighbors since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Saudi Arabia, which requested a U.S.-led multinational force to help defend it after the Iraqi invasion, expelled Jordanian diplomats and cut oil and aid to Jordan last month because Amman had not strongly protested Iraq's actions. U.S. officials, meanwhile, said the 2-month-old U.S. troop buildup in Saudi Arabia is virtually complete. But the officials in Washington and Saudi Arabia said the U.S. forces still lack the firepower and supplies necessary to launch a successful ground offensive against Iraqi troops in Kuwait. Britain's armed forces minister, Archibald Hamilton, said in Dharhran, Saudi Arabia, he expected Britain's 7th Armored Brigade, with about 7,000 troops and 120 Challenger tanks, to be in place in the Saudi desert by early November, alongside U.S. Marine uits already there. The unit won fame as the Desert Rats during World War II North African campaigns. Also Saturday, Italy's remaining two diplomats abandoned its diplomatic mission in Kuwait and half of Britain's delegation left the emirate after Iraq cut supplies and power to the compounds. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein reportedly assured a top Soviet diplomat that Soviets in Iraq may leave the country soon. The official Soviet news agency Tass reported the assurance, which it said was made by Saddam to Kremlin envoy Yevgeny Primakov. Primakov left Baghdad Saturday after talking with Saddam and delivering a message from President Mikhail Gorbachev. About 5,000 Soviets have been prevented from leaving Iraq since the invasion, although they are not among the Westerners being held as ``guests'' at hotels and strategic sites in an Iraqi effort to deter Western attack. Hundreds of thousands of foreigners have fled Iraq and Kuwait since the invasion, and U.N. and Jordanian officials fear 80,000 more refugees may arrive in Jordan this week. In Amman, U.N. Undersecretary-General Mohammad Essaafi said the U.N.'s disaster relief agency and Jordanian authorities are preparing food stockpiles to feed 120,000 more people. Essaafi said the agency also is buying 7,600 winter tents to replace the summer tents now set up in refugee camps around the country. ``If there's a worsening of the situation in Iraq and Kuwait, we might expect an increased flow of evacuees, particularly Egyptian nationals, who might cross in very large numbers,'' he added. Some 422,400 refugees, mainly Egyptian and Asians, have been flown out of Jordan in more than 1,798 flights by military and civilian aircraft since Aug. 5, Jordanian civil aviation officials said. Another 60,000 have been flown home from Turkey and hundreds of thousands, mainly Egyptians, have been taken home by sea. In other developments: -Iraqi radio, monitored in Britain, said Iran and Iraq would hold talks this week on reopening embassies in Tehran and Baghdad. An Iraqi delegation will arrive in Iran Tuesday. The two nations fought a war from 1980-88. Baghdad now seeks to persuade Iran to help it skirt U.N. economic sanctions on Iraq. -Jordan announced an energy rationing program, effective next Saturday, due to Saudi Arabia's recent cutoff of oil supplies. -Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat arrived in Amman from Baghdad on Saturday, proposing a U.N.-sponsored solution to the crisis and other regional conflicts. -British warships stopped and searched two Indian ships carrying more than 2,000 Indians from Iraq, then cleared their travel to the United Arab Emirates. The refugee ships were to arrive Sunday. -Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu met with Saudi King Fahd and affirmed Japanese support for Saudi Arabia in the gulf crisis. -Kuwait's crown prince, Sheik Saad, said the emirate's exiled rulers have invited 450 prominent Kuwaitis to Saudi Arabia discuss a new type of government if and when Iraq pulls out of Kuwait. -An Egyptian state newspaper said authorities have arrested 30 Arabs - 23 Palestinians and seven Iraqis - sent by Iraq to attack city squares, tourist attractions and other targets to create disorder. -The British Foreign Office said a 46-year-old Scottish man has died in Kuwait after suffering an undisclosed illness. William Norrie Atack, a scientist, had worked in Kuwait for eight years as a scientific officer at the Ministry of Public Health, his family said.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistani Clerics Say Heaven Closed to Bhutto Supporters
DOC.TEXT: From the pulpits of Islamic mosques, clerics are warning that the gates of heaven will be closed to those who vote for ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's party in Oct. 24 parliamentary elections. Abdul Qadir told hundreds of faithful attending prayers on Friday, the Moslem sabbath, that unless they abandoned Ms. Bhutto's party their spiritual fate would be sealed. ``Anyone who supports the Pakistan People's Party will not enter heaven,'' he said at Badshahi Mosque in Lahore. Pakistan's powerful religious right has criticized Ms. Bhutto since she became the first woman to rule a modern Moslem nation in 1988. She has been accused of being an infidel or non-believer, slammed for her Western education and ridiculed for cultivating an Islamic image by always wearing voluminous shawls and a headscarve. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan used his constitutional authority to dismiss the 37-year-old Ms. Bhutto on Aug. 6, 20 months after she took office. She, her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, and several former Cabinet ministers have been charged before special one-judge tribunals with corruption and abuse of power. Ms. Bhutto's supporters say they are victims of political persecution. Ms. Bhutto's father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was driven out of power in 1977 and tried before similar courts. Bhutto was executed in 1979. Because of the strong emotions on both sides, many fear the Oct. 24 election could be the most violent in the country's 43-year history. In the latest accusation against an official of Ms. Bhutto's government, former railways minister Farooq Ahmed Leghari has been charged with murder, according to news reports Saturday. A one-paragraph news item distributed by the state-run news agency said he was charged in connection with the death of a relative in the village of Dera Ismail Khan, 180 miles south of Islamabad. It gave few details and Leghari could not be immediately reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Veto Upheld in House
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS graf 13, ``Both the xxx to update with both houses adjourning for night, scheduling Sunday sessions, and Bush to Camp David; INSERTS 2nd and 3rd grafs from end, ``Some GOP xxx to include letter to Bush registering upset with Sununu, Darman
DOC.TEXT: President Bush successfully vetoed legislation Saturday to restore the government's ability to spend money and presided over the gradual shutdown of non-essential services in a confrontation spawned by deadlock over the federal deficit. Negotiators from the White House and Congress resumed negotiations on a package of spending cuts and tax increases that could win approval and end the impasse - but not before Sunday night at the earliest. But in the meantime, the president said he would no longer abide ``business as usual'' by the Democratic-controlled Congress. He vetoed a bill that would have permitted the government to operate normally for another week, and a few hours later, the House failed to override the veto. The 260-138 vote override was six short of the two-thirds majority required. On the vote, 235 Democrats and 25 Republicans voted to overturn Bush's veto and nine Democrats and 129 Republicans voted to uphold it. ``Responsible congressional action to reduce the deficit can be delayed no longer,'' Bush said in his veto message. Democrats denounced the president's decision. ``Unnecessary, unjustified and harmful,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. But under the eyes of tourists packing the visitors' galleries because many federal tourist attractions in town were closed, the House mustered only the 260 votes to override, well short of the two-thirds vote needed. Reflecting the importance of the budget fight and lawmakers' recent spate of long hours, the debate was unusually acrimonious. ``Mr. Speaker, there are snakes loose in the chamber,'' shouted Rep. Robert Dornan, R-Calif., after Democrats hissed during the reading of Bush's veto message. But Republicans were hissing moments later after Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., said Bush's veto resulted in ``treating 2 million federal workers like Saddam Hussein treats his so-called guests in Iraq.'' Feelings ran so high that angry conservative Republicans blocked an effort by leaders of both parties to recess the House for two hours so lawmakers could have dinner while budget negotiators tried to work out a compromise. At the White House, spokesman Roman Popadiuk said: ``We are pleased that the House has sustained the veto. It is now time for the House to get on with dealing with the budget.'' Both the House and Senate adjourned for the evening after the House vote, which made any Senate override action moot, but scheduled Sunday afternoon sessions to be available to consider any new budget proposals. Bush, meanwhile, motored to Camp David for the night. The federal shutdown presumably would increase pressure on the negotiators trying to piece together a plan to replace the five-year, $500 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts that was defeated in the House after midnight Thursday night. House GOP Leader Bob Michel of Illinois said he hoped Congress and the White House could break the gridlock before the end of the three-day Columbus Day weekend, when millions of federal workers face the threat of furloughs. There was no immediate word from congressional leaders on their next move. One possible step was to pass legislation replenishing the government's coffers, but coupled with across-the-board spending cuts mandated by the Gramm-Rudman anti-deficit law. Bush hinted he might accept such a measure, which would give negotiators time to craft a larger deficit-reduction package. The earlier deficit-reduction plan went down in a crescendo of criticism - with Republicans expressing anger over tax hikes and Democrats rebelling over $60 billion in cuts in the Medicare program that pays for health care for the elderly. Bush and the Democratic leaders of Congress had jointly forged that agreement - and the president said he still supported it. But at the same time, his decision to veto the short-term funding bill and proceed with the shutdown of non-essential government services meant a high-stakes political showdown was unfolding with the Democratic majorities of Congress. Asked how long he was willing to keep government doors locked, he replied: ``It's not a question of how long I can take it,'' Bush said. ``It's a question of how long Congress can take it. Congress is where the action is.'' The White House last week estimated the fiscal 1991 budget deficit would be about $294 billion. The budget agreement the House rejected would have cut the deficit $40 billion this year and $500 billion over five years. Bush said he was ``very sorry'' if anyone was inconvenienced by the shutdown, which was felt first at the Washington Monument, Lincoln Memorial, Smithsonian museums and popular sites in the nation's capital. In fact, the early disruptions were minimal, confined largely to government tourist attractions. The full impact of the shutdown of non-essential services was not likely to be felt until after Monday's Columbus Day holiday for federal workers. And the administration said it had the authority to maintain essential services such as the military, air traffic safety control and prison control. Despite his criticism aimed at Congress, Bush seemed to offer the possibility for a fresh compromise on taxes. He refused to dismiss reporters' questions that in return for cuts in the capital gains tax - a 1988 Bush campaign promise - he might accept Democrats' demands for higher income taxes on the wealthy. ``I remain in a flexible frame of mind,'' the president said. Neither item was included in the deficit-reduction package that Bush agreed to last weekend with congressional leaders. The capital gains tax - levied on profits from sales of real estate and other property - is now the same as for other income, with a top 33 percent rate. Bush has proposed slashing that rate to 15 percent, arguing it would spur sales and feed cash into the economy. But Democrats, arguing that most of the tax break would be enjoyed by the wealthy, have insisted that income tax rates on the rich be raised as a tradeoff. Dropping the two tax changes was the last major hurdle the two sides cleared in their four contentious months of negotiations. That plan was soundly rejected by a rebellious House early Friday as majorities of rank-and-file Republicans and Democrats turned on their own party leaders. The stunning 254-179 defeat came despite the most intense lobbying campaign of Bush's presidency, and equally all-out efforts by top lawmakers of both parties. Some GOP representatives still had bitter tastes in their mouths from the White House arm-twisting, accusing Chief of Staff John Sununu and budget director Richard Darman of particularly gruff behavior. ``Your staff did a lot of insensitive and unnecessary things to Republican members,'' Rep. Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa, wrote Saturday in a letter to Bush. ``Bring Millie, but leave the pit dogs at the White House.'' Many lawmakers were alienated by the package's costs to poor and middle-income people, including Medicare cuts and tax hikes on home-heating oil and gasoline.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Week at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here at-a-glance are the developments in the Persian Gulf during the week of Sept. 30 to Oct. 07:
DOC.HEAD: SUNDAY
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein struck a softer note in the Persian Gulf crisis, urging peaceful dialogue instead of ``threats and warnings.'' U.S. and Soviet officials were reported drafting U.N. resolutions to authorize the use of military force against Iraq if an economic squeeze fails to force Iraq out of Kuwait.
DOC.HEAD: MONDAY
DOC.TEXT: President Bush denounced Iraqi Presdent Saddam Hussein as an international outcast who plundered Kuwait. But Bush also offered Baghdad hope that relinquishing its grasp on its Persian Gulf neighbor could spur negotiations for Israeli withdrawal from land once held by the Arabs.
DOC.HEAD: TUESDAY
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has strengthened its forces in southern Iraq and Kuwait and has now deployed nearly half its 1 million-man army to defend the occupied territory, U.S. military sources said. The U.S. military sources in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, said analysts estimate there are well over 400,000 Iraqi troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait, compared to 360,000 a week ago.
DOC.HEAD: WEDNESDAY
DOC.TEXT: A close adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev headed for Iraq on a special Middle East mission. The Soviet news agency Tass announced the departure of Yevgeny Primakov, former head of the leading Soviet think tank on Middle East issues. It is said he would visit Baghdad en route to Amman, Jordan, where he would meet with King Hussein and PLO chairman Yasser Arafat.
DOC.HEAD: THURSDAY
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein made his first known visit to the oil-rich neighbor he conquered two months ago, meeting Iraqi troops and military commanders in occupied Kuwait. The Iraqi News Agency said Saddam toured the streets of Kuwait, which ``appeared flourishing after its return to the mother homeland.'' Kuwait City `` glittered with pride'' at Saddam's visit, said the news agency, monitored in Nicosia.
DOC.HEAD: FRIDAY
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has high-explosive devices that pack the equivalent destructive power of small nuclear bombs, and military officials say the United States has no ready defense against them, the Los Angeles Times reports. The fuel-air explosives create a huge fireball and shock wave over a concentrated area, but without the radiation fallout associated with nuclear weapons, the newspaper says. The explosives have 10 times the power of conventional explosives and could devastate oil fields, air bases and troops, the Times reported.
DOC.HEAD: SATURDAY
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military officials said the buildup on the Arabian peninsula is virtually complete, but American forces still lack the firepower and supplies necessary to launch a successful ground offensive against Iraqi troops in Kuwait. Diplomatic sources said Saudi Arabia recalled its ambassador to Jordan, in another reflection of souring relations between the Arab neighbors.

DOC.HEAD: Participants Share Goal At `Catalyst' Environmental Conference
DOC.TEXT: About 7,000 people - more than twice the number organizers expected - turned out for a three-day conference on improving the environment. Jeremy Hays, co-chairman of the Catalyst environmental conference at the University of Illinois, was delighted and surprised at the response. He welcomed the crowd Friday night with a question: ``Where in the heck did you all come from?'' Most of the participants were college students. They hailed from big cities and small towns in all 50 states and shared a common goal: improving the environment. Organizers said they hoped the conference would help train a new generation of environmental leaders. Adam Spak and his friends came from Kansas City, Mo., with their brightly painted Recycling Bus, a converted school bus used to pick up trash after a curbside recycling bill failed in Kansas City. Spak said he hoped to share details of the program with other activists and to learn from others at the conference how to persuade Kansas City officials to support recycling. Among the speakers Friday night was actor Robert Redford, who said ``we've messed up the air, the land, the water in our passion to control things. ``I'm not a prophet of gloom and doom,'' Redford said. ``But, I've always assumed a love of land and a love of country go together.'' Jim McGuire, a student at the University of Minnesota, said he hoped the conference would bring student activists credibility. The gathering was organized by the Student Environmental Action Coalition. ``There's always statements that students aren't active on issues from the mainstream press,'' said McGuire. ``It's been my sense for quite a while that that's not true. I think this shows that. ``But, what's really going to show it in the long run is action that comes out of this.''

DOC.HEAD: Von Weizsacker: Germany'll Always Remember Holocaust Responsibility
DOC.TEXT: Germany's President Richard von Weizsacker, in a special message to the Israeli people, said Saturday that his country will always remember its responsibility for the Holocaust and the six million Jewish victims. ``Something terrible has been done in the name of the Germans - the gravest and the most terrible crime ever committed, the Holocaust. Its memory lives with us as part of our hope for the future. And I hope that our obligations towards the past and our aspirations towards peace in the future will be understood in Israel too,'' von Weizsacker said. His remarks were carried in an Israel Television broadcast. He said responsibility for the Holocaust would be shared by all in the new Germany. ``As we unite as Germans, something that has been divided is also reuniting, namely: the bearing of responsibility for the results of our history,'' von Weizsacker said. ``I am convinced that the young generation in East Germany, which has now united with us in the West, is aware of the responsibility for the results of history.'' The television said von Weizsacker made the statement in response to a written appeal from Israel's President Chaim Herzog. Israel, founded in 1948 as a Jewish homeland largely in response to Holocaust, accepted Germany's unification with a heavy heart. ``There have been two parts of Germany. One, a democratic state that has accepted the historic responsibility and historic guilt, and has been close to Israel in many fields, and East Germany, which has been hostile towards Israel,'' said Herzog, who also spoke on the television. ``Looking back at the 40 years of experience with West Germany... I hope and I'm almost certain that the statements of President von Weizsacker, and Chancellor (Helmut) Kohl, and all the leadership will guide the united Germany in its relations with Israel,'' Herzog said.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: This is an optional add for members who may desire more detail on the various national parks ^WASHN: to them.
DOC.TEXT: -A busload of tourists from Indiana drove six hours to reach the Great Smoky Mountain National Park, nnly to be turned away by rangers Saturday at Clingman's Dome, the highest point in the park. ``It's really unfair to rub this in the people's face. This is really not helping relations with the public. I would suspect if they wanted to get in the good graces of the people, they would work for free for one day,'' said Bob Davenport, director for the weekend tour arranged by Wandering Wheels tour company from Upland, Ind. At the park visitors center, Eddie Christensen of Napa, Calif., a retired Corps of Engineers employee said: ``I definitely feel like George Bush is doing this to make Congress see his way. I don't see why they should make the people suffer for it. It's politics, no question about it.'' -In Montana, `closed'' signs went up on the gates at the Custer Battlefield National Monument and the National Bison Range, but few other effects of the national budget impasse were immediately visible. Visitors could still enter both places, as well as Glacier and Yellowstone national parks, but few or no services were available. -At Yosemite National Park in California, some 7,000 campers were told they would have to clear out by 1 p.m. Sunday because of the budget crisis. ``I think it's horrible,'' said Becky Vaccarezza of Stockton, who months ago had made reservations for a week-long vacation with five other adults and six children. ``When you're at home you deal with the bills and everything. But when you come up here, this is everybody's escape. This is how you're supposed to get away from budgets. It's a major disappointment. We had so many plans for the kids.'' Yosemite superintendent Michael Finley said he was told by Interior Department officials in Washington not to close the park, but to curtail all operations except emergency services. -Elsewhere in California, the budget crisis also caused a shutdown of other popular venues in California, including Alcatraz, Muir Woods and Stinson Beach in the Golden Gate National Recreation Area in Northern California, and the Joshua Tree and Death Valley national monuments in Southern California. Odette Zwetzig, acting superintendent of Death Valley National Monument, said, ``I've been with the park service for over 15 years. I have seen shutdowns ... (but) I have not seen quite the hullabaloo that is going on with this one. ... I've been around long enough to know that eventually they'll pass a budget. In the meantime ... the (tourists) are very sad. They've come so far and they've made their plans for a vacation and there are no services we can offer.'' -In Michigan, the budget stalemate was having an impact in the deepest woods, where park rangers and naturalists were among victims. Layoffs were reported at the Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore at Munising and at the Sleeping Bear Dunes on Lake Michigan near Empire. That left some tourists on their own Saturday in finding the best places to see the fall color display, which is at its peak in the area. At the Picture Rocks on Lake Superior, the visitor center was open Saturday, but scheduled to close Sunday and Monday said Julie Fosbender, an information assistant for the Munising Ranger District. ``If they want information on the park or a back country camping permit, there won't be anyone around,'' she said. ``Then again, there won't be anyone out there anyway to check and see if they have a permit.'' -In Texas, visitors were turned away from seashores and mountain lodges. At Big Bend National Park in West Texas, spokesman Roy Given had to notify guests on Saturday they were no longer welcome at the remote wilderness park. The park hotel, restaurant and stables will remain open, but Big Bend no longer is offering its guided tours, campground facilities or its back country and river permits. -In Pennsylvania, historic buildings were closed, hikes canceled and guides absent at National Park Service sites across the state. ``We stopped here especially to see the treasures of Philadelphia, and they're closed to us,'' said Dee Gilmore, 67, of Riverside, Calif., who was visiting Independence National Historical Park. ``I think this is a sad way for President Bush to try to get his own way.'' Andrea Vogel, 10, of Washington, D.C., who was traveling with her parents and brother, said, ``We came to see the history of Philadelphia and I don't think it's fair that they should close down the tourist sites. Why would people want to come to Philadelphia anymore?'' -In Washington state, Olympic National Park was shutting down and Mount Rainier National Park was closing all but one small campground. -In Arkansas, five national parks were closed. -In northern Minnesota's Voyageur's National Park, only essential workers were overseeing the park's operation, said Raoul Lufbery, facility manager. One ranger was patrolling the northern district of the park and one in the southern district, Lufbery said. Usually, there are four to five rangers patrolling the park on weekends, he said. The park will remain open, with its trails, campsites and boat launches still available, he said. -In Florida, ticket takers at Everglades National Park were sent home, allowing motorists to drive in free. Inside, most of the privately-run concessions remained open. At the opposite end of the state, Jerry Eubanks, supervisor of the Gulf Islands National Seashore headquartered in Gulf Breeze, said the park that includes barrier islands and mainland recreation areas in the Florida Panhandle and Mississippi will remain open. ``We have looked at alternatives,'' he said. ``We've just refreshed in our own minds what are essential health and safety measures, but we have no plans as of now for shutting down.'' -In Connecticut, the shutdown and wrangling in Washington had little effect on services, but forced the state's congressional leaders to cancel their campaign stops in the state Saturday. For incumbents trying to get in some campaigning in the final stretch before the election in November, losing a chance to campaign at town fairs and parades throughout the state was frustrating. ``I just can't tell you what it's like to know your opponent is out there campaigning and you can't do anything,'' said Republican Rep. Christopher Shays, who faces a challenge from attorney Alfred J. Smith, a Democrat from Darien. -In Iowa, hundreds of visitors were touring the Herbert Hoover Presidential Library and Museum, most buildings on the 186-acre grounds were locked up and National Park Service rangers were off duty, said a clerk at the museum. The library and museum are operated by the National Archives and Records Administration, while the grounds - which include Hoover's grave site, his birthplace cottage and a blacksmith shop - are under the jurisdiction of the National Park Service. ``As to why we're open today and the National Park Service is not, I don't know,'' said Chris Christensen, a sales clerk in the library and museum. -In Nebraska, many federal employees nervously enjoyed their three-day weekend. ``I probably should be worried, but I'm not,'' said Doug Druliner, a hydrologist with the U.S. Geological Survey. ``We've gone through this thing in the past, but there was not as much hype about it. We've had furloughs in the past and been paid later.'' Jim Kula, a service representative with the Social Security Department, agreed. ``But this is the first time they were required to give us a formal 30-day warning that there might be furloughs,'' he added. -In Wyoming, Yellowstone National Park officials began a phased closure of the park. Spokeswoman Joan Anzelmo said that while the park was open on Saturday and would remain open through the long Columbus Day weekend, it was staffed only by emergency and utility personnel. The Old Faithful Inn and four campgrounds were expected to remain open through the weekend, Anzelmo said. ``There is a snowstorm here and we don't want to strand visitors,'' she said. ``Later in the weekend, we may have to start further closures. We hope we don't have to close down ... completely. ... Because Yellowstone is so large and has a large visitor population, we just can't simply shut a gate and walk away.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Considers Adoption of Multiparty System
DOC.TEXT: The People's Assembly opened debate on a new constitution that envisions a multiparty democracy with full freedom of expression, the national news agency reported Saturday. In the document, the ruling FRELIMO party is no longer referred to as the nation's leading force,AIM reported. FRELIMO led the guerrilla war to drive the Portuguese from Mozambique and has been the sole legal party in the southeast African nation since the war ended in 1975. Virtually all members of the People's Assembly, or parliament, belong to FRELIMO and were expected to back the changes, proposed by President Joachim Chissano. Debate began Friday. On July 31, Chissano announced that Mozambique should have a multiparty system in place for parliamentary and presidential elections scheduled for next year. He previously had opposed multiparty democracy, saying it would encourage tribalism and waste the country's scarce resources. Chissano also has promised to end a 13-year-old civil war with the Mozambique National Resistance that has claimed 600,000 lives and left about half the country's 15 million people in need of donated food. The government and the rebels have held a series of peace talks this year. A multiparty system and new election laws are two key demands of the rebels. The FRELIMO party was Marxist, but has undergone reforms in recent years and officially dropped its Marxist label last year. The draft includes provisions allowing freedom of expression, freedom of the press and the right to strike. AIM reported the draft would give the president power to dissolve parliament if it rejected the government program. The Central Committee approved resolutions in August that suggested any new electoral laws should prohibit parties set up along racial, ethnic, regional or religious lines.

DOC.HEAD: Russell Means and Followers Lead Denver's Columbus Day Parade
DOC.TEXT: Organizers of a Columbus Day parade Saturday allowed American Indian Movement leader Russell Means and about 150 supporters to lead the procession to avoid a threatened demonstration. Means, whose backers carried signs denouncing Christopher Columbus as a murderer, called the concession by the city's Federation of Italian-American Organizations ``a historic first.'' ``One of the most beautiful things ... is that they understand that we have a political agenda,'' Means said. ``Because of their belief in the First Amendment, we're more than welcome to lead the parade.'' Means' supporters, who included non-Indians, marched a block ahead of the main parade participants, beating a drum and chanting Indian ceremonial songs. At the reviewing stand, the group waved to the parade organizers, who waved back. Afterward, the group passed around a eremonial pipe at the state Capitol and made plans to rally at the Christopher Columbus statue in Civic Center Park on Monday. Means initially had been denied permission to march in the parade, because he has called Columbus a genocidal killer on a par with Adolf Hitler. Last year, Means was arrested for pouring fake blood over the Columbus statue. But less than an hour before the parade began Saturday, Bill Marinella, chairman of the parade committee, said the Indian activists and their supporters would lead the parade. He said organizers gave in because they feared a disruption of the parade could endanger spectators. Denver's first Columbus Day parade since 1981 was organized in anticipation of the 500th anniversary of Columbus' first voyage to America. The 1992 anniversary is a cause for celebration of Italian-American pride in Columbus, who was born in Genoa, Italy, in 1451 but sailed under the Spanish flag. The American Indian Movement sees the anniversary as a chance to educate Americans about Columbus' involvement in slave trading and the deaths of natives of the lands he discovered. The parade's grand marshal was character actor Vito Scotti, who is featured locally on Cub Foods commercials.

DOC.HEAD: Three Arabs Killed as Collaborators
DOC.TEXT: Three Arabs suspected of helping Israeli authorities or dealing drugs were killed in the occupied lands by fellow Palestinians, according to reports Saturday. Israel radio said the body of 27-year-old Samih Khalil Hamad of Beit Hanoun village in the occupied Gaza Strip was found in an orange grove Saturday. He had been stabbed and beaten to death, Arab reporters said. They said Palestinian activists suspected Hamad of collaboration. On Friday, Mustafa Hasan Abu Okel, 30, was found stabbed to death at his house in Gaza's Jabaliya refugee camp, Arab reports said. Abu Okel was reportedly known as a drug dealer. Before dawn Saturday in Beit Umar, in the occupied West Bank, masked Palestinian enforcers entered the home of Taghrib Abu Ayash, 36, and shot her to death. Arab reports said Mrs. Abu Ayash, a mother of seven, also was suspected of collaboration. The military command confirmed the three deaths, but said Abu Okel's death was apparently a criminal killing. Most of the 280 Palestinians slain by other Arabs in the 34-month uprising against the Israeli occupation were accused of serving as informants for the military authorities. But they include drug dealers and prostitutes, who uprising activists see as corrupting Palestinian morals and as easy prey for Israel's secret services. Israeli soldiers or civilians have killed at least 736 Palestinians during the revolt, which has left 48 Israelis dead. Police spokesman Uzi Sanduri said about 500 people at a protest rally in the village of Isiwiya were dispersed by tear gas. The Palestine Press Services said two youths were wounded by rubber bullets.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Prosecutor Kills Self After Infamous Case
DOC.TEXT: A county prosecutor involved in a murder investigation that apparently led to a witness' death has killed himself, police said. Collier Vale, 39, was found dead in his apartment Friday from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, a police report said. Sgt. Fred Ragghianti said the case remained under investigation. A preliminary coroner's report indicated no sign of foul play and an autopsy was to be performed. Vale, a Monterey County prosecutor for 10 years who was recently promoted to assistant district attorney, was the focus of nationwide media attention stemming from a mix-up that exposed a murder witness to retaliation. Sonjii Johnson, 23, of Seaside, was shot to death in the driveway of her parents' home in August 1989. Bradley Hardison, 25, is accused of slaying Ms. Johnson so she could not testify against him in another case. Vale and a police officer had earlier mistakenly telephoned a woman named Sonya Johnson, who spread the word that Sonjii Johnson must be helping police. The district attorney's office has maintained that the case was not mishandled. The nationally syndicated television program ``A Current Affair'' recently broadcast a segment on the phone call and Ms. Johnson's subsequent death. Vale ``was affected deeply by having his name connected'' with the case, said Superior Court Judge John Phillips. ``I guess we didn't know how strongly he was affected,'' he said. Vale joined the county prosecutor's office in 1979 and ``developed into one of the finest, most dedicated prosecutors any county could ever have,'' said Phillips, who in his former post as assistant district attorney hired Vale.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Aide Leaves Iraq after Visit to Saddam
DOC.TEXT: Soviet envoy Yevgeny Primakov, a close associate and aide of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, left Iraq on Saturday after delivering a message from the Soviet president to President Saddam Hussein. Primakov, a member of the Soviet Presidential Council, said he ``will remain optimistic that a peaceful and political settlement for this crisis is always possible,'' according to a Baghdad-based Soviet journalist who met with Primakov before he left. The Soviet news agency Tass reported that Saddam had assured Primakov that Soviets in Iraq may leave the country soon. About 5,000 Soviet workers, many of them described as oil industry technicians, have been prevented from leaving Iraq since the invasion, although they are not among the Westerners held as ``guests'' at hotels and strategic sites in an effort to deter attacks. Primakov told Saddam that the Kremlin ``favors a political settlement of the gulf crisis, bearing in mind a return to the situation that existed before Aug. 2,'' the Soviet news agency Tass reported. He repeated Moscow's belief that Saddam should withdraw immediately from Kuwait, which Iraq invaded on Aug. 2, Tass said. Tass quoted Primakov as saying, ``Settlement of the Kuwaiti crisis on this basis should give an impetus to the settlement of other conflicts in the region, above all the Arab-Israeli conflict.'' During his stay, Primakov met three times with Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, who was also visiting Baghdad. Primakov agreed that resolving the Iraq-Kuwait conflict was possible in connection with other Mideast issues, with priority being given to the Arab-Israeli question, diplomatic sources in Baghdad said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Primakov did not reveal the message he brought, but Tass said ``On the instruction of the Soviet president, Primakov raised the issue of the departure from Iraq of Soviet specialists wishing to go home.'' Primakov and Igor Belusov, the Soviet first deputy prime minister, met with Soviet citizens in Baghdad and at a township being built with Soviet help near the Euphrates River, Tass said. ``The two statesmen explained the steps by the Soviet government to ensure normal living conditions for Soviet people in the aggravated situation,'' Tass said. Belusov also met with Iraq's oil minister, Issam al-Chalabi, to discuss the stranded Soviet workers. State-run Iraqi News Agency reported the meeting but did not mention the Soviets who wished to return home.

DOC.HEAD: Wife of `Last POW' Dies in Apparent Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Dorothy Marian Shelton, who lobbied for families of missing servicemen as the wife of the last American still listed as a prisoner of war in Southeast Asia, has died in an apparent suicide. She was 57. Police said Friday that Mrs. Shelton died Thursday night from an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head. Family members said she left a note at her home professing her love for her five children, but it did not mention her husband or offer an explanation for her death. Mrs. Shelton's quest to learn her husband's fate took her to the jungles of Laos and the halls of Congress in the unwavering belief that Air Force Col. Charles E. Shelton was still alive. A friend said it was a terrible burden. ``Marian was carrying a very heavy load on her shoulders with her husband being the last POW. I think she said, `I just can't take another day of it.''' said Fran Masterson of Upland, whose husband was listed as missing in action during the Vietnam War. ``You go to sleep at night and your husband's not there. It just goes on and on and on. You ask yourself, `Is this ever going to end?' '' She is to be buried at Arlington National Cemetery outside Washington. Shelton, then a captain, was shot down over Laos on April 23, 1965, and captured a few days later. A Pentagon spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Edward Lundquist, was quoted this summer as saying the military believed Shelton died in the 1960s from malaria or dysentery. But the U.S. government made Shelton a symbol, promoting him, leaving him on the official rolls as a POW and sending an ``active duty'' pay check to his wife every month. The about 2,500 other men unaccounted for in Southeast Asia have been listed as presumed dead. For 25 years, Mrs. Shelton pressured legislators for help, traveled the world seeking information about her husband and appeared on numerous radio and television programs urging the government to provide more answers to families of the missing. Family members said she had been depressed recently but believed in the POW cause ``to her dying breath.'' ``She knows one way or another now,'' sister-in-law Faye Newcom said in a telephone interview from Owensboro, Ky. ``Either he's up there with her or she knows where he's at. Maybe she can do more good up there.'' ``She spent a lot of time looking for answers and couldn't find them,'' said retired Navy Capt. Red McDaniel, a POW for six years. ``But her death will strengthen the resolve of a lot of people. This issue will not go away.''

DOC.HEAD: Balloonists Killed At Albuquerque Fiesta
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with pilot's name, witnesses saying men jumped; picks up 3rd graf, `The Sandoval...' ADDS two grafs to add memorial service scheduled, FAA investigation.
DOC.TEXT: A hot-air balloon taking part in a balloon festival drifted into power lines and burst into flames Saturday, killing both men aboard. Pilot Steve Falacy, 46, and passenger William Schobel, 32, both of Albuquerque, died at University Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Annie Olson. She declined to release details of the men's injuries. Several people who witnessed the accident said the men jumped from the balloon before it burned. The Sandoval County Sheriff's Department, which responded to the 10 a.m. accident, said the pilot apparently was attempting to land in a nearby field when he drifted into the power lines. The accident occurred on the opening day of the 19th annual Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta, about a mile south of Bernalillo, some seven miles from Balloon Fiesta Park on Albuquerque's northeast side. About 150,000 spectators turned out to watch nearly 600 hot-air balloons launch under sunny and clear skies. Balloon Fiesta president Bob Ruppenthal said a memorial service for the men would be held Sunday morning and the festival would proceed as scheduled. The Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board will investigate the accident, Ruppenthal said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Airline Negotiates To Buy First Western-Made Jets
DOC.TEXT: Aeroflot, the Soviet national airline, is negotiating with Eastern Airlines to buy or lease 13 wide-body jets in a deal that could be worth more than $150 million to the troubled U.S. carrier. If finalized, it would be Aeroflot's first acquisition of aircraft manufactured in the West, officials said Friday. The Soviets are eyeing Lockheed L-1011 jetliners that Miami-based Eastern values at between $12 million to $14 million each. They range in age from 13 to 18 years old. ``We've offered to either sell them the planes or run the operation for them, including flying the planes or anything in between,'' Eastern executive Joseph Leonard said. ``Hopefully, we can negotiate something.'' A team of Aeroflot officials led by Alex Timofeev, general director of the airline's Moscow division, has been in Miami for a week talking with Eastern executives and test-flying the planes. The deal could be worth between $150 million and $200 million, depending on Eastern's level of shared service, said Allen Blattner, president of Jetborne International, who brought the two parties together. Any deal is at least 30 to 60 days away, Blattner said. If an agreement is reached, it would have to be approved by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York, where Eastern has filed for Chapter 11 protection.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Pact Reached In Louisiana Strike
DOC.TEXT: A union representing more than 5,000 teachers and other school employees reached a tentative agreement Saturday night that could end a three-week strike in Louisiana's largest public school district. Nat LaCour, president of the United Teachers of New Orleans, and Frank Fudesco, chief negotiator for the Orleans Parish School Board, said an accord was reached on a three-year contract, but refused to release details. LaCour said he would explain the offer to union members Sunday night and recommend they vote to approve it in time to return to work Monday. LaCour described the deal as a ``win-win situation.'' But Fudes said: ``Quite frankly, there will be some cutbacks in some manner, shape and form.'' Since the strike began Sept. 17, many teachers in the nation's 27th largest school district have crossed picket lines. District officials said 41 percent of the teachers were at work Friday, compared with union estimates that 36 percent had broken the strike. Striking teachers sought support Saturday afternoon near some polling places as primary elections were being held statewide. Voters were asked to sign petitions seeking the recall of school board president Carl Robinson and three other board members. Union members accused them of failing to negotiate in good faith. The union sought higher salaries and improved health benefits in a three-year contract. It had asked a federal mediator to join the talks, but the school board refused his offer to intervene. Earlier Saturday, Fudesco said he was ``extremely disappointed'' that the union continued to demand more money, but that the board would consider the request. LaCour said the money was available and union members deserved it. ``The board has indicated that it has $3 million from a recent bond sale, $3 million saved due to the strike, plus $2 million in expected sales tax increases. That's $8 million,'' he said. ``I think our demands can be met and this strike can be over in time for schools to begin normal operations on Monday.''

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Communist Party Makes Major Changes
DOC.TEXT: The Cuban Communist Party will allow local elections by secret, direct ballot, the Cuban government news agency Prensa Latina said, in an apparent move toward greater democaracy. The party party wants to be more ``flexible to the characteristics of the territory,'' the daily newspaper Granma reported. The report Friday was picked up by Prensa Latina, monitored in Mexico City. In elections scheduled for November through February, city and provincial committees will be elected by secret and direct vote and there will be 20 to 25 percent more candidates than committee seats, Prensa Latina said. In another development, the Central Committee secretariat reduced its own membership from seven members to five and the committee's departments from 19 to nine in what is said was an attempt to eliminate bureaucratic bloat. The agency quoted Granma as saying the committee wants to be an example of ``the coherent and systematic effort that is required to overcome the hypertrophy of the state aparatus, the administration and the political organizations of the masses.'' President Fidel Castro continues as first secretary of the secretariat and his brother Raul as second secretary. Other members are Ramon Machado, Julian Rizo and Carlos Aldana. Jorge Risquet, who will continue as a member of the Politburo, and Brig. Gen. Sergio Perez were removed. Perez headed the military department, which was replaced by a military commission under the Politburo. Castro has said repeatedly that he will never surrender his Socialist ideals or allow Socialism to fall as it did in Eastern Europe. Since reforms began in the Soviet Union in 1985, aid to Cuba from the Soviet Union and its former allies has fallen steadily, and Cuba's economy is ailing. ``The revolution will face this special period without throwing anyone into the street, without depriving a single citizen of his resources, without leaving anyone jobless,'' Castro said late last month.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Police Criticized For Blackface Drug Sting Busts
DOC.TEXT: An undercover police drug sting operation unofficially dubbed ``Operation Al Jolson'' because white detectives wore blackface makeup netted 30 arrests but was branded racist by black community leaders. Police halted the practice in the mostly black neighborhood of River Park after news reports brought complaints, but officials defended its use. ``Because the sales are made predominantly by blacks ... there's no way (detectives) could get out there and sell drugs standing on the corner looking the way they were,'' Naples Police Capt. Kevin Rambosk said recently. The department in the southwestern Florida city of about 18,000 residents has one black on a force of about 75 officers. The neighboring Collier County sheriff's department has 10 blacks on a force of 407 officers. The shortage of black officers is no excuse for the racial masquerade, a black leader said. ``The police seemed to be saying, `This is what a drug pusher would look like,''' said Fran Haugabrook. ``In other words, `A drug pusher is black.' It is offensive.'' The Naples Daily News published a package of stories in August about the controversial police technique. Shortly thereafter, a group of 249 residents demanded an investigation by the FBI and the attorneys general for Florida and the United States. Recently, Newsweek magazine carried a short but sharply worded item on the blackface anti-drug tactic they dubbed ``Operation Al Jolson.''
