Klaus Weakens, Moves Over Open Atlantic Waters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with 10:30 p.m. location and speed; picks up 8th graf, `It was ...
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Klaus weakened to a tropical storm Saturday and drifted into the open waters of the Atlantic after leaving at least six dead and 1,500 homeless from flooding in Martinique. Klaus' winds decreased from 75 mph to 65 mph early Saturday and the National Hurricane Center in Miami said a further decrease in strength was possible over the next 24 hours. The hurricane center lifted all storm warnings and watches that had been in effect for the islands of the northeastern Caribbean, but said small craft should avoid venturing into the northeast Caribbean until winds and seas subside. The storm skirted Antigua on Friday, tearing roofs from houses but causing no major damage. The storm moved from the northeastern Caribbean and into open Atlantic waters, causing rough seas but reducing the threat to island residents. At 10:30 p.m. EDT, Klaus was centered near 19.1 degrees north latitude and 62.6 degrees west longitude, or about 75 miles north-northeast of St. Martin, according to the hurricane center. Tropical storm-force winds extended 115 miles from its center. The system was moving northwest at about 5 mph and that general motion was expected to continue for the next 24 hours. It was not known whether the storm would reach the continental United States. Klaus was upgraded to a hurricane from a tropical storm Friday. Tropical storms become hurricanes when winds reach a sustained speed of 74 mph. Klaus is the 11th named storm and the sixth hurricane of the Atlantic hurricane season. The French island of Martinique south of the Leewards was by far the hardest hit by the storm. Heavy rain since Tuesday spawned landslides and serious flooding, blocking many roads and forcing 1,500 people from their homes. Authorities said six people were killed, including two young sisters swept from a bridge, and two fishermen were reported missing. Wind and flood damage also occurred on Barbados, Dominica and St. Lucia, but no injuries were reported from those islands. St. Lucia's Banana Growers Association said about 15 percent of this year's crop was destroyed. Damage was estimated at near $1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Scripps Announces $1 Million Journalism School Grant
DOC.TEXT: The Scripps Howard Foundation on Saturday announced a $1 million grant to the E.W. Scripps School of Journalism at Ohio University. The money will be used to establish a program to bring noted journalists to the school as teachers, lecturers or consultants, the foundation said. ``The Scripps Howard Visiting Professional Chair will give the school an infusion of fresh experience, providing students and faculty another valuable link to the real world of working journalists,'' said Albert Schottelkotte, foundation president. The foundation, established in 1962, gave its first grant of $1.5 million to the school in 1983. E.W. Scripps Co. is the Cincinnati-based media company founded by Edward Wyllis Scripps. It owns newspapers, television and radio stations.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb At Military Headquarters Raises Fears of More Unrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs, UPDATING with new explosion. Picks up 10th graf, Earlier Saturday . . .
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MLA5
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded outside the Finance Department on Sunday hours after a bombing at Defense headquarters, raising fears of continued unrest after a revolt ended on the Philippines' second-largest island. Both explosions came after the rebel leader, Col. Alexander Noble, surrendered and gave up his three-day secessionist revolt on Mindanao island. The mutiny was crushed after troops loyal to President Corazon Aquino bombed an army camp seized by rebels in Butuan city, 500 miles southeast of Manila. Noble, who took over another camp in neighboring Cagayan de Oro province, 500 miles to the south, gave up Saturday and was flown to Manila. Hours after Nobel surrendered, a bomb destroyed two jeeps and injured one person outside Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos' office at Camp Aguinaldo, a few yards where Noble was being detained. Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa said rebel soldiers may have set off that blast to get even with the recent blow to renegade forces. The second bombing, on Sunday, hurt no one and destroyed a cement plant box outside the Finance building. Police said both devices were the same type that rebel right-wing soldiers have been using in a series of bombings in the capital since mid-August. Guards closed the gates at the Camp Aguinaldo and barred anyone from entering or leaving. The camp has been on alert since the revolt erupted Thursday on Mindanao island. Sunday's blast was the 37th in the Manila area since Aug. 13 in what the military believes is a terror campaign by rightist rebels. The bombs raised fears of more attacks by military dissidents despite the failure of the seventh military rebellion during Mrs. Aquino's 4{-year-old administration. Earlier Saturday, de Villa said Noble's arrest dealt a severe blow to elements in the military who aim to topple the struggling government. Mrs. Aquino told Filipinos in a televised address that ``the constitution will be upheld with force if need be.'' She also asked Congress to enact legislation increasing the penalty for rebellion from six to 20 years imprisonment to life. Most Filipinos have little sympathy for military rebels. But the inability of the governmnt to control the dissidents has discredited a civilian administration that seems unable to deliver basic services, control prices and guide national development. That concern has been reflected in the business community, which is already alarmed over the prospects of economic decline brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis and the effects a July earthquake that killed more than 1,600 people. On Thursday, Noble's forces of about 800 soldiers, civilians and militiamen seized a garrison in Butuan, about 70 miles east of Cagayan de Oro. They were joined by about 150 elite Scout Rangers in Iligan, a major industrial center in northern Mindanao. They declared independence for the southern island in a move widely thought to be a prelude to an attack on the central government in Manila. The government crushed the revolt, in part with bombing raids. The uprising left one person dead, one wounded and one missing, military officials said. Officials said all garrisons were back in government hands Saturday. Government forces were rounding up Noble's followers, and hundreds were already in custody, authorities said. Noble was escorted to Manila by Brig. Gen. Arturo Enrile, superintendent of the Philippine Military Academy, and other armed forces officials. Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos said Noble's chief civilian ally, Reuben Canoy, also was arrested in Cagayan de Oro, where he once served as mayor. De Villa blamed Noble's defeat on the failure of his allies to come to his aid and instigate uprisings elsewhere in Mindanao. ``Certainly the surrender of Noble and the suppression of the pocket rebellion in northern Mindanao will greatly weaken this movement, which has been continuously bedeviling the country,'' de Villa said. Despite his surrender, Noble claimed he achieved his objectives of drawing attention to the problems of Mindanao. Noble, 42, was formerly chief of staff of Mrs. Aquino's guard force, but he turned against her and joined the coup attempt in December. He later fled to the jungles of northern Mindanao.

DOC.HEAD: Slovenia, Croatia Demand Radical Restructuring of Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: The rebellious republics of Croatia and Slovenia published a document Saturday demanding that Yugoslavia's federal system be refashioned into a loose confederation of sovereign states. The document, drafted by the leadership of the two republics, both of which are politically center-right, was published simultaneously in Slovenia and Coatia. It proposed that the present six republics become semi-independent states that would cooperate only for common economic and political interests. Each member of this ``union of sovereign states'' would have its own army and currency and could secede at any time. Yugoslavia, formed in 1918, has been a centralized federation since the Communist takeover in 1945. It is governed by a collective presidency. This Balkan nation of 23 million people has been torn by traditional rivalries among various religious and ethnic groups. Heightening the tensions have been recent political conflicts between republics with democratically elected governments and those still ruled by Communists. The Communist government in the largest republic of Serbia strongly opposes turning Yugoslavia into a confederation. It advocates ``a modern federation,'' with central rule remaining in Belgrade. Slovenian President Milan Kucan has said the only alternative to confederation would be breaking up Yugoslavia. He indicated Slovenia would otherwise secede or form a confederation with Croatia. Serbia's hardline President Slobodan Milosevic said recently that if Yugoslavia becomes a confederation, Serbia would demand its borders be changed to include about 500,000 Serbs now living in Croatia. On Friday, a small national army unit occupied the headquarters of Slovenia's regional defense forces in Ljubljana, the Slovenian capital, in a bid to reassert federal authority.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Abortion Clinic Trespassing Charge Against Priest
DOC.TEXT: A trespassing charge against a Roman Catholic priest accused of blocking abortion clinic doors was dismissed after a jury was unable to reach a verdict in the case. Municipal Court Judge Richard Van Dusen dismissed the charge against the Rev. George Peter Irving on Friday after a jury deadlocked 11-1 in favor of conviction. ``You're really dealing with a simple trespassing case that has larger moral issues thrown in,'' Van Dusen said. Prosecutors unsuccessfully moved to retry the priest after Van Dusen declared a mistrial. The judge said another jury was unlikely to reach a verdict either. Irving, 37, was the first anti-abortion activist in Los Angeles County permitted to use the so-called ``necessity defense,'' which allows defendants to argue that they broke a law to prevent a higher evil. Irving, associate pastor of Church of the Assumption, was arrested Dec. 19, when 100 anti-abortion protesters gathered outside Clinica Eva, a family planning clinic in El Monte. In several hundred similar anti-abortion trespassing cases, prosecutors have successfully barred the ``necessity defense'' on grounds abortion is legal and therefore does not pose a ``significant evil'' that would warrant breaking the law. The mistrial came as the Archdiocese of Los Angeles and parishes around the country prepared for ``Respect Life Sunday.'' Los Angeles Archbishop Roger Mahony urged all priests and deacons to preach special anti-abortion sermons Sunday and throughout the month. Operation Rescue anti-abortion leaders hailed the dismissal of charges as a ``victory for unborn children,'' but abortion rights activists said the judge's decision sent the wrong message. ``This says it's OK to be easy on a criminal just because he's wearing a collar,'' said Robin Schneider, executive director of the California Abortion Rights Action League.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Want Slovak as Only Official Language
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people gathered in Bratislava, the capital of the Slovak republic, demanding that Slovak be the only official language in the republic, according to a news report Saturday. The rally by demonstrators from throughout Slovakia seemed directed against the Hungarian minority of at least 570,000 living in the Slovak republic, the daily Lidove Noviny reported. It appeared to have nationalist overtones. Hungarian is used in some kindergartens and schools and in a few teachers' training colleges. Plans exist to set up a Hungarian-language university in Slovakia. Leaders of the separatist Slovak National Party want Slovak to be the only official language. Slovak is similar to Czech, the language of the other republic of Czechoslovakia. Speakers at the Bratislava rally also demanded creation of an independent and sovereign Slovak state, the daily said. Czechoslovakia is now a confederation. The only speaker who supported confederation was jeered.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Marriage is a Lifesaver
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Listen up, bachelors! Being single can be deadly, according to a national study that says unmarried, middle-aged men are twice as likely to die as those who have spouses. And don't think living together will save your lives. ``Even single men who live with someone other than a spouse have a higher death rate,'' Maradee Davis, primary author of the university study, said Friday. ``It seems to be the presence of a spouse that's protective.'' Twenty-three percent of men ages 45 to 54 who lived without a spouse died within 10 years, compared to 11 percent of similarly aged men who lived with their wives, according to the study by epidemiologists at the University of California at San Francisco. The study also found that 7.7 percent of women ages 45 to 54 who lived without a spouse died within 10 years, compared to 4 percent of the married women in the same age group. But overall, women's risk was linked to low income, not the type of living arrangement, researchers said. The study analyzed data compiled by the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey. The 7,651 subjects from across the United States ranged in age from 45 to 74 and were studied from 1971 to 1975 and then again from 1982 to 1984. Researchers theorize that both middle-aged men and women died sooner than their married counterparts because of factors such as a poor diet, alcohol consumption, smoking, a lack of exercise and low income. Marriage apparently breeds better living habits, while the single life often includes more drinking, smoking and perhaps too many beer nuts and party snacks and not enough square meals. ``For men, the health behavior factors tended to explain the difference (in death rates),'' said Davis, an associate professor of epidemiology. ``In our society, men generally are not able to take care of their everyday needs. ``But, for women, a high proportion of those who are single head households and usually have low incomes.'' Researchers also said they believe that men don't have as much life-enhancing social support as women outside of marriage. ``Men derive a lot of social support by being married, but women have a more widespread social support system outside of marriage,'' Davis said. Davis said researchers began the study, funded by the National Institute on Aging, because of a concern about an increasing number of older adults living alone in the United States. In the study group, slightly more than half of women ages 65 to 74 in the study were living alone or with someone other than a spouse, compared to 19 percent of the men in the same age group. ``Because of the high divorce rate in the United States and the trend toward older adults choosing to live alone if they are widowed, there is a general concern about the social isolation, health and well-being of older adults living alone,'' Davis said. Davis presented the study Thursday to the 118th annual meeting of the American Public Health Association in New York City.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-government Protesters Attack Police Stations, Burn Cars
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of protesters attacked two police stations, set several government vehicles ablaze and burned down part of the main market in this West African capital. The demonstrators turned violent Friday when soldiers forced them out of a courtroom during the trial of two people accused of distributing tracts that were deemed hostile to the military government of Gen. Gnassingbe Eyadema. Eyadema seized power in a coup in 1967 and rules this nation as a one-party state. The content of the tracts was not immediately available, but many African countries have been hit by a wave of unrest this year as demonstrators demand multiparty democracy. The protests had not touched Togo, however. Those expelled from the court spread out across town, with two groups attacking two police stations and others stoning and setting fire to government vehicles. Other protesters set stalls ablaze in the main market. Calm returned in the middle of the day after soldiers were stationed at intersections and othe strategic points in the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Charges Dropped Against President's Son
DOC.TEXT: Murder charges against a son of President Kenneth Kaunda in the shooting death of a 20-year-old woman were dropped, court officials said. A court in Lusaka instead ordered Kambarage Kaunda, 26, to face manslaughter charges, a spokesman at the Lusaka magistrate's court said Friday. Rafique Mulla, accused with Kaunda of involvement in the shooting last year, was acquitted by Lusaka magistrate Peter Chitengi during a hearing Friday, said the spokesman, who by custom spoke on condition of anonymity. Attorneys for Kaunda had asked for a court ruling on whether police had sufficient evidence to charge him with murder. Prosecutors say the woman, Tabeth Mwanza, was a former girlfriend of Kaunda and that the two quarreled before the shooting in September 1989. Kaunda pleaded innocent during earlier hearings and said he opened fire in self-defense when a mob hurled stones at his car in Lusaka. Kaunda, one of the Zambian president's seven children, said he did not know the dead woman.

DOC.HEAD: Man Enraged by Noisy Youths Fires Deadly Shot
DOC.TEXT: NEUILLY-SUR-MARNE, France (AP) - A man who said he was upset by a group of noisy youths in a low-rent housing district fired a rifle shot at them, killing a 19-year-old with a wound to the heart, police said. Khemissi Karar died moments after the Thursday night shooting at the Cite des Fauvettes, east of Paris, one of numerous high-rise developments that house low-income residents, often immigrants. Police said Friday they found the murder weapon during their investigation of the apartment tower from where the shot was fired. They did not identify the suspect. Karar, a Frenchman born in Algeria, was talking loudly with two friends at the foot of the tower when the shot was fired, police said. ``Khemissi was anything but mean,'' said his friend Mustapha, 18, who was with him when the shooting occurred. He said people in the building often ``threw objects, tomatoes or bear cans'' when young people gathered below to talk.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Federal Government Shuts Down; Budget Stalemate Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Incorporates bulletin material, pick up 4th graf: ``Senate Majority,'' now 8th graf ^By ALAN FRAM
DOC.TEXT: Much of the federal government shut down at midnight Friday, victim to a deepening budget standoff between the White House and Congress. ``The hour of reckoning is at hand,'' President Bush said in a statement Friday night. The president refused to sign or veto 11th-hour legislation passed by Congress restoring the government's power to spend money, choosing instead to let the shutdown commence. ``The president simply feels we ought to quit fooling around,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. ``Surely the reality of a government shutdown will convince everyone a solution should be found.'' The budget dispute has prevented Congress from approving any appropriations bills for the fiscal year that began Monday, effectively leaving the government with no money. The U.S. Constitution states, ``No money shall be drawn from the Treasury but in consequence of appropriations made by law.'' Only those services needed to ``protect life and property'' were to continue in the absence of a budget, White House budget director Richard Darman wrote in a memo to agency chiefs. With the long holiday weekend about to start, it seemed likely that the full brunt of the shutdown would not be felt until Tuesday. But the Park Service was preparing to close the Statue of Liberty, the Washington Monument and other tourist favorites, at least for the weekend. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell criticized Bush for his decision. ``I believe it is inflicting needless pain and anguish on thousands of American families and I do not believe it is creating the kind of atmosphere that enhances the chances for an agreement,'' said Mitchell, D-Maine. The Senate sent the measure to Bush on a voice vote Friday night, shortly after Democrats rammed it through the House by a tally of 300-113. The measure, fully financing the government through next Friday, even got some Republican support in the House. The president has 10 days to sign or veto the bill, but Fitzwater said Bush hoped to have a budget solution in hand ``before that.'' ``I don't know what the answer is right now,'' said Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass. ``But I do know one thing. Chaos is not the answer.'' Congress planned a Saturday session - and possible sessions throughout the three-day Columbus Day weekend - because of the fiscal standoff. The specter of federal agencies having no funds to operate arose after the House early Friday resoundingly defeated a budget agreeent worked out by Bush and congressional leaders. As lawmakers began trying to put together new packages, they revived talk of perhaps cutting the capital gains tax rate and raising income tax rates for the rich. To boost pressure on budget writers to forge a spending plan for the five-day-old fiscal year, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush would not sign any such temporary financing bill. ``We would close down the government at midnight'' Friday unless Congress completes a broad budget outline by then, Fitzwater said. Fitzwater said Bush followed the debate in the House on cable television in the family living quarters at the White House. Most of the nation's 2.4 million federal workers were told to report on Tuesday - after Monday's federal holiday - even if only to be sent home after they arrived. Congressional leaders of both parties met with administration officials to grope for a deficit-cutting plan that would be acceptable to lawmakers just a month shy of Election Day. Democrats sought support for a new plan with fewer cuts for the elderly and the poor, but there were no signs that Republicans were willing to accept it. Democrats also said they would be willing to consider cuts in the capital gains tax rate, a Republican proposal, in exchange for higher taxes for the rich. Budget negotiators had rejected the tradeoff last week. Earlier, in a Thursday night session that stretched into Friday morning, a rebellious House overwhelmingly defeated the $500-billion compromise package of tax boosts and spending slashes that Bush and congressional leaders preferred. That vote was an embarrassment to administration officials and top lawmakers of both parties, who had waged an all-out lobbying thrust on behalf of the measure. Uncertainty reigned on Capitol Hill. ``This thing could be - who knows?'' said a confused Rep. Robert Matsui, D-Calif. Democrats hoped that by sending the emergency spending bill to Bush, the president - and not Congress - would be blamed for the closure. But lawmakers of both parties agreed that all sides looked bad in light of the seemingly endless budget battle. Rep. Jack Buechner, R-Mo., tugged on a tie bearing a Mickey Mouse pattern and said, ``Everybody ought to have these on today.'' The House's 254-179 rejection of the budget was driven by unhappiness among members of all stripes. Conservatives disliked its $134 billion in taxes and as well as its spending cuts they considered overly gentle. Liberals thought the $60 billion in Medicare reductions, including cuts in benefits, were too steep. They said the plan's higher levies on gasoline, heating oil, tobacco and alcohol would hit the poor too hard. And members of both parties said they resented the process by which the package was written - four months of closed-door summit talks involving only congressional leaders and administration officials. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said he believed that as a result, lawmakers should try to write a budget themselves, perhaps with reduced Medicare cuts and a lesser tax burden for low-income people. ``We will, of course, keep in touch with the White House, but I do not anticipate ... the resumption of anything that would be called summit talks,'' he said. Foley said he wanted a budget that would be supported by a majority of Democrats and Republicans. ``I am not of the opinion that political warfare is of some value at this point,'' he said. But not all lawmakers agreed. Conservative Republicans urged Bush to keep the government shut down until Democrats agreed to limit federal spending. ``A budget plan ought to be put together by the president in consultation with Republicans,'' said Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas. ``Tell the Democrats to put up their best shot. We'll sustain every veto he's got.''

DOC.HEAD: Disturbing Images Came From Photographer's Life
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents may offend some readers.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Mapplethorpe Trial, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In the early 1970s, Robert Mapplethorpe took his first photographs with a Polaroid camera. It was the perfect tool for radical art. What was radical about his work was not so much the subject matter but the process and materials he applied to a stagnant form, adding fabric, texture, tone. Form and technique, however, are not what spring to mind these days when considering the late artist. Today, it is the rough images he immortalized - oral sex, bondage, homosexual fondling - that give him an important place in 20th-century art. Perhaps Mapplethorpe never fully realized his destiny as an artist. He died in March 1989 at the age of 42 of complications from acquired immune deficiency syndrome. In death, he has become a symbol for artistic freedom. On Friday, a jury acquitted the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati, and its director, Dennis Barrie, of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. The charges were prompted by the exhibit ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment,'' which had a seven week-run last spring and drew more than 80,000 people, an attendance record for an art exhibit in Cincinnati. The show closes this week in Boston. A Mapplethorpe exhibit last year at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington was canceled after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., declared some of the artist's photographs to be obscene. Helms' objections resulted in a move by Congress to limit federal funds to the arts. ``I wasn't starting out to make a statement, that isn't the way I work,'' Mapplethorpe once said. ``The statement grows out of what I do.'' In his 1976-77 work ``Bill,'' Mapplethorpe placed a mirror between two panels of a man masturbating. The idea is to have the viewer seehhim or herself flanked by two erect penises. He used the same technique in 1979's ``Easter Lilies With Mirror.'' Here, four panels form a cross around a center mirror. The lilies are shown in dramatic shadows, a dusting of light illuminating their inner and almost religious beauty. It is a way of engaging the viewer beyond mere voyeurism; the viewer becomes a part of the work. The intense shadow composition of the triptych ``Jim and Tom, Sausalito'' (1977-78) is obliterated by the action in the picture, in which one man urinates on another. Around the same time, Mapplethorpe did a self-portrait, posed partly naked in leather with the handle of a bullwhip in his rectum. They are among his most disturbing photographs, from a period in which he unraveled a violent homosexual mystique for an unsuspecting audience. They are terrifying, sadomasochistic tableaux - chained men, leather-bound men, men prepared for pain in an aristocratic setting. But despite the frightening and sometimes sickening roughness of these sexual and psychological images, Mapplethorpe succeeded in crafting a rich tonal range. ``He was involved in an incredibly wide variety of life, the other side of which is death,'' said the artist Lowell Nesbitt, who first met and befriended Mapplethorpe in 1971-72. ``It's very clear that much of his photographs were mirrors of his personal life. I think that Mapplethorpe really wanted to be censored. He was pushing for it. He was pushing the artistic barriers, the way many artists have in the past, to see how far he could push before he could met a boundary.'' Back in the early '70s, a time of rainbow drugs and easy sex, of troubled politics and an unpopular war, Mapplethorpe was into refashioning jewelry by adding materials to customize a piece for the owner. Mapplethorpe was one of six children born to Joan and Harry Mapplethorpe. He fled his Catholic childhood in Floral Park, Queens, for the bohemian earthiness of Brooklyn in the 1960s. There, he received his art education at Pratt Institute. It also was there that he encountered and forged a lasting friendship with radical poet and musician Patti Smith. He spent his artistic lifetime photographing her, in pictures ranging from early Polaroids to the portrait he used on her 1988 LP, ``Dream of Life.'' He did portraits of actor Richard Gere, artists Louise Nevelson and Alice Neel, lawyer Roy Cohn, body builder Lisa Lyon and transvestite Candy Darling. And they were as varied as his classically poetic studies of flowers, fruit and vegetables. Mapplethorpe's eye consumed more than merely the flat surface of a photo. He infused light and shadow, certainly, but he also applied textures and tones, using fabric and paint such as platinum on linen or mesh wire overlays. His early work utilized collage for drama and movement. In his last years, his work was austere. A 1988 picture titled ``Nipple'' could be a parched desert, the moon's surface or a dried river bed. But it is a closeup of the human form. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Dolores Barclay has been the AP Arts and Entertainment Editor for 11 years.

DOC.HEAD: Sequence of Events in Obscenity Trial
With PM-Mapplethorpe Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events in the obscenity case based on photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe: -April 1987-Dec. 1988: Mapplethorpe assembles an exhibition called ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment'' in consultation with Janet Kardon, curator of the Institute for Contemporary Art in Philadelphia. -Oct. 1988: Dennis Barrie, the director of the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati, decides to display the exhibit, calling it ``the most stunning photographic show I'd seen in years.'' -March 1989: Mapplethorpe dies at age 42 of AIDS in Boston. -June 1989: The Corcoran Gallery in Washington, D.C., cancels a planned Mapplethorpe exhibition. The gallery director says she acted to defuse debate over government support to the arts. -March 16, 1990: Hamilton County Sheriff Simon L. Leis Jr. says in an interview that he considers parts of the planned 175-picture exhibition legally obscene and says he plans to take legal action if Cincinnati police don't act. -March 27: The Contemporary Arts Center files a lawsuit seeking a court ruling on whether the pictures are obscene before the exhibition opens. -April 2: Cincinnati police vice officers review the Mapplethorpe exhibition at the gallery's request, but decline to file charges. -April 6: A Hamilton County Municipal Court judge dismisses the gallery's lawsuit. The exhibition opens with a private showing to more than 4,000 dues-paying gallery patrons. -April 7: The exhibition opens to the public, and more than 8,000 see it the first day. A county grand jury indicts the Contemporary Arts Center and Barrie on misdemeanor counts of pandering obscenity and using children in material involving nudity. The indictment covers five pictures depicting sex acts and two showing children with their genitals exposed. -April 8: U.S. District Judge Carl B. Rubin issues an injunction barring police from seizing the photographs at the gallery. -April 16: Barrie and the Contemporary Arts Center plead innocent before Judge David J. Albanese in Hamilton County Municipal Court. -April 19: County Prosecutor Arthur M. Ney turns the case over to city prosecutors, saying his office cannot handle it because it involves only misdemeanor charges. -April 23: The Association of Art Museum Directors, which represents directors of 176 museum directors in the United States and Canada, promises to pay any fine imposed on Barrie and the Contemporary Arts Center. -May 26: The exhibition closes after more than 81,000 people pay to see it, making it the largest arts event in Cincinnati history. -June 20: Albanese, rejecting defense arguments that the artistic quality of two pictures of children make them immune from child-nudity law, orders Barrie and the gallery to stand trial Sept. 24 on the child-nudity charge. -Aug. 1: The exhibit opens in Boston at the Institute for Contemporary Art. -Sept. 5, 1990: A Municipal Court clerk in Boston refuses a request by critics of the show to file obscenity charges. -Sept. 6: Albanese rules that jurors in Barrie's trial will consider only the seven photos named in the indictment, saying they need to find that only one of the pictures is obscene to return a conviction. The judge orders Barrie and the gallery to stand trial Sept. 24 on the obscenity charge. -Sept. 24, 1990: The trial begins. -Oct. 2: Mrs. Kardon testifies that she considered the pictures to be artistically important. She says she found the pictures of the two children non-sexual and morally innocent. -Oct. 3: Barrie testifies in his own defense, saying he recognized the controversial nature of the photos before the exhibition began. But he says Mapplethorpe was an important artist whose work the public should be able to see. -Oct. 4: Judith Reisman, the prosecution's only expert witness, testifies that the photos of sex acts lack artistic value and that the photos of the children could encourage child abuse. -Oct. 5: Jurors deliberate just two hours before finding Barrie and the Contemporary Arts Center innocent on all charges. The exhibit closes in Boston, after 103,000 people paid to see the photographs.

DOC.HEAD: House OKs Catchall Crime Bill
DOC.TEXT: A tough, election-year crime bill that became a catchall for House members intent on sending a law-and-order message to voters is headed to a compromise committee with a veto threat attached. The House passed the bill, 368-55, Friday after first adopting a lengthy list of amendments. Most stiffened penalties and criminal law. But the House also backed a provision barring execution of prisoners who can show that their death sentence was imposed because of racial discrimination. The administration has strongly opposed that provision, and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh issued a statement reiterating that President Bush will veto ``a bill that imposes racial quotas on our death penalty laws.'' The bill goes back to the Senate, which has passed its own version, and then to a conference committee to resolve differences. Among other amendments adopted by the House was one allowing the government to seize the homes of savings and loan executives convicted of fraud and who were using state homestead laws to keep their residences - even when they are multimillion-dollar mansions. Another established minimum penalties for sale of drugs within 1,000 feet of a truck stop or highway rest area. The House voted 216-204 to reject an amendment that would have removed a racial justice provision for the appeal of death penalty cases. That provision would allow death row inmates to use racial statistics in their appeals to show the sentencing courts were biased, and bars execution of prisoners who demonstrate their death sentence was imposed because of racial discrimination. Rep. James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., offered the amendment to delete the provision, with supporters saying it would dramatically weaken and perhaps abolish use of the death penalty. Backers said there was indisputable evidence that blacks are more likely to be sentenced to die than are whites. Rep. Jim Slattery, D-Kan., cited what he said was an ``incredible fact: never in the history of this country has a white man been convicted and executed for killing a black man or any minority.'' ``As far as I'm concerned that makes the case there has been discrimination in the imposition of capital punishment,'' Slattery said. Congressional staffers said that assertion covered the more than 125 executions carried out since capital punishment resumed in 1977. The Supreme court approved new state death penalty laws in 1976, replacing those struck down by the court as unconstitutional in their application in 1972. The House adopted another amendment lessening the burden of proof on the government to counter such evidence. The Senate excluded such a provision when it passed its version of the crime bill. Bush and congressional conservatives have been highly critical of the racial provision. In his statement, Attorney General Thornburgh clled on House and Senate conferees to ``delete this misguided provision and send to the president's desk a bill which does not nullify the death penalty.'' ``Unfortunately, the House bill as passed would have the effect of nullifying many state death sentences now in effect and would threaten future enforcement of the death penalty at both the federal level and in the 37 states with capital punishment laws,'' Thornburgh said. A dozen more crimes would be subject to the federal death penalty and executions would be carried out more quickly, as a result of amendments added to the bill. ``I hope we never bring up another crime bill a month before an election,'' said Rep. William Hughes, D-N.J.. He complained during the debate that campaign considerations were overshadowing all else.

President Bush summoned congressional leaders to the White House and began closing down the government today in an attempt to pressure lawmakers into reaching a bipartisan budget compromise. ``The president believes they need to get on with the job and settle this issue right now,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said at a Friday night news briefing during which he blamed the 12:01 a.m. shutdown on Congress. ``The president simply feels we ought to quit fooling around,'' Fitzwater said. ``Surely the reality of a government shutdown will convince everyone a solution should be found.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, returned the favor. He told reporters that Bush was responsible for the shutdown because his people insisted on ``the very positions which led to the defeat'' of the proposed budget. ---= CINCINNATI (AP) - Sexually graphic photos by Robert Mapplethorpe have artistic value, a jury ruled in acquitting an art gallery and its director of obscenity charges in a closely watched trial. A Hamilton County Municipal Court jury Friday cleared Cincinnati's Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, of one count each of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related photos in the exhibit, ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment.'' Barrie said he was grateful at the outcome in the nation's first obscenity trial of an art gallery, but lamented that battles over artistic freedom were still being waged. ``I'm glad this fight is over in Cincinnati, but it's not over in the rest of our country,'' he said. ``I will be in a number of cities speaking about this issue.'' ---= MANILA, Philippines (AP) - The leader of a military revolt on the country's second-largest island surrendered today, ending the latest attempt to overthrow Corazon Aquino's struggling government. The military chief of staff, Gen. Renato de Villa, said the arrest dealt a severe blow to those trying to topple the president. It was the seventh military rebellion during her 4{-year administration. ``Let me be precise once again in stating that the constitution will be upheld with force if need be,'' Mrs. Aquino said in a television address. The uprising's leader, Col. Alexander Noble, gave up early today at a military garrison he seized in Cagayan de Oro, 500 miles south of Manila. ---= UNITED NATIONS (AP) - Iraq told U.N. members that the United States and its allies are trying to control the world's oil reserves, but the U.S. ambassador dismissed the charges as lies. Other opponents of Iraq, including the Soviet Union and exiled Kuwaiti leaders, joined Friday in the angry replies to Iraq's latest accusations, made in a speech at the United Nations. Saudi Arabia's ambassador said Iraq had committed ``an unforgivable crime, a crime to shine in the history of crimes'' by invading Kuwait on Aug. 2. In Washington, there was renewed worry about Iraq's military potential. Five senators called for a Pentagon study of how Iraq might have gained control of technology to make so-called fuel-air explosives. Such bombs carry 10 times the power of conventional explosives without the fallout of nuclear weapons. Military officials say the United States has no ready defense against the explosives, which could devastate oil fields, air bases and troops, the Los Angeles Times reported. ---= AURORA, Colo. (AP) - A housewife constantly racing to keep up with her active 4-year-old son has found a high-tech way to get him home in a hurry - she beeps him. ``When Jonathan's beeper goes off, he is home, which is nice.
